1 l980 - 2050 - Broward Co., Ft. Lauderdale, Oakland Park, Pompano Beach - A tornado damaged apartments, businesses, schools, and homes. A woman  was blown off her 6th floor balcony and killed. A fishing boat was found hanging from the power lines. Thirty-three injuries.   1 - 2 l994 - Okaloosa, Walton, Bay, Leon Counties - Thunderstorms produced rainfall of five to 8 inches over the Florida panhandle. The 8.22 inches at Tallahassee was the sixth highest 24-hour total in the city's history. The rain caused widespread street and small stream flooding with damage to cars, mobile homes and a school. Four vehicles in Tallahassee were swept off roads, but no one was injured.  2 1941 - morning - Freezing temperatures spread into south central Florida.   2 l972 - l230 - Jackson Co., Mariana - Thunderstorm winds capsized a boat and two men drowned. Tornadoes also struck Pensacola, Jay, and Port St. Joe.   2 1994 - morning-afternoon - central and south Florida - Severe thunderstorms ahead of a strong low pressure system and cold front spread over the peninsula. Tornadoes were reported in Polk, Charlotte, Collier, Broward, and Monroe Counties. Severe thunderstorm winds were reported in Sarasota, Pinellas, Polk, Volusia, Highlands, St. Lucie, Dade, and Duval Counties. The tornadoes were weak and thunderstorm wind gusts were in the 55 to 65 mph range. As a result there was no widespread property damage. The only injuries occurred in Collier Co. when a weak tornado rolled an unanchored mobile home injuring a man and woman inside. The woman was hospitalized.  3 l960 - 0530 - Lake/Orange Co. - Tornado hit l0 homes in Orange Co. l small home was leveled and four people injured near Groveland.   3 l962 - Palm Beach Co., Boynton Beach - Wind driven waves washed l man off a fishing vessel and he drowned.   3 - Outbreaks of four or more tornadoes have struck the Florida Peninsula on March 3rd in l97l, l978, and l99l, more than any other day.   3 l971 - Afternoon - West Central Florida - Tornado Outbreak - Severe thunderstorms and seven tornadoes touched down from Ft. Myers and Sarasota to Tampa to Gainesville as a squall line crossed central Florida. Only l injury directly resulted from storms. A man drowned when his boat capsized in high winds.   3 l978 - Afternoon - Central and South Florida - Tornado outbreak - five tornadoes and l3 severe thunderstorms were reported from Tampa and Ft. Myers to West Palm Beach and Miami as a squall line crossed the peninsula ahead of a fast-moving cold front. Despite widespread minor property damage, only l injury was reported at Belle Glade.   3 l99l  - Morning to Afternoon - Statewide - Severe Weather Outbreak. Many severe thunderstorms and at least eight tornadoes struck from Apalachicola to West Palm Beach as an intense squall line ahead of a cold front swept across the State. Thirty-four severe storm reports were received, but property damage was minor. This outbreak is noteworthy because the only injury was caused by 2.5" hail that crashed through the window of a car, knocking the driver unconscious in Volusia County at Ormond by the Sea. This is believed to be the only serious injury from hail in Florida since l959.  4 l972 - l459 - Broward Co., Ft. Lauderdale - Tornado damaged about l34 homes in the Pembroke Pines retirement area injuring six.  5 l970 - l232 - Brevard Co., Titusville - Tornado ripped through two subdivisions, damaging about 35 homes injuring seven.  6 l954 - morning - northern Florida - Snow - Accumulated depths: - Milton 4 inches; Niceville 3 inches; Pensacola 2 inches; Caryville l inch. Southern and eastern limits of reports of snow or sleet were Panama City, Live Oak, and Jacksonville.  6 l982 - afternoon - Pinellas, Dade, Highlands Co. - A tornado moved through St. Petersburg, overturning four airplanes, damaging others, causing roof damage and downing power lines. A tornado in Miami damaged l00 homes, cars, and miles of power lines. A tornado in Sebring damaged l0 homes.  6 l992 - Early Evening - Central Florida - Hail up to l.75" covered the ground up to a foot deep in southwest Seminole County. l.75" hail fell in Lake County and l.25" hail fell in Orange County. Severe Thunderstorm winds caused damage in Orange, Seminole, Brevard, and Indian River Counties. Damage ran into the millions, but there were no serious injuries.  7- 9 - l962 - Florida East Coast - Beach Erosion - Large waves generated by winds of an intense Atlantic storm pounded beaches along entire east Florida coast during three day period. Tides along the coast at time of high tide ranged two to 3 feet above normal. Superimposed wave action caused considerable erosion and several beach roads and properties were inundated. Greatest damages occurred between Melbourne and Miami Beach. One death in Miami Beach occurred while fighting an electrical fire caused when rising waters created a short circuit. Nearly all damages resulted from heavy ground swells rather than high tides.  8 l99l - l7l9 - St. Johns Co., St. Augustine - Severe thunderstorm wind Gusts to 58 mph north of St. Augustine. Radio antenna and large oak tree downed.  9 l973 - 0020- Marion Co., Belleview - A tornado skipped through Belleview and Lake George, damaging l7 homes and destroying one. Six injuries reported.  l0 l99l - l030 - Seminole Co., Geneva - High winds capsized a l5 ft boat on Lake Harney, two men drowned, l was rescued.  10-11 1996 - Nassau, Duval, St. Johns and Flagler Counties - Winter Storm - A strong Nor'easter with winds of 50 to 60 mph caused damage from Amelia Island to Flagler beach. At Amelia Island, 6 to 12 feet of beach was lost on the island's south end. Atlantic Beach - between one-third and one-half of the sand added during the previous summer's beach re-nourishment project was washed away. St. Augustine Beach - about half of the beach re-nourishment project south of city hall was wiped out. Flagler Beach - about 100 feet of the 840-foot pier was lost. Estimated property damage was over $1 million dollars.  ll l944 - 2030 - Polk Co., Agricola - Tornado destroyed a large barn and unroofed a house. 2100 - Polk Co., Welcome - Tornado unroofed two large houses and destroyed a small one.  12 l95l - afternoon-evening - Sarasota Co., Nokomis - Waterspout/Tornado moved in from the Gulf of Mexico damaging seven homes and eight buildings. Other Waterspouts were reported off Clearwater and severe thunderstorm winds caused minor damage in Tampa area.  l2-l3 l993 - 2200-l430 - All  Florida - Tornados, Thunderstorm Winds, Hail, High Winds, Storm Surge, Flood, Beach Erosion, Snow - The "Storm Of The Century" or "SuperStorm" roared across Florida producing a variety of severe and unusual weather conditions for about l8 hours from late Friday the l2th through late afternoon Saturday the l3th. A severe squall line raced eastward at over 50 mph ahead of an intense low producing several tornadoes and strong downbursts as it moved through the state and directly caused seven fatalities. This was followed by an unprecedented (for the Gulf Coast) winter storm surge of nine to l2 feet in Taylor County, with storm surges and/or tidal and wind driven flooding of five to 9 feet elsewhere along the Gulf Coast to the Keys. This was followed by a period of eight to l2 hours of high sustained winds of up to 50 mph with gusts to 70 mph, keeping tides much above normal along the west coast and causing severe beach erosion in many areas. As colder air poured in behind the intense low up to four inches of snow fell in the panhandle from north of Pensacola to Crestview, and a trace to 3 inches of snow fell elsewhere across north Florida. Record or near record low temperatures occurred over much of the state the following two nights. Total number of fatalities from the storm was 47, including l4 from storm surge and flooding, seven from tornadoes and/or strong downbursts, and four from high winds in the aftermath of the squall line. Eleven people drowned offshore in the Gulf of Mexico after strong winds swamped or capsized ships (including seven crewmen from a 200-ft Honduran freighter). Eleven others died during rescue operations and cleanup activities. Total property damage was estimated at $l.6 billion. Details follow:  12 l993 - 2338 - Levy Co., Chiefland - A tornado struck a home in which four people were asleep, pinning two of them under a fallen wall and suffocating them. Two others were injured. A nearby mobile home was destroyed killing its elderly occupant. The tornado went on to destroy or damage other mobile homes injuring five more people, and knocking down trees and power lines.  13 l97l - afternoon - Clay Co., Starke - Lightning killed a 50 yr. old woman fishing on a boat.   l3 l993 - Manatee County, Terra Ceia Bay - Thunderstorm winds -A man who lived on a houseboat drowned while apparently attempting to evacuate the boat in strong winds.  l3 l993 - 0020 - Alachua Co., LaCrosse - A tornado destroyed a mobile home killing l person and injuring four others. Trees and power lines down. A few houses destroyed, one by propane explosion.   13 l993 - 0030 - Lake County, Mt. Dora - Tornado - A small fast-moving tornado touched down near Howey-in-the-Hills and moved northeast striking Mt. Dora and continued northeast until dissipating in Volusia County. A 5-month old baby boy was killed in a mobile home l0 miles northeast of Mt. Dora at 0050 EST. The mobile home was destroyed and two adults in it were seriously injured. In all l3 homes were destroyed, 80 suffered major damage and 266 reported minor damage.  l3 l993 - 0405 - Pinellas County, Clearwater - High Winds - Winds to 6l mph were recorded at the Clearwater Pass Bridge. Two boaters in a sailboat were drowned when they apparently were pushed into the bridge pilings and capsized.   l3 l993 - Citrus County, N. Homosassa - High Winds -Two males were apparently washed overboard from a fishing boat and drowned. Their bodies were recovered a week later.  13 l993 - 0420 - Taylor County, Coastal Areas - Storm Surge - A l0 - to l2-foot storm surge moved into the coast destroying 57 homes. Ten people were killed, nine at Dekle Beach and one at Keaton Beach.  l3 l993 - 0452 - Dade County, Narrowrowanja - Thunderstorm Winds overturned a mobile home, killing one person and injuring another.   l3 l993 - 0530 - Hernando County, Aripeka to Hernando Beach - Flood - Flood waters about nine feet deep inundated the coastal area with most residents in water chest deep. One person suffered a heart attack and died attempting to evacuate out of the flooded area. 6l homes were destroyed, 3,300 damaged, and l00 people evacuated.   l3 l993 - 0530 - Pasco County, Hudson to Aripeka - Flood - Water at least 9 feet deep flooded homes and businesses. An elderly woman drowned in her home.   l3 l993 - 0545 - Levy County, Cedar Key - Storm Surge - A 9.5 foot storm surge was reported and l20 homes were flooded. An elderly male died while attempting to evacuate the flood.  l3 l993 - 0600 - Pinellas County, Honeymoon Island - High Winds - A 38-ft fishing vessel was swamped by 20-30 foot seas seven miles west of the coast. One crew member drowned and the other was rescued by the Coast Guard.   l3 l993 - l035 - Broward County, Davie - High Winds uprooted a tree that struck and killed a person.   l3 l993 - ll34 - Broward County, Pompano Beach - High Winds caused a building to collapse, killing a motorcyclist who was standing near it.  14 l986 - 0400 thru l445 - North and Central Florida - Severe Weather Outbreak - A squall line moved across North Central Florida producing at least nine tornadoes and many severe thunderstorms. In Gainesville, a tornado threw a pickup truck l00 ft - two stores were unroofed and gutted and seven others damaged. A wind gust of 85 mph reported in Taylor Co. A tornado in Orange Lake downed power poles and pine trees, and a large tree was blown over and destroyed a mobile home roof in Putnam Co. A tornado in Astor Park damaged several mobile homes. High winds blew the roof off a large equipment shed in St. Johns Co. A gust of 63 mph was reported at Daytona Beach airport. A tornado at Palm Coast damaged the roof of a shopping center and downed several power lines. A tornado in Belleview damaged a 3-car garage and barn. A tornado in Deltona destroyed utility sheds and carports, uprooted trees, and damaged roofs in a nine-block area. A 27 year old man was injured in Hillsborough Co. while working on a roof when lightning hit the roof.  14 l993 - l000 - Highlands County, Lake Charles - A Waterspout picked up a l6-ft boat and overturned it, spilling the two boaters into the water. One drowned, and the other was rescued two hours later.  15 - l8 l960 - north and central Florida - Citrus, Marion, Lake, Seminole, Brevard, Orange, Osceola, Polk, Sumter, Hernando, Pasco and Hillsborough Counties - Heavy Rain and Flood - Generally more than l0 inches of rain fell on a large section of central Florida during this 4-day period and the area of Pasco, Hernando, most of Sumter and the northern portion of Hillsborough counties received close to l5 inches of rain. Many points reported hail, high wind and tornadoes at some point during the period. Resulting high water and river overflow wreaked havoc on roads, bridges and agricultural crops. River overflow and/or accumulated waters in poorly drained areas forced many residents from their homes in several effected counties. Flood on the Hillsborough River considered worst since September l933. Total storm damage, including that of hail, wind, tornadoes, flood and other causes estimated near $20 million, half of which was sustained by agriculture.  16 l986 - 0850 - Hillsborough Co.- Thunderstorm winds blew over a trailer and killed a man. Hail damaged vegetable crops.  l7 l928 - 00l0 - Lake/Orange Cos.- Tornado moved from Lake Jem to Mt. Dora. A woman was killed when she was thrown from her disintegrating home.   l7 l960 - Afternoon - Polk County, Haines City - Lightning killed one person.   l7 l973 - early morning - Central Florida - Tornado Outbreak - Five tornadoes struck from Pinellas Co. to Brevard Co. as a squall line ahead of a fast moving cold front swept across the Florida Peninsula. Tornadoes struck near Treasure Island, Zephyrhills, Winter Haven, Haines City, and Sharpes. Three injuries were reported.   17 l985 - 0430 - Sarasota Co., Venice - A tornado destroyed 55 CBS houses and caused major damage to l50 houses, minor damage to l00 houses. A 65 year old woman was killed inside a camper. A 66 year old man was killed standing on his front porch. 45 people injured.  17 1995 - 0430 - Volusia Co., Daytona Beach - A Canadian tourist who had been swimming with two friends drowned in a rip current behind the La Playa Cocktail Lounge.  l8 l960 - Hillsborough Co. - All time record flood crest on Hillsborough River near Zephyrhills.   l8 l975 - 2140 - St. Johns Co., St. Augustine - Tornado unroofed houses, damaged a school, trailers, and an auto showroom.   l8 l991 - l0l4 - Polk Co., Lakeland - A tornado touched down three times. Thirteen mobile homes destroyed, 85 mobile homes damaged, l90 houses and apartments, telephone, power lines, and trees downed. Two injuries.  19 l965 - 1800 - Gadsden Co.- Three-quarter inch hail fell, damaging tobacco shades. Hail covered ground three to 4 inches deep in spots.   19 l98l - 0045 - Orange Co., Orlando - A tornado destroyed l2 houses, damaged 35 more, and destroyed two mobile - injuring one. 0200 - Osceola Co., St. Cloud - A tornado destroyed four mobile homes, damaged several others, and destroyed a house. Eleven injuries.  20 l929 - Jackson & Gadsden Counties - All time record flood crest (79.6') on the Apalachicola River at Chattahoochee, near the present day site of Woodruff Dam.  20 l964 - 0550 - Pinellas Co., St. Petersburg - Tornado damaged and unroofed 20 homes.   20 l984 - l000 - Bay Co., Panama City - High winds destroyed a motel roof, blew down trees, utility poles, destroyed four townhouses under construction. Twenty car windows were broken.  21 1929 - Calhoun and Liberty Counties - All time record flood crest (28.6') on the Apalachicola River at Blountstown.   21 1950 - Bay Co. - Hail up to 2 1/2 inches in diameter struck the Panama City area. At Tyndall AFB hailstones ripped through airplane wings, smashed windows and heavily damaged cars. Several people suffered minor injuries. Damage was estimated at two million dollars.   21 l993 - l400 - Indian River Co., Vero Beach - Flash flooding damaged about 50 homes and many roads around Hwy 60 were washed out.  22 l957 - l600-l700 - Polk Co., near Waverly - Hailstones of golf-ball size hit citrus groves in 2- square-mile area, stripping trees of foliage and knocking large amounts of fruit from trees. Many oranges split open, some grapefruit completely penetrated by hail but left hanging on trees.   22 l968 - 1140 - Okaloosa Co., Destin - A tornado damaged a museum, motel, and three cars. Minor damage at Destin Airport.  23 l984 - 0830 - Hendry Co., Labelle - Lightning struck two men under a piece of equipment, killing one.  24 l983 - Morning - Central-South Florida - Severe Weather Outbreak - A strong squall line moved across peninsular Florida, producing tornadoes in Winter Haven, Polk Co., Kenansville, Osceola Co., Cocoa Beach, Merritt Island, and Melbourne in Brevard Co. Severe thunderstorm winds and hail struck Citrus, Hardee, Hernando, Pasco, Hillsborough, Pinellas, Broward, and Dade Counties. Two injuries were reported.  25 l909 - 0700 - Polk Co., Kathleen - Tornado killed a person in one of 8 homes destroyed.   25 1955 - afternoon - central Florida - Large Hail caused heavy roof damage to homes and barns in Sumter County. Large hail also fell in Pasco, Hernando, Polk, and Indian River Counties. Hail of lesser size was reported in Lake and Brevard counties.   25 l973 - l600 - Sarasota Co., Casey Key - Lighting killed a l9 year old surfer standing near the water's edge.  25 l992 - Evening -  Central Florida - Hailstorm - The worst hailstorm in Florida history struck the Orlando area just three weeks after one of the worst hailstorms in Central Florida history (see 3/6/92). Hail up to baseball size hit the University of Central Florida (UCF) and the vast greenhouse areas in western Orange County, crippling the nursery industry in the area. Damage was estimated at 60 - l00 million dollars. Smaller hail also fell in North Florida and as far South as Miami. Thunderstorm winds destroyed a citrus packing plant near Groveland in Lake County, injuring eight. The largest official hailstone recorded was 3.00" at the UCF - the third largest Florida hailstone on record, but residents reported larger hail that melted. While it will remain debatable whether the largest hail of all time fell in this storm (that distinction - 4 1/2"- belongs with the 3/30/95 Polk Co. hailstorm), it was clearly the costliest hailstorm in Florida history.  26 l964 - afternoon - Duval Co., Jacksonville - Wind and lightning caused a limb to fall, killing a man working in the yard. Lightning struck a jetliner on the ground at airport and injured three employees.  27 l946 - l300 - Suwannee C o., Houston - Tornado destroyed some barns and unroofed a school.  28 1955 - One inch of snow fell in northwest Florida. This is the latest date of measureable snow on record.   28 - 3l - l972 Statewide - Extended Severe Weather - A series of squall lines starting on the 28th preceded a cold frontal passage on the 3lst. Thunderstorms with high winds, hail, heavy rains, and tornadoes were reported. Damage totals were in the millions. Rainfall averaged 2" to 4" during this time, with many individual stations reporting over 5". Details are reported below.   28 l972 - afternoon - Panhandle/northwest Florida - Severe Weather Outbreak - A severe squall line spawned eight tornadoes and many severe thunderstorms as it moved across north Florida. Tornadoes were reported in Altha, Milton, Tallahassee, Starke, near St. Augustine, and at Keystone Heights in Clay Co. 20 people were injured in Gainesville when thunderstorm winds collapsed a circus tent. Lightning injured several people and started several fires.  29 l972 - Afternoon-Evenin g - Panhandle/north Florida - Severe Weather hit area for second straight day. Several tornadoes and severe thunderstorms reported from Pensacola and Panama City to Jacksonville. A report of hailstones up to 3 l/2" that did considerable damage in the Freeport, Walton Co. area is the second largest on record for the State of Florida.  28-29 l982 - Martin & Palm Beach Cos. -  Coastal storm - Very heavy rains and high winds struck the Florida Gold Coast around the Palm Beach area. Lantana, a suburb of Palm Beach, measured l6 inches of rain in 24 hours. High seas sunk a Haitian freighter and drowned ll people. Two other people were killed because of the storm. Hundreds of homes and cars were flooded. The Lake Worth Pier sustained heavy damage.  29 l990 - l545 - north Lake Co. - Thunderstorm winds downed trees and power lines. A 72 year old man drowned while docking his boat in high winds.  30 l939 - 22l0 - Duval Co. , Jacksonville - Deadliest northeast Florida tornado - killed four workers at a turpentine plant. Ten small homes were destroyed. A roof was carried for 2 miles.   30 l974 - 0200 - Gadsden Co. - A tornado struck near Hinson uprooting trees, destroying a home, large double mobile home, and damaging the Concordia Church - injuring four. A woman died of injuries several days later.   30 l990 - l400 - Duval Co., Jacksonville - Lightning killed a construction worker on a loading dock roof.  30 1996 - Afternoon - evening - Central Florida - Severe Weather Outbreak - Tornadoes were documented in Hernando, Sumter, Lake, Polk, and Brevard counties. In Brevard County, a waterspout /tornado touched down in Merritt Island and Cape Canaveral, tearing out windows and damaging roofs on six homes, destroying a small building on a used car lot, and damaging the roof of a night club and a dive shop. 25 other buildings in the area received minor damage. Windows were blown out of 30 vehicles. Damage estimates were near $500,000.  Hail, most the size of baseballs, severely damaged the roofs, knocked out windows in nearly 600 homes, and severely damaged 3,000 vehicles in Lake Wales, Polk County. Softball size hail (4.50-inch) also occurred in Lake Wales, which set a new record as the largest documented hail for the state of Florida. Hail accumulated to a depth of one foot in Bartow.  Golf ball size hail (1.75-inch) fell in Hillsborough, Lake, Orange, Seminole, Brevard, Osceola and Martin counties. An 86 mph wind gust at Bartow Municipal Airport caused window and roof damage to the FAA tower, severely damaged roofs and doors of two businesses at the airport, and overturned and demolished five mobile homes on wheels at a mobile home plant on airport property. Winds blew down trees in Chuluota, Seminole County, in Mulberry, Polk County, and damaged a van and injured one person in Ocoee, Orange County. Total property damage was estimated at $28 million dollars, with the storm producing the record size hail causing the majority of the damage at nearly $25 million dollars.  31 l93l - l030 - Polk Co., Mulberry - Tornado damaged or destroyed 20 small homes and unroofed l large home, injuring nine.   31 l933 -2030 - Escambia/Santa Rosa Counties - Tornado moved northeast from Pensacola and destroyed three small homes. Five injuries were in a home thrown into a tree.   3l l939 - 0730 - Volusia Co., Daytona Beach - Tornado unroofed a house injuring three, then moved out to sea.   31 l949 - 0930 - Okaloosa Co., Niceville - Tornado destroyed a home, injuring one person, then unroofed another home. Trees were uprooted and twisted off.   31 l962 - 0900 - Santa Rosa Co. - Tornad o - one of the deadliest in Florida History, struck northeast of Milton, destroying 75 small homes. Trailers and cars were thrown several l00 ft. About 200 other homes and buildings were damaged. About 80 injuries required treatment. A mother and three young children were killed in their home. At least l0 homes had a single death. Total deaths - l7. Tornadoes were also reported in Okaloosa and Escambia Counties in the morning and Bay County in the afternoon.  31 l972 - morning - afternoon - Central Florida - Severe Weather Outbreak. At least l0 tornadoes, and many high wind reports were received as a squall line crossed the Peninsula. Tornadoes were reported in Brooksville, Plymouth, Apopka, Longwood, N. Orlando, Tampa, Allenhurst (Brevard Co.), Kennedy Space Center, Brandon, and Loxahatchee. Pinellas Co. and Tampa were hardest hit with several hundred homes damaged and six injured.   31 l994 - l750 - Volusia Co., Ormond Beach - Strong winds produced rip currents that drowned a boy visiting from Louisiana.  31 1996 - Afternoon - early evening - North central to southeast Florida - Severe weather hit for the second day in a row.  A small tornado blew down a few trees on S. R. 60 west of Vero Beach.  Baseball to softball size hail was reported near Fellsmere, while dime to golf ball size hail occurred from Levy to Dade county, causing over a quarter million dollars damage to property and crops. Lightning struck and injured a man on Miami Beach. In Levy County, two large pine trees were snapped at the base and downed at Cedar Key.

HURRICANE IRENE...AT 5PM EDT THE CENTER OF HURRICANE IRENE WAS  LOCATED NEAR LATITUDE 25.6 NORTH...LONGITUDE 81.0 WEST OR  APPROXIMATELY 330 MILES SOUTH SOUTHWEST OF JACKSONVILLE. THE STORM  WAS MOVING TOWARD THE NORTH NORTHEAST NEAR 12 MPH. A GRADUAL TURN TO  THE NORTH IS EXPECTED OVER THE NEXT 24 HOURS.   TRACK INFORMATION...ALONG THE FORECASTED TRACK IRENE IS EXPECTED TO MOVE ACROSS SOUTHERN AND CENTRAL FLORIDA THROUGH SATURDAY  AFTERNOON AND SHOULD EMERGE INTO THE ATLANTIC BETWEEN DAYTONA BEACH  AND ST. AUGUSTINE ON SATURDAY EVENING.    WIND INFORMATION...ON THE CURRENT FORECAST TRACK...THE HIGHEST WINDS  WILL BE ALONG THE IMMEDIATE COAST AND ADJACENT ATLANTIC COASTAL  WATERS. SUSTAINED WINDS BETWEEN 40 AND 45 MPH WITH OCCASIONAL HIGHER  GUSTS ARE EXPECTED TO MOVE OVER THE IMMEDIATE COASTAL SECTIONS OF  FLAGLER BEACH SATURDAY MORNING AND SPREAD NORTH TO NEAR THE  FLORIDA-GEORGIA BORDER BY EARLY EVENING.   OFFSHORE...SUSTAINED WINDS OF 40 TO 50 MPH WITH HIGHER GUSTS ARE EXPECTED OVER THE COASTAL WATERS BEGINNING SATURDAY AFTERNOON AND CONTINUING THROUGH SUNDAY MORNING.  INLAND...WEST OF THE ST. JOHNS RIVER FROM DOWNTOWN JACKSONVILLE  SOUTHWARD...AND WEST OF INTERSTATE 95 NORTH OF DOWNTOWN  JACKSONVILLE...SUSTAINED WINDS OF 25 TO 30 MPH WITH HIGHER GUSTS CAN  BE EXPECTED.  RAINFALL...RAINFALL AND ASSOCIATED LOCALIZED FLOODING IS EXPECTED TO  BE ONE OF THE PRIMARY THREATS ASSOCIATED WITH IRENE. AS THE STORM  APPROACHES GENERAL RAINFALL AMOUNTS OF 3 TO 6 INCHES ARE ANTICIPATED  WITH LOCALLY HIGHER AMOUNTS POSSIBLE. RESIDENTS OF THE NORMALLY  FLOOD PRONE AREAS AND THOSE AREAS WITH POOR DRAINAGE SHOULD BE  PREPARED FOR THE POSSIBILITY OF FLOODING.   STORM SURGE AND TIDES...A SIGNIFICANT STORM SURGE IS NOT EXPECTED  ALONG THE COAST. EAST TO NORTHEAST WINDS ARE ALREADY BLOWING ACROSS  THE COASTAL WATERS AND WILL GRADUALLY INCREASE AS THE STORM  APPROACHES THE REGION. TIDES OF 1 TO 3 FEET ABOVE NORMAL ON THE OPEN  OCEAN AND 1 TO 2 FEET ON THE ST. JOHNS RIVER AND THE ESTUARY SYSTEM  ARE POSSIBLE. IT MUST BE REMEMBERED THAT THE DRAINAGE IN LARGE  PORTION OF THE AREA IS DEPENDENT ON THE TIDE LEVEL. IT IS POSSIBLE  THAT DRAINAGE MAY BE INHIBITED AT THE TIME OF HIGH TIDE AND WITH  HEAVY RAINFALL THE NORMALLY FLOOD PRONE LOW LYING AREAS MAY  EXPERIENCE FLOODING CONDITIONS.  SURF...WILL CONTINUE TO INCREASE AND BREAKERS OF 6 TO 8 FEET ARE EXPECTED. THIS WILL MAINTAIN THE THREAT OF RIP CURRENTS OR RUN OUTS THROUGH SUNDAY.   ...PREPAREDNESS RECOMMENDATONS... RESIDENTS OF NORTH FLORIDA AND SOUTHEASTERN GEORGIA ARE URGED TO  CLOSELY MONITOR THE PROGRESS OF IRENE.    INTERESTS IN NORTH FLORIDA AND SOUTHEAST GEORGIA SHOULD MONITOR  LOCAL MEDIA...CABLE TELEVISION OR NOAA WEATHER RADIO OF FURTHER  INFORMATION...WATCHES OR POSSIBLE WARNINGS. AT 5 PM EDT THE CENTER OF HURRICANE IRENE WAS LOCATED NEAR LATITUDE 25.6 NORTH...LONGITUDE  81.0 WEST OR ABOUT 175 MILES SOUTH SOUTHWEST OF MELBOURNE. IRENE IS MOVING TOWARD THE NORTH NORTHEAST NEAR 12 MPH. A GRADUAL TURN TO THE NORTH IS EXPECTED OVER THE NEXT 24 HOURS. MAXIMUM SUSTAINED WINDS ARE NEAR  85 MPH...WITH HIGHER GUSTS.  ...PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS... HURRICANE IRENE IS INLAND OVER SOUTH FLORIDA AND IS FORECAST TO MOVE ACROSS EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA THROUGH SATURDAY. RESIDENTS OF EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA SHOULD PREPARE FOR FLOODING RAINFALL AND TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS FROM IRENE. RESIDENTS OF LOW LYING AND FLOOD PRONE AREAS SHOULD REMAIN ALERT FOR THE ISSUANCE OF FLOOD WARNINGS AND BE PREPARED TO TAKE ACTION TO PROTECT LIFE AND PROPERTY. ALSO...LOOSE OBJECTS THAT CAN BE BLOWN ABOUT BY THE WIND SHOULD BE SECURED OR BROUGHT INSIDE BEFORE DARK.  ...CURRENT RADAR/SEVERE WEATHER THREAT... AT 515PM...THE MAIN RAINBANDS ASSOCIATED WITH IRENE WERE OVER BROWARD COUNTY AND OFFSHORE PALM BEACH COUNTY. THESE RAINBANDS AND ASSOCIATED HEAVY RAIN WILL BEGIN MOVING INTO MARTIN COUNTY BY 6PM AND WILL QUICKLY RESULT IN LOCALIZED FLOODING. RESIDENTS SHOULD BE ALERT FOR THE ISSUANCE OF FLOOD WARNINGS. FLOODING RAINFALL WILL SPREAD INTO ST LUCIE...OKEECHOBEE... AND INDIAN RIVER COUNTIES LATER THIS THE EVENING. BRIEF...ISOLATED TORNADOES ARE POSSIBLE IN OUTER RAINBANDS THROUGH THE NIGHT. THESE TYPE OF TORNADOES OFTEN SPIN UP QUICKLY AS STRONG RAINBAND CONVECTION MOVES ONSHORE. TORNADO WARNINGS MAY BE ISSUED LATER TONIGHT.  ...WIND AND RAINFALL INFORMATION... FLOODING IS THE GREATEST THREAT FROM IRENE WITH 8 TO 12 INCHES OF RAIN ARE POSSIBLE. SOME AREAS OF EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA HAVE EXPERIENCED 24 INCHES OF RAIN IN THE PAST 30 DAYS. ANY ADDITIONAL RAIN WILL QUICKLY CAUSE SERIOUS FLOODING PROBLEMS.  BASED ON THE CURRENT FORECAST TRACK TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS SHOULD BEGIN TO SPREAD OVER MARTIN...ST LUCIE AND OKEECHOBEE COUNTIES THIS EARLY THIS EVENING AND SPREAD OVER ALL OF EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA DURING THE NIGHT AND THROUGH THE DAY SATURDAY. THE ORLANDO METRO AREA AND SANFORD COULD SEE TROPICAL STORM FORCE GUSTS BY DAYBREAK SATURDAY. PEAK WIND GUSTS DURING IRENE ARE EXPECTED TO BE IN THE 50 TO 60 MPH RANGE WHICH WILL NOT CAUSE WIDESPREAD DAMAGE... BUT WILL BLOW TREE LIMBS ON POWER LINES CAUSING SCATTERED OUTAGES... POSSIBLY BRING DOWN OLDER DISEASED TREES. THE STRONGEST WIND GUSTS WILL LIKELY OCCUR IN RAIN SQUALLS WITHIN RAINBANDS MOVING ONSHORE.  ...STORM SURGE AND STORM TIDE INFORMATION... SIGNIFICANT STORM SURGE IS NOT EXPECTED ALONG THE COAST...HOWEVER... SUSTAINED ONSHORE WINDS OF TROPICAL STORM FORCE WILL PRODUCE EXTREMELY ROUGH SURF...RIP CURRENTS...ADDITIONAL MINOR BEACH EROSION...AND POSSIBLY SOME MINOR COASTAL FLOODING...ESPECIALLY AROUND THE TIME OF HIGH TIDE. HIGH TIDES ALONG THE EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA COAST FROM DAYTONA BEACH TO FT PIERCE WILL BE JUST AFTER MIDNIGHT TONIGHT AND JUST AFTER 1PM SATURDAY AFTERNOON  ...NEXT UPDATE... THIS STATEMENT APPLIES TO PEOPLE IN ALL OF THE FLORIDA KEYS OF  MONROE COUNTY CONCERNING THE EFFECTS OF HURRICANE IRENE.    ...WARNINGS... A HURRICANE WARNING IS IN EFFECT FOR ALL OF THE FLORIDA KEYS. A  HURRICANE WARNING MEANS THAT HURRICANE CONDITIONS ARE EXPECTED OR  OCCURRING.    A FLOOD WARNING IS IN EFFECT FOR THE KEYS THROUGH 800 PM. A FLOOD  WARNING MEANS THAT FLOODING IS OCCURRING OR IMMINENT WITHIN THE  WARNED AREA.  ...WATCHES... A FLOOD WATCH IS ALSO IN EFFECT FOR ALL OF THE KEYS THROUGH TONIGHT.  A FLOOD WATCH MEANS THE THREAT OF FLOODING EXISTS WITHIN THE WATCH  AREA.  ...STORM INFORMATION... AT 500 PM EDT THE CENTER OF HURRICANE IRENE WAS NEAR LATITUDE 25.6  NORTH...LONGITUDE 81.2 WEST...OR ABOUT 45 MILES WEST-SOUTHWEST OF  MIAMI AND 60 MILES SOUTHEAST OF NAPLES. MOTION WAS TO THE NORTH-  NORTHEAST NEAR 12 MPH.        AT 500 PM EDT THE CENTRAL PRESSURE OF IRENE WAS 985 MB OR 29.09  INCHES. MAXIMUM SUSTAINED WINDS WERE 85 MPH WITH HIGHER GUSTS. THIS  MAKES IRENE A CATEGORY ONE ON THE SAFFIR-SIMPSON SCALE. IRENE IS  EXPECTED TO WEAKEN AS IT MOVES OVER THE FLORIDA PENINSULA TONIGHT  AND TOMORROW.   ...PRECAUTIONARY ACTIONS... A CITY OF KEY WEST IMPOSED CURFEW ON NON-EMERGENCY VEHICULAR AND  PEDESTRIAN TRAFFIC DUE TO DOWNED WIRES AND WATER ON ROADWAYS EXPIRED  AT 400 PM...BUT RESIDENTS ARE STRONGLY URGED TO REMAIN AT HOME BY  THE MONROE COUNTY SHERIFF.    US1 IS BLOCKED AT MM 75 DUE TO HIGH WATER AND DEBRIS. TRAFFIC WILL  NOT RESUME UNTIL WATERS RECEDE...SAND CAN BE CLEARED FROM THE  HIGHWAY AND AN INSPECTION OF THE ROAD REVEALS A VENUE FOR SAFE  PASSAGE.  PLEASE LEAVE THE ROADWAYS FREE FOR EMERGENCY VEHICLES.   BOATERS SHOULD REMAIN IN PORT.   THE MONROE COUNTY RUMOR CONTROL PHONE NUMBER IS 1-800-955-5504. HERE YOU MAY OBTAIN THE LATEST AVAILABLE INFORMATION ON COUNTY-WIDE  ACTIVITIES.  THREE STORM SHELTERS ARE OPEN FOR RESIDENTS LIVING IN LOW-LYING OR  FLOOD-PRONE AREAS INCLUDING MOBILE HOMES OR RECREATIONAL VEHICLES.  THE SHELTERS ARE AT GLYNN ARCHER SCHOOL ON WHITE STREET IN KEY  WEST...STANLEY SWITLIK SCHOOL (MILE MARKER 48 BAYSIDE) IN  MARATHON... AND KEY LARGO ELEMENTARY (MILE MARKER 106) IN KEY LARGO.  CITY AND COUNTY OFFICES REMAIN CLOSED.  ...STORM SURGE FLOODING/TIDES/MARINE HAZARDS... BOATERS SHOULD STAY IN PORT UNTIL IRENE PASSES AND CONDITIONS  SUBSIDE.   SOME MINOR TIDAL OVERFLOW IS POSSIBLE ALONG THE KEYS NEAR THE TIMES  OF HIGH TIDE. STORM SURGE FLOODING OF 2 TO 4 FEET ABOVE NORMAL TIDE  LEVELS IS EXPECTED ALONG BOTH SIDES OF THE UPPER KEYS. PLEASE SEE  THE LATEST SHORT-TERM FORECAST FOR FURTHER DETAILS.   TIMES OF THE NEXT HIGH TIDES...  KEY WEST HARBOR 207 AM SAT  WHALE HARBOR CHANNEL  139 AM SAT  OCEAN REEF CLUB 113 AM SAT   ...WIND INFORMATION... SUSTAINED WINDS AT 500 PM AT KEY WEST AIRPORT WERE FROM THE  NORTHWEST AROUND 25 MPH WITH GUSTS TO 35 MPH. AT MARATHON AIRPORT  WINDS WERE SOUTHWEST 15-20 MPH GUSTING TO 35 MPH. RECENT WIND GUSTS  OF 41 MPH WAS OBSERVED AT THE C-MAN STATION AT DRY TORTUGAS...45 MPH  AT SAND KEY...59 MPH AT SOMBRERO KEY...67 MPH AT LONG KEY AND 74 MPH  AT MOLASSES REEF. GUSTS TO 80 MPH ARE STILL POSSIBLE IN SQUALLS OVER  THE COASTAL WATERS.   ...RAINFALL INFORMATION... KEEP IN MIND THAT A FLOOD WARNING IS IN EFFECT FOR ALL OF THE  FLORIDA KEYS THROUGH 800 PM. THIS MEANS FLOODING IS OCCURRING OR  IMMINENT. A FLOOD WATCH IS ALSO IN EFFECT FOR ALL OF THE KEYS  THROUGH TONIGHT. YOU SHOULD MONITOR WEATHER CONDITIONS CLOSELY AND  BE READY TO MOVE AWAY FROM LOW LYING AREAS IF FLOODING IS OBSERVED.  MORE RAIN IS EXPECTED THROUGH SATURDAY WHICH COULD CAUSE CONTINUED  FLOODING OF LOW LYING AREAS. TOTAL RAINFALL ALONG THE PATH OF IRENE  WILL RANGE UP TO 10 TO 15 INCHES. LOCALLY HIGHER AMOUNTS ARE  POSSIBLE.  RAIN BANDS WILL CONTINUE TO MOVE ACROSS THE UPPER KEYS BRINGING VERY  HEAVY RAINS...ESPECIALLY FROM ROCK HARBOR TO OCEAN REEF. RECENT  RAINFALL AMOUNTS IN THIS AREA INDICATE THAT 2 TO 3 INCHES HAVE  FALLEN BETWEEN 2 AND 5 PM. FLOOD WATCH FOR REMAINDER OF SOUTH FLORIDA THROUGH SATURDAY   A HURRICANE WARNING IS IN EFFECT FOR COLLIER AND MAINLAND MONROE  COUNTIES AND MIAMI-DADE COUNTY SOUTH OF FLORIDA CITY.  TROPICAL STORM WARNING AND HURRICANE WATCH IN EFFECT FROM FLORIDA  CITY TO JUPITER INLET..INCLUDING LAKE OKEECHOBEE.  THIS  INCLUDES MOST OF MIAMI-DADE AND ALL OF BROWARD AND PALM BEACH  COUNTIES.   AN INLAND HIGH WIND WARNING IS IN EFFECT FOR GLADES AND HENDRY  COUNTIES THROUGH TONIGHT.  ...CENTER LOCATION MOVEMENT INTENSITY AND TREND... AT 5 PM EDT THE CENTER OF HURRICANE IRENE WAS LOCATED NEAR 25.6N 81.0W...INLAND OVER MAINLAND MONROE COUNTY...60 MILES  SOUTHEAST OF NAPLES...OR ABOUT 45 MILES SOUTHWEST OF MIAMI. IRENE IS  MOVING TO THE NORTH NORTHEAST AT 12 MPH AND THIS MOTION IS EXPECTED  TO CONTINUE FOR THE NEXT 24 HOURS.  MAXIMUM WINDS ARE ESTIMATED TO BE NEAR 85 MPH WITH HIGHER GUSTS  WHICH MAKES IRENE A CATEGORY ONE HURRICANE ON THE SAFFIR-SIMPSON  SCALE. IRENE WILL WEAKEN SOMEWHAT OVER LAND. MINIMUM CENTRAL  PRESSURE IS 985 MB.  ...RAINFALL AND FLOODING WIDESPREAD STORM RAINFALL TOTALS OF 6 TO 10 INCHES HAVE OCCURRED  ACROSS SOUTHEAST FLORIDA WITH LOCAL AMOUNTS OF 12 TO 14 INCHES.  THROUGH 3 PM...HOMESTEAD AIR RESERVE BASE REPORTED A STORM TOTAL OF  10.97 INCHES. SOUTHWEST FLORIDA HAS RECEIVED 2 TO 4 INCHES.  ADDITIONAL RAINFALL AMOUNTS OF 4 TO 8 INCHES ARE POSSIBLE BEFORE THE  RAIN ENDS SATURDAY.  FLOODING IS OCCURRING IN POORLY DRAINED AREAS. THE HEAVY RAINS WILL  PUT PRESSURE ON FLAT TOPPED ROOFS WHICH MAY LEAK OR COLLAPSE FROM  THE WEIGHT OF THE WATER.  MOTORISTS ARE URGED TO USE EXTREME CAUTION. STANDING WATER ON  ROADWAYS CAN CAUSE MOTORISTS TO DRIVE INTO CANALS OR OTHER DEEP  WATER. PARENTS ARE URGED TO SUPERVISE CHILDREN TO PREVENT THEM FROM  PLAYING IN FLOODED AREAS WHERE HAZARDS INCLUDE SHARP UNDERWATER  OBJECTS...STORM DRAINS AND CONTAMINATED WATER.   ...STORM SURGE/TIDE/OTHER MARINE HAZARDS THE STORM SURGE ALONG THE SOUTHWEST FLORIDA COAST THIS EVENING AND  TONIGHT WILL BE A MAXIMUM OF 5 TO 7 FEET. RIP  CURRENTS ARE POSSIBLE ALONG THE BEACHES OF SOUTHEAST FLORIDA.  ...TORNADOES THERE IS STILL A THREAT FROM TORNADOES AND WATERSPOUTS. A SHELTER IS ALSO  OPEN IN GLADES COUNTY.  ...PROTECTIVE ACTIONS... PERSONS ARE URGED TO REMAIN INDOORS TONIGHT. THESE CONDITIONS WILL CONTINUE TO SPREAD NORTH TO PALM  BEACH COUNTY BEFORE 130 PM... AND TO GLADES HENDRY COUNTIES BY  AROUND 2 PM. THERE IS STILL A  POSSIBILITY OF THUNDERSTORMS ALONG WITH ISOLATED TORNADOES ACROSS  MOST OF SOUTH FLORIDA THROUGH THE AFTERNOON HOURS. FLOOD WATCH FOR REMAINDER OF SOUTH FLORIDA THROUGH SATURDAY   A HURRICANE WARNING IS IN EFFECT FROM SOUTH OF FLORIDA CITY AROUND  THE FLORIDA PENINSULA TO ANCLOTE KEY...INCLUDING ALL OF THE FLORIDA  KEYS AND THE DRY TORTUGAS.  THIS INCLUDES EXTREME SOUTH  MIAMI-DADE...MAINLAND MONROE AND COLLIER COUNTIES.  TROPICAL STORM WARNING AND HURRICANE WATCH IN EFFECT FROM FLORIDA  CITY TO SOUTH OF FLAGLER BEACH..INCLUDING LAKE OKEECHOBEE.  THIS INCLUDES  MOST OF MIAMI-DADE AND ALL OF BROWARD AND PALM BEACH COUNTIES.   AN INLAND HIGH WIND WARNING IS IN EFFECT FOR GLADES AND HENDRY  COUNTIES THROUGH TONIGHT.  A TORNADO WATCH IS IN EFFECT FOR ALL OF SOUTH FLORIDA UNTIL 3 PM  THIS AFTERNOON.  ...CENTER LOCATION MOVEMENT INTENSITY AND TREND... AT 11 AM EDT THE CENTER OF HURRICANE IRENE WAS LOCATED NEAR 24.7N  81.6W NEAR KEY WEST...100 MILES SOUTH OF NAPLES...OR ABOUT 115 MILES  SOUTHWEST OF MIAMI. IRENE IS MOVING TO THE NORTH NORTHEAST AT 8 MPH  AND THIS MOTION IS EXPECTED TO CONTINUE FOR THE NEXT 24 HOURS. THE CENTER OF IRENE WILL MOVE NEAR MARCO ISLAND AND NAPLES THIS EVENING.  MAXIMUM WINDS ARE ESTIMATED TO BE NEAR 75 MPH WITH HIGHER GUSTS  WHICH MAKES IRENE A MINIMAL CATEGORY ONE HURRICANE ON THE  SAFFIR-SIMPSON SCALE. SOME SLIGHT STRENGTHENING IS STILL POSSIBLE  BEFORE LANDFALL.   ...RAINFALL AND FLOODING STORM RAINFALL TOTALS OF 4 TO 8 INCHES HAVE FALLEN ACROSS THE  METRO AREAS OF MIAMI-DADE...BROWARD AND PALM BEACH COUNTIES WITH 2  TO 4 INCHES IN OTHER AREAS OF SOUTH FLORIDA INCLUDING THE NAPLES  AREA. ADDITIONAL RAINFALL AMOUNTS OF AT LEAST 6 TO 10 INCHES ARE  POSSIBLE BEFORE THE RAIN ENDS LATE SATURDAY. WITH SATURATED GROUND  FLOODING OF POORLY DRAINED AREAS WILL OCCUR. THE HEAVY RAINS WILL  PUT PRESSURE ON FLAT TOPPED ROOFS WHICH MAY LEAK OR COLLAPSE FROM  THE WEIGHT OF THE WATER.  MOTORISTS ARE URGED TO USE EXTREME CAUTION. STANDING WATER ON  ROADWAYS CAN CAUSE MOTORISTS TO DRIVE INTO CANALS OR OTHER DEEP  WATER. PARENTS ARE URGED TO SUPERVISE CHILDREN TO PREVENT THEM FROM  PLAYING IN FLOODED AREAS WHERE HAZARDS INCLUDE SHARP UNDERWATER  OBJECTS...STORM DRAINS AND CONTAMINATED WATER.   ...WIND INFORMATION AT NOON A WIND GUST OF 61 MPH WAS REPORTED AT HOMESTEAD AIR RESERVE  BASE AND MANY OTHER LOCATIONS IN MIAMI-DADE AND SOUTHERN BROWARD  COUNTY ARE REPORTING WIND GUSTS NEAR OR ABOVE 40 MPH. THESE WIND  GUSTS WILL SPREAD NORTH THIS AFTERNOON INTO NORTHERN BROWARD AND  PALM BEACH COUNTY AS WELL AS IN COLLIER...HENDRY AND GLADES  COUNTIES. WIND WILL APPROACH HURRICANE STRENGTH OVER MAINLAND  MONROE...AND COLLIER COUNTIES BY MID TO LATE AFTERNOON AND CONTINUE  THROUGH THIS EVENING.  ...STORM SURGE/TIDE/OTHER MARINE HAZARDS THE STORM SURGE...WHICH IS HIGHLY DEPENDENT ON THE EXACT  TRACK...WILL BE AT A MAXIMUM ALONG THE SOUTHWEST FLORIDA COAST  BEGINNING THIS EVENING OR EARLY TONIGHT AFTER IRENE MOVES NORTH  OF THE AREA. MAXIMUM STORM SURGE VALUES OF 5 TO 7 FEET ARE EXPECTED  IN THIS AREA AND WILL FLOOD THE AREA AROUND CHOKOLOSKEE...EVERGLADES  CITY INCLUDING HIGHWAY 29. STORM SURGE FLOODING CAN ALSO BE EXPECTED  NEAR MARCO ISLAND.   HIGH TIDES AT THE NAPLES PIER WILL BE AT... 505 PM FRIDAY 342 AM SATURDAY  ROUGH SURF CONDITIONS CAN BE EXPECTED ALONG BOTH SOUTHEAST AND  SOUTHWEST COAST AND SMALL BOATERS ARE URGED TO REMAIN IN PORT. RIP  CURRENTS ARE POSSIBLE ALONG THE BEACHES OF SOUTHEAST FLORIDA.  ...TORNADOES THE RAINBANDS OF IRENE ARE CAPABLE OF PRODUCING TORNADOES AND  WATERSPOUTS. PERSONS AND BOATERS SHOULD BE ALERT IN CASE TORNADO  WATCHES OR WARNINGS ARE ISSUED OR A TORNADO OR WATERSPOUT IS  SIGHTED.   ...EVACUATION/SHELTERING SEVERAL SHELTERS IN COLLIER AND MIAMI-DADE COUNTY ARE OPEN OR WILL  OPEN THIS AFTERNOON. A SHELTER WAS ALSO OPEN IN GLADES COUNTY.  PERSONS IN MOBILE HOMES AND PERSONS IN AREAS SUBJECT TO FRESHWATER  FLOODING SHOULD CONSIDER RELOCATING.  ...PROTECTIVE ACTIONS... PERSONS ARE URGED TO REMAIN INDOORS THIS AFTERNOON AND TONIGHT.  TREES AND POWER LINES WILL BE BLOWN DOWN AND FLOODING OF STREETS AND  POORLY DRAINED AREAS WILL MAKE DRIVING HAZARDOUS. LUSHINE                        WWUS31 KTBW 151602 HLSTBW FLZ039-042-043-048>052-055>057-060>062-065-151930-  HURRICANE IRENE LOCAL STATEMENT NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE TAMPA BAY AREA - RUSKIN FL 1200 PM EDT FRI OCT 15 1999  ...WATCH/WARNING INFORMATION...  ...HURRICANE WARNING CONTINUED FOR THE FOLLOWING LOCATIONS: ...LEE...CHARLOTTE...DESOTO...SARASOTA...MANATEE...HILLSBOROUGH    ...AND PINELLAS COUNTY.  ...HURRICANE WATCH CONTINUED FOR THE FOLLOWING LOCATIONS: ...CITRUS...HERNANDO...AND PASCO COUNTIES.  ...TORNADO WATCH UNTIL 3 PM FOR THE FOLLOWING LOCATIONS: ...HIGHLANDS COUNTY.  ...INLAND HIGH WIND WARNING IN EFFECT FOR THE FOLLOWING LOCATIONS: ...HIGHLAND...HARDEE...AND POLK COUNTIES.  ...FLOOD WATCH CONTINUED FOR THE FOLLOWING LOCATIONS: ...LEE...CHARLOTTE...DESOTO...HARDEE...HIGHLANDS...SARASOTA... ...MANATEE...HILLSBOROUGH...AND POLK COUNTIES.  ...STORM LOCATION... AT NOON EDT...THE CENTER OF HURRICANE IRENE WAS LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 125 STATUTE MILES SOUTH SOUTHEAST OF FORT MYERS OR 225 STATUTE MILES SOUTH SOUTHEAST OF TAMPA. IRENE IS MOVING NORTH NORTHEAST AT 8 MPH.  IRENE REMAINS NEAR MINIMAL HURRICANE STRENGTH WITH MAXIMUM SUSTAINED WINDS NEAR 75 MPH AROUND NEAR THE CENTER.  SLIGHT STRENGTHENING IS POSSIBLE DURING THE NEXT 12 HOURS UNTIL LANDFALL. HOWEVER TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS OF 39 TO 73 MPH EXTEND OUTWARD UP TO 140 MILES FROM THE CENTER AND ARE EXPECTED TO BEGIN EFFECTING CHARLOTTE AND LEE COUNTIES BY SOMETIME THIS AFTERNOON.  ...RADAR AND RAINFALL INFORMATION... DOPPLER RADAR COMPOSITES SHOWED THE HEAVIEST RAINBANDS REMAINED SOUTH AND EAST OF LEE COUNTY AT 1130 AM.  THESE BANDS WERE MOVING VERY SLOWLY NORTHEASTWARD. OTHER SCATTERED SHOWERS WERE CONTINUED TO DEVELOP WESTWARD FROM THE EAST COAST OF FLORIDA INTO POLK...SUMTER... PASCO...AND HERNANDO COUNTIES.  THESE SHOWERS AND ISOLATED THUNDERSTORMS ARE EXPECTED TO INCREASE IN COVERAGE AND INTENSITY FROM SOUTHEAST TO NORTHWEST THROUGH THE DAY. THIS IS ESPECIALLY TRUE IN HIGHLANDS COUNTY...WHERE A TORNADO WATCH IS IN EFFECT UNTIL 3 PM.  IRENE HAS HAD VERY HEAVY RAINFALL ASSOCIATED WITH IT SO FAR...AND THIS IS EXPECTED TO CONTINUE AS THE STORM MOVES NORTHWARD INTO FLORIDA. STORM TOTAL RAINFALL OF UP TO 10 INCHES IS POSSIBLE ALONG AND EAST OF THE CENTER TRACK OF IRENE IN HIGHLANDS AND EASTERN POLK COUNTIES. ELSEWHERE...2 TO 4 INCHES IS POSSIBLE BEFORE THE STORM MOVES BY SATURDAY NIGHT. OF COURSE...IF THE TRACK SHIFTS WESTWARD HEAVIER RAIN WILL FALL ACROSS WEST CENTRAL AND SOUTHWEST FLORIDA... AND IF IT MOVES FARTHER EAST RAINFALL AMOUNTS WILL DECREASE.  ...WIND INFORMATION... WINDS ARE CONTINUING TO INCREASE OVER LEE AND CHARLOTTE COUNTIES. AT 11 AM...WINDS WERE GUSTING BEYOND 30 MPH OVER PORTIONS OF THE AREA... WITH WINDS LIKELY GUSTING TO MINIMAL TROPICAL STORM FORCE ALONG THE COAST AND NEAR BAYS...HARBORS...INLAND WATERS...AND LOCAL HIGH SPOTS. SUSTAINED WINDS OF TROPICAL STORM FORCE ARE NOT EXPECTED UNTIL EARLY AFTERNOON IN LEE COUNTY...AND LATER AFTERNOON IN CHARLOTTE COUNTY.  SUSTAINED WINDS WILL SLOWLY INCREASE ELSEWHERE THROUGH THE AFTERNOON...BUT SHOULD REMAIN BELOW TROPICAL STORM STRENGTH UNTIL THIS EVENING. TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS WILL GRADUALLY MOVE FROM THE SOUTH TO NORTH TONIGHT...EFFECTING DESOTO...HIGHLANDS... SARASOTA...AND HARDEE COUNTIES BY MID TO LATE THIS AFTERNOON AND MANATEE...POLK...HILLSBOROUGH...AND SUMTER COUNTIES BY LATE TONIGHT AND EARLY SATURDAY MORNING.  ...STORM SURGE INFORMATION... HURRICANE TIDAL WATER AND STORM SURGE INCREASES WILL BE HIGHLY DEPENDENT UPON THE EVENTUAL STRENGTH AND TRACK OF IRENE AS THE HURRICANE MOVES NORTH NORTHEASTWARD. THE FOLLOWING STORM SURGE ESTIMATES ARE BASED ON THE LATEST TRACK AND INTENSITY FORECAST AND THE INHERENT UNCERTAINTY IN THESE TRACK FORECASTS:  ...LOCATION...    ...SURGE ESTIMATE...  ...TIME OF POTENTIAL SURGE...  LEE COAST            3 TO 5 FEET           TONIGHT THRU AM SAT  CHARLOTTE COAST AND  2 TO 4 FEET           TONIGHT THRU AM SAT CHARLOTTE HARBOR INCLUDING TIDAL DESOTO COUNTY  SARASOTA COAST       1 TO 2 FEET           TONIGHT THRU AM SAT  TO CALCULATE STORM TIDE...ADD THE STORM SURGE FORECAST TO THE ASTRONOMICAL TIDE.  STORM SURGE + ASTRONOMICAL TIDE = STORM TIDE.  ALL PERSONS ALONG THE SOUTHWEST FLORIDA GULF COAST SHOULD CLOSELY MONITOR TIDAL WATER FORECASTS. REMEMBER...THE GREATEST THREAT FOR STORM SURGE WILL OCCUR ALONG OR TO THE RIGHT OF LANDFALL. AT 11 AM EDT THE CENTER OF HURRICANE IRENE WAS LOCATED NEAR LATITUDE 24.7 NORTH...LONGITUDE  81.6 WEST OR ABOUT 250 MILES SOUTH OF ORLANDO. IRENE IS MOVING TOWARD THE NORTH NORTHEAST NEAR 8 MPH. LOOSE OBJECTS THAT CAN BE BLOWN ABOUT BY THE WIND SHOULD BE SECURED OR BROUGHT INSIDE.  ...STORM SURGE AND STORM TIDE INFORMATION... WITH THE CENTER OF IRENE EXPECTED TO REMAIN OVER LAND AND WEAKEN...SIGNIFICANT STORM SURGE IS NOT EXPECTED ALONG THE COAST FROM SOUTH OF FLAGLER BEACH TO JUPITER INLET. HOWEVER... AT 1130...SCATTERED SHOWERS WITH LOCALLY HEAVY RAIN CONTINUED OVER MUCH OF EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA. THIS RAINFALL IS NOT DIRECTLY ASSOCIATED WITH THE MAIN CIRCULATION OF IRENE. RAINFALL AMOUNTS OF 1 TO 2 INCHES CAN BE EXPECTED THIS AFTERNOON WHICH WILL CAUSE SOME PONDING OF WATER ON ROADWAYS. A TORNADO WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT FOR OKEECHOBEE...MARTIN AND ST LUCIE COUNTIES UNTIL 3PM...BUT THERE HAS BEEN NO INDICATION OF SEVERE WEATHER DURING THE MORNING. ANY TORNADOES THAT DO FORM WILL TYPICALLY BE ASSOCIATED WITH INTENSE CONVECTION IN IRENE'S OUTER RAINBANDS. THE SEVERE WEATHER THREAT IS EXPECTED TO INCREASE LATE TONIGHT AND CONTINUE THROUGH SATURDAY. SPOTTER ACTIVATION WILL PROBABLY BE REQUESTED EARLY SATURDAY MORNING.  ...WIND AND RAINFALL INFORMATION... IRENE HAS BECOME BETTER ORGANIZED AND IF THE DEEP CONVECTION HOLDS TOGETHER AS IT MOVES INTO EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA SATURDAY...EXTREME RAINFALL OF PERHAPS 8 TO 12 INCHES IS POSSIBLE. FLOODING IS PROBABLY THE GREATEST THREAT FROM IRENE. THE SITUATION IS STILL UNFOLDING RAINFALL COULD BE LESS OR IT COULD BE SIGNIFICANTLY HIGHER. FLOOD WARNINGS ARE LIKELY TO BE ISSUED LATER TONIGHT OR EARLY SATURDAY. SOME AREAS OF EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA HAVE EXPERIENCED 24 INCHES OF RAIN IN THE PAST 30 DAYS. ANY ADDITIONAL RAIN WILL QUICKLY CAUSE SERIOUS FLOODING PROBLEMS. THE ORLANDO METRO AREA AND SANFORD COULD SEE TROPICAL STORM FORCE GUSTS BY DAYBREAK SATURDAY...AND VOLUSIA COUNTY AND DAYTONA BEACH SATURDAY AFTERNOON. PEAK WIND GUSTS DURING IRENE ARE EXPECTED TO BE IN THE 50 TO 60 MPH RANGE WHICH WILL NOT CAUSE WIDESPREAD DAMAGE...BUT WILL BLOW TREE LIMBS ON POWER LINES CAUSING SCATTERED OUTAGES...POSSIBLY BRING DOWN OLDER DISEASED TREES. THE STRONGEST WINDS WILL LIKELY OCCUR IN RAIN SQUALLS WITHIN RAINBANDS.  ...NEXT UPDATE... THE NEXT HURRICANE LOCAL STATEMENT WILL BE ISSUED AT 6 PM OR SOONER IF CONDITIONS WARRANT. A HURRICANE WARNING IS IN EFFECT FOR ALL OF THE FLORIDA KEYS AND FOR  THE DRY TORTUGAS. A HURRICANE WARNING MEANS THAT HURRICANE  CONDITIONS ARE EXPECTED OR OCCURRING.    A FLOOD WARNING IS ALSO IN EFFECT FOR THE KEYS THROUGH 125 PM. A  FLOOD WARNING MEANS THE FLOODING IS OCCURRING OR IMMEDIATE WITHIN  THE WARNED AREA.  ...STORM INFORMATION... AT 1100 AM EDT THE CENTER OF HURRICANE IRENE WAS NEAR LATITUDE 24.7  NORTH...LONGITUDE 81.6 WEST...OR VERY NEAR KEY WEST. THE EYE WAS  POORLY-DEFINED AND MOVEMENT WAS ERRATIC WITH A NET MOTION TO THE  NORTH NORTHEAST NEAR 8 MPH.        AT 1100 AM EDT THE CENTRAL PRESSURE OF IRENE WAS 987 MB OR 29.14  INCHES. MAXIMUM SUSTAINED WINDS WERE 65 KTS/75 MPH WITH GUSTS TO 85 KTS/98 MPH. THIS MADE IRENE A CATEGORY ONE ON THE SAFFIR-SIMPSON  SCALE. SOME SLIGHT STRENGTHENING IS POSSIBLE DURING THE NEXT 12 TO  24 HOURS.  ...PRECAUTIONARY ACTIONS... RESIDENTS WERE STONGLY URGED TO REMAIN AT HOME BY THE MONROE COUNTY  SHERIFF.   THE CITY OF KEY WEST HAD IMPOSED A CURFEW ON NON-EMERGENCY  VEHICULAR AND PEDESTRIAN TRAFFIC THROUGH 800 AM SATURDAY DUE TO  DOWNED WIRES AND DEBRIS ON ROADWAYS.   US1 WAS BLOCKED AT MM 75 DUE TO HIGH WATER AND DEBRIS.  PLEASE LEAVE THE ROADWAYS FREE FOR EMERGENCY VEHICLES.   BOATERS SHOULD REMAIN IN PORT.   THE MONROE COUNTY RUMOR CONTROL PHONE NUMBER IS 1-800-955-5504. HERE YOU MAY OBTAIN THE LATEST AVAILABLE INFORMATION ON COUNTY-WIDE  ACTIVITIES. THOUGH TODAY MARKS THE START OF STONE CRAB SEASON...BOATERS SHOULD  STAY IN PORT UNTIL IRENE PASSES AND CONDITIONS SUBSIDE. AT 800 AM EDT...THE CENTER OF HURRICANE IRENE WAS LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 160 MILES SOUTH OF FORT MYERS OR 255 MILES SOUTH SOUTHEAST OF TAMPA. IRENE IS MOVING JUST EAST OF DUE NORTH AT ABOUT 8 MPH.  IRENE REMAINS NEAR MINIMAL HURRICANE STRENGTH WITH MAXIMUM SUSTAINED WINDS NEAR 75 MPH AROUND NEAR THE CENTER.  SLIGHT STRENGTHENING IS POSSIBLE DURING THE NEXT 12 TO 24 HOURS. HOWEVER TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS OF 39 TO 73 MPH EXTEND OUTWARD UP TO 140 MILES FROM THE CENTER AND ARE EXPECTED TO BEGIN EFFECTING CHARLOTTE AND LEE COUNTIES BY SOMETIME THIS AFTERNOON.  ...RADAR AND RAINFALL INFORMATION... DOPPLER RADAR COMPOSITES SHOWED THE HEAVIEST RAINBANDS REMAINED SOUTH OF LEE COUNTY AT 830 AM.  THESE BANDS WERE MOVING VERY SLOWLY NORTHWARD. OTHER SCATTERED SHOWERS WERE BEGINNING TO DEVELOP WESTWARD FROM THE EAST COAST OF FLORIDA INTO THE INTERIOR COUNTIES OF HIGHLANDS...HARDEE...AND POLK.  THESE SHOWERS AND ISOLATED THUNDERSTORMS ARE EXPECTED TO INCREASE IN COVERAGE AND INTENSITY FROM SOUTHEAST TO NORTHWEST THROUGH THE DAY. THIS IS ESPECIALLY TRUE IN HIGHLANDS COUNTY...WHERE A TORNADO WATCH IS IN EFFECT UNTIL 3 PM.  IRENE HAS HAD VERY HEAVY RAINFALL ASSOCIATED WITH IT SO FAR...AND THIS IS EXPECTED TO CONTINUE AS THE STORM MOVES NORTHWARD INTO WEST CENTRAL AND SOUTHWEST FLORIDA. STORM TOTAL RAINFALL OF 10 TO 15 INCHES OF RAIN IS POSSIBLE ALONG AND EAST OF THE CENTER TRACK OF IRENE.   ...WIND INFORMATION... WINDS ARE BEGINNING TO INCREASE OVER LEE COUNTY. AT 8 AM...WINDS WERE GUSTING TO 32 MPH AT SOUTHWEST INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT AND 35 MPH AT PAGE FIELD. WINDS WILL LIKELY BE GUSTING TO MINIMAL TROPICAL STORM FORCE BY LATE MORNING ALONG THE COAST AND NEAR BAYS... HARBORS...INLAND WATERS...AND LOCAL HIGH SPOTS. SUSTAINED WINDS OF TROPICAL STORM FORCE ARE NOT EXPECTED UNTIL EARLY AFTERNOON IN LEE COUNTY...AND LATER AFTERNOON IN CHARLOTTE COUNTY.  SUSTAINED WINDS WILL SLOWLY INCREASE ELSEWHERE THROUGH THE AFTERNOON...BUT SHOULD REMAIN BELOW TROPICAL STORM STRENGTH UNTIL THIS EVENING. TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS WILL GRADUALLY MOVE FROM THE SOUTH TO NORTH TONIGHT.  ...STORM SURGE INFORMATION... A FLOOD WATCH IS IN EFFECT FOR ALL OF SOUTH FLORIDA THROUGH SATURDAY   A HURRICANE WARNING IS IN EFFECT FROM SOUTH OF FLORIDA CITY AROUND  THE FLORIDA PENINSULA TO ANCLOTE KEY...INCLUDING ALL OF THE FLORIDA  KEYS AND THE DRY TORTUGAS.  THIS INCLUDES EXTREME SOUTH  MIAMI-DADE...MAINLAND MONROE AND COLLIER COUNTIES.  TROPICAL STORM WARNING AND HURRICANE WATCH IN EFFECT FROM FLORIDA  CITY TO SOUTH OF FLAGLER BEACH..INCLUDING LAKE OKEECHOBEE.  THIS INCLUDES  MOST OF MIAMI-DADE AND ALL OF BROWARD AND PALM BEACH COUNTIES.  .  AN INLAND HIGH WIND WARNING IS IN EFFECT FOR GLADES AND HENDRY  COUNTIES THROUGH TONIGHT.  A TORNADO WATCH IS IN EFFECT FOR ALL OF SOUTH FLORIDA UNTIL 3 PM  THIS AFTERNOON.  ...CENTER LOCATION MOVEMENT INTENSITY AND TREND... AT 8 AM EDT THE CENTER OF HURRICANE IRENE WAS LOCATED ABOUT 25 MILES  SOUTHWEST OF KEY WEST...130 MILES SOUTH OF NAPLES...OR ABOUT 145  MILES SOUTHWEST OF MIAMI. IRENE IS MOVING JUST EAST OF DUE NORTH AT  8 MPH. ON THIS TRACK THE CENTER OF IRENE WILL MOVE NEAR MARCO ISLAND  AND NAPLES THIS EVENING.  MAXIMUM WINDS ARE ESTIMATED TO BE NEAR 75 MPH WITH HIGHER GUSTS  WHICH MAKES IRENE A MINIMAL CATEGORY ONE HURRICANE ON THE  SAFFIR-SIMPSON SCALE. SOME SLIGHT STRENGTHENING IS STILL POSSIBLE IN  THE NEXT 12 TO 24 HOURS.   ...RAINFALL AND FLOODING STORM RAINFALL TOTALS OF 4 TO 8 INCHES HAVE FALLEN ACROSS THE  METRO AREAS OF MIAMI-DADE...BROWARD AND PALM BEACH COUNTIES WITH 2  TO 4 INCHES IN OTHER AREAS OF SOUTH FLORIDA INCLUDING THE NAPLES  AREA. ADDITIONAL RAINFALL AMOUNTS OF AT LEAST 6 TO 10 INCHES ARE  POSSIBLE BEFORE THE RAIN ENDS LATE SATURDAY. WITH SATURATED GROUND  FLOODING OF POORLY DRAINED AREAS WILL OCCUR. THE HEAVY RAINS WILL  PUT PRESSURE ON FLAT TOPPED ROOFS WHICH MAY LEAK OR COLLAPSE FROM  THE WEIGHT OF THE WATER.  MOTORISTS ARE URGED TO USE EXTREME CAUTION. STANDING WATER ON  ROADWAYS CAN CAUSE MOTORISTS TO DRIVE INTO CANALS OR OTHER DEEP  WATER. PARENTS ARE URGED TO SUPERVISE CHILDREN TO PREVENT THEM FROM  PLAYING IN FLOODED AREAS WHERE HAZARDS INCLUDE SHARP UNDERWATER  OBJECTS...STORM DRAINS AND CONTAMINATED WATER.   ...WIND INFORMATION AT 8 AM A WIND GUST OF 56 MPH WAS REPORTED AT HOMESTEAD RESERVE  BASE. WINDS GUSTS NEAR OR ABOVE 40 MPH OR HIGHER ARE OCCURRING IN  MIAMI-DADE COUNTY AND MAINLAND MONROE COUNTY AND WILL SPREAD  NORTHWARD...REACHING BROWARD AND COLLIER COUNTIES AROUND NOON AND  PALM BEACH...HENDRY...AND GLADES COUNTIES MID AFTERNOON. TROPICAL  STORM FORCE WINDS WILL BE MOVING INTO MAINLAND MONROE COUNTY AND  COASTAL COLLIER COUNTY JUST AFTER NOON AND WILL LIKELY SPREAD INTO  HENDRY AND WESTERN GLADES COUNTIES LATE THIS AFTERNOON AND THIS  EVENING. THE TIMES OF POSSIBLE HURRICANE FORCE WINDS FOR COASTAL  COLLIER COUNTY WOULD BE THIS EVENING.  ...STORM SURGE/TIDE/OTHER MARINE HAZARDS THE STORM SURGE IS HIGHLY DEPENDENT ON THE EXACT TRACK THAT IRENE  TAKES BUT ON THE CURRENT FORECAST TRACK STORM SURGE WOULD OCCUR  ALONG THE SOUTHWEST FLORIDA COAST MAINLY AFTER THE CENTER MOVES  NORTH OF THE AREA TONIGHT. MAXIMUM STORM SURGE ALONG THE COLLIER AND  MAINLAND MONROE COUNTY COASTS IS FORECAST FROM 5 TO 7 FEET. STORM  SURGE OF THIS MAGNITUDE COULD CAUSE CONSIDERABLE FLOODING IN THE  EVERGLADES CITY AND NEARBY COASTAL AREAS IN COLLIER AND MAINLAND  MONROE.  HIGH TIDES AT THE NAPLES PIER WILL BE AT... 505 PM FRIDAY 342 AM SATURDAY  ROUGH SURF CONDITIONS CAN BE EXPECTED ALONG BOTH SOUTHEAST AND  SOUTHWEST COAST AND SMALL BOATERS ARE URGED TO REMAIN IN PORT. RIP  CURRENTS ARE POSSIBLE ALONG THE BEACHES OF SOUTHEAST FLORIDA.  ...TORNADOES THE OUTER RAINBANDS OF IRENE ARE CAPABLE OF PRODUCING TORNADOES AND  WATERSPOUTS. THE CENTER OF HURRICANE FLOYD WAS LOCATED NEAR LATITUDE 25.1 NORTH... LONGITUDE  75.9 WEST OR ABOUT 370 MILES SOUTHEAST OF CAPE CANAVERAL. FLOYD IS NOW MOVING WEST NORTHWEST NEAR 14 MPH. TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS WILL SPREAD ACROSS VOLUSIA...SEMINOLE...ORANGE...AND LAKE COUNTIES BY THIS EVENING. HURRICANE FORCE WINDS WILL APPROACH MARTIN COUNTY ABOUT 9 PM THIS EVENING AND SWEEP ACROSS SAINT LUCIE... INDIAN RIVER AND BREVARD COUNTIES TONIGHT AND WEDNESDAY MORNING. HURRICANE FORCE WINDS WILL ENTER VOLUSIA AND FLAGLER COUNTIES BEFORE SUNRISE ON WEDNESDAY.  THE CENTER OF FLOYD IS EXPECTED TO PASS ABOUT 60 MILES OFFSHORE MARTIN COUNTY...AND ABOUT 40 MILES OFFSHORE CAPE CANAVERAL. IMPORTANTLY...FLOYD IS A STRONG CATEGORY 4 HURRICANE WITH HURRICANE WINDS EXTENDING OUTWARD 125 MILES.  ...STORM SURGE AND TIDE INFORMATION... A STORM SURGE OF 7 TO 12 FEET CAN BE EXPECTED AROUND MIDNIGHT TONIGHT. THIS WILL PRODUCE SIGNIFICANT BEACH EROSION.  ...RAINFALL INFORMATION... A FLOOD WATCH HAS BEEN ISSUED FOR ALL COUNTIES IN EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA.  EVEN THOUGH FLOYD IS MOVING QUICKLY... IT IS A LARGE HURRICANE. AS A RESULT...RAINFALL FROM FLOYD COULD BE AS MUCH AS 5 TO 10 INCHES.  INLAND COUNTIES CAN EXPECT 4 TO 5 INCHES OF RAIN.  ...MARINE INFORMATION... WEATHER CONDITIONS WILL CONTINUE TO DETERIORATE RAPIDLY OVER THE COASTAL WATERS TODAY AND SMALL CRAFT SHOULD REMAIN IN PORT. THIS STATEMENT APPLIES TO PEOPLE IN ALL PARTS OF THE KEYS OF MONROE  COUNTY FLORIDA CONCERNING THE EFFECTS OF HURRICANE FLOYD.  ...WATCHES...WARNINGS AND ADVISORIES... A TROPICAL STORM WARNING IS IN EFFECT FOR THE UPPER AND MIDDLE  FLORIDA KEYS AND THE ADJACENT COASTAL WATERS...FROM THE SEVEN-MILE  BRIDGE NORTHWARD TO ANGELFISH KEY. THIS INCLUDES FLORIDA BAY. A WIND ADVISORY IS IN EFFECT FOR THE LOWER KEYS. A SMALL CRAFT  ADVISORY IS IN EFFECT FROM PIGEON KEY TO DRY TORTUGAS AND THE  ADJACENT FLORIDA STRAITS OUT TO 50 NAUTICAL MILES...AND FOR THE  WATERS FROM KEY WEST TO CAPE SABLE.   ...HURRICANE INFORMATION... AT 5 AM EDT HURRICANE FLOYD WAS CENTERED ABOUT 375 MILES EAST OF KEY  WEST OR ABOUT 275 MILES EAST OF KEY LARGO. FLOYD WAS MOVING  WEST-NORTHWEST NEAR 14 MPH. A GRADUAL TURN EVEN MORE TO THE  NORTHWEST IS EXPECTED LATER TODAY. MAXIMUM SUSTAINED WINDS ARE NEAR  155 MPH WITH HIGHER GUSTS...MAKING IT A POWERFUL CATEGORY 4  STORM...JUST ONE MPH BELOW A CATEGORY 5 HURRICANE. ONLY TWO CATEGORY  5 HURRICANES HAVE EVER HIT THE U.S. THIS CENTURY...INCLUDING THE  LABOR DAY HURRICANE OF 1935 THAT DEVASTATED PARTS OF THE FLORIDA  KEYS.   ...PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS... BASED ON CURRENT FORECAST TRENDS...THERE ARE NO EVACUATION ORDERS  FOR MONROE COUNTY. HOWEVER...MONROE COUNTY EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT  ADVISES EVERYONE IN THE KEYS TO STAY TUNED TO FUTURE REPORTS.  SEVERAL PRECAUTIONARY MEASURES ARE ALREADY IN EFFECT ACCORDING TO   MONROE COUNTY EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT OFFICIALS...  MONROE COUNTY SHELTERS THAT ARE OPEN ARE KEY LARGO ELEMENTARY SCHOOL AND STANLEY SWITLIK ELEMENTARY SCHOOL IN MARATHON.  ALL MONROE COUNTY SCHOOLS ARE CLOSED TO STUDENTS TODAY.  ALL COUNTY AND STATE PARKS ARE CLOSED.  ALL COUNTY OFFICES FROM THE SEVEN MILE BRIDGE TO THE NORTH END OF  KEY LARGO ARE CLOSED TODAY. THERE IS A POSSIBILITY SOME OTHER COUNTY  OFFICES MAY BE CLOSED WEST OF THE SEVEN MILE BRIDGE TODAY.  ALSO...ALL BRIDGES IN THE FLORIDA KEYS...INCLUDING THE SEVEN MILE  BRIDGE IS STILL OPEN AS OF 6 AM.  MONROE COUNTY RUMOR CONTROL TELEPHONE NUMBER IS 1-800-955-5504.   ALL PERSONS IN THE UPPER AND MIDDLE KEYS ARE URGED TO STAY OFF  ROADS...ESPECIALLY ON THE 18 MILE STRETCH AND CARD SOUND ROAD. THERE  HAVE BEEN REPORTS FROM EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT THAT WATER WAS VERY  CLOSE TO PARTS OF THE 18 MILE STRETCH OF U.S. 1 DURING THE LAST HIGH  TIDE MONDAY EVENING...AND SEA SPRAY WAS CAUSING LOW VISIBILITY AT TIMES. IF  YOU MUST BE ON THE ROAD TODAY...PLEASE DRIVE WITH EXTREME CARE.  PERSONS ATTEMPTING TO DRIVE NORTH FROM THE KEYS TO THE MAINLAND  SHOULD BE AWARE THAT EVACUATION TRAFFIC ALONG THE ENTIRE FLORIDA  EAST COAST IS LIKELY EXTREMELY HEAVY. IF TRAVEL TO THE MAINLAND IS  ABSOLUTELY REQUIRED TODAY...IT WOULD BE BEST TO AVOID THE  TURNPIKE...INTERSTATE 95..AND U.S. 1 FROM MIAMI-DADE COUNTY  NORTHWARD.   AIRLINE COMMUTERS SHOULD BE AWARE THAT MOST AIRLINES FLYING IN AND  OUT OF MIAMI INTERNATIONAL AND FORT LAUDERDALE INTERNATIONAL HAVE  ALREADY CANCELED FLIGHTS. BOTH OF THOSE AIRPORTS ARE EXPECTED TO  SUSPEND FLIGHT OPERATIONS DURING TODAY.  ...STORM SURGE FLOODING/TIDES/OTHER MARINE HAZARDS... SOME MINOR TIDAL OVERFLOW WILL OCCUR ALONG THE UPPER AND MIDDLE  KEYS...NEAR THE TIMES OF HIGH TIDE TODAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY.  ALREADY...SOME SPOTS OF U.S. 1 NORTH OF KEY LARGO HAD WATER VERY  CLOSE TO THE ROAD AND AS THE HURRICANE MOVES CLOSER TO LAND  ADDITIONAL FLOODING PROBLEMS ARE EXPECTED. THERE COULD BE AN  ADDITIONAL PROBLEM OF WATER PILING UP IN FLORIDA BAY LATE TONIGHT  AND WEDNESDAY AS WINDS SHIFT TO MORE WESTERLY.  TIMES OF THE HIGH TIDES ARE THESE... OCEAN REEF HARBOR...NORTH END OF KEY LARGO  1217 PM TUE  1225 AM WED  101 PM WED   KEY LARGO...LARGO SOUTH SOUND   1250 PM TUE  1258 AM WED  134 PM WED  MARATHON (VACA KEY)  1224 PM TUE  1214 AM WED  108 PM WED  THE WESTERN SIDE OF CARD SOUND ROAD   318 PM TUE   316 AM WED   402 PM WED  MARINERS SHOULD REMAIN IN PORT TODAY OF THE UPPER AND MIDDLE KEYS  WATERS...WITH A TROPICAL STORM WARNING IN EFFECT. SMALL CRAFT  ADVISORIES WILL REMAIN IN EFFECT FOR THE LOWER KEYS. WIND WAVES  TODAY INTO TONIGHT WILL REACH AS HIGH 8 TO 12 FEET OVER OPEN WATERS  THE KEYS. ALSO...LARGE SWELLS GENERATED ON THE WEST SIDE OF FLOYD  WILL PROPAGATE SOUTHWARD DOWN THE STRAITS OF FLORIDA AFFECTING  FLORIDA STRAITS WATERS OF THE UPPER AND MIDDLE KEYS TODAY AND  TONIGHT. MARINERS IN THE LOWER KEYS SHOULD MONITOR LATER WEATHER  ISSUANCES...AND BE ALERT TO POSSIBLY DETERIORATING WEATHER...WIND  AND SEAS.  ...WIND IMPACTS... FLOYD CONTINUES TO BE VERY LARGE IN SIZE. TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS  EXTEND OUT 150 MILES TO THE SOUTHWEST OF FLOYDS CENTER...AND 190  MILES TO THE NORTHWEST. ACCORDING TO EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT...SOME OF  THESE WINDS HAVE ALREADY BEEN IMPACTING THE OCEAN REEF AREA OF UPPER  KEY LARGO AND FOWEY ROCKS LIGHT OFF MIAMI HAS BEEN REPORTING WIND  GUSTS PAST 40 MPH MOST OF THE EARLY MORNING HOURS.   WIND ACROSS THE WATERS OF THE FLORIDA KEYS EARLY THIS MORNING HAVE  BEEN 25 TO 30 MPH SUSTAINED...WITH GUSTS AT TIMES NEAR 35 MPH. WIND  DIRECTION HAS BEEN MOSTLY FROM THE NORTH...EXCEPT NORTH TO NORTHEAST  AT DRY TORTUGAS.   WIND AT THE AIRPORTS FROM MARATHON TO KEY WEST HAVE BEEN NORTH AS  HIGH AS NEAR 20 MPH...WITH GUSTS AS HIGH AS 25 TO 30 MPH.   BASED ON THE CURRENT FORECAST TRACK...SUSTAINED WINDS OF TROPICAL  STORM FORCE WILL SPREAD SLOWLY DOWN THE KEYS TODAY. DURING THIS  MORNING MOST OF THE TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS OF 39 MPH OR GREATER  WILL OCCUR IN THE UPPER KEYS AND SURROUNDING WATERS...POSSIBLY  REACHING THE MIDDLE KEYS AND THE ADJACENT WATERS THIS AFTERNOON AS  FLOYD MAKES IT CLOSEST PASS TO THE KEYS. WIND GUSTS MAY EVEN EXCEED  50 MPH THIS AFTERNOON AND EVENING FROM KEY LARGO TO OCEAN REEF IF  FLOYD TRACKS CLOSER TO THE AREA.  WINDS ACROSS THE LOWER KEYS AND THE ADJACENT WATERS WILL ONLY BE  SLIGHTLY LOWER DURING TODAY AND TONIGHT...BUT OCCASIONAL WIND GUSTS  PAST 40 MPH ARE POSSIBLE. SUSTAINED WINDS OF 25 MPH OR GREATER WILL  OCCUR OVER THE LOWER KEYS TODAY PROMPTING A WIND ADVISORY. DRIVE  WITH EXTREME CARE TODAY...ESPECIALLY ON THE BRIDGES AS THE WIND WILL  BE PERPENDICULAR TO U.S. 1  WIND DIRECTION ACROSS THE KEYS AND ADJACENT MARINE AREA WILL BE  MAINLY NORTH THIS MORNING...SHIFTING TO NORTHWEST THIS AFTERNOON AND  THEN TO WEST OR WEST-NORTHWEST TONIGHT.  ALSO...WIND COULD BE EVEN STRONGER IF ANY OUTER RAINBANDS FROM FLOYD  MAKE IT INTO THE KEYS.  ...RAINFALL INFORMATION... ALTHOUGH THERE CAN BE OCCASIONAL DOWNPOURS OF RAIN IN ANY RAINBAND  THAT DOES MOVE THROUGH THE KEYS...NO WIDESPREAD HEAVY RAINS WILL  OCCUR DUE TO THE FAST MOVEMENT AND THE LOCATION OF FLOYD IN RELATION  TO THE KEYS. MAXIMUM SUSTAINED WINDS ARE NEAR 155 MPH AND THE MINIMUM CENTRAL PRESSURE IS 927 MB. FLOYD IS MOVING TOWARD THE WEST NORTHWEST AT 14 MPH AND A GRADUAL TURN TO THE NORTHWEST IS EXPECTED LATER TODAY. ALTHOUGH THE CENTER IS FORECAST TO REMAIN OFFSHORE NORTHEAST FLORIDA AND SOUTHEAST GEORGIA...THE WIND FIELD IS LARGE ENOUGH TO HAVE A SIGNIFICANT IMPACT ON THE AREA. ON ITS CURRENT FORECAST TRACK...TROPICAL STORM WINDS WILL START TO REACH THE NORTHEAST FLORIDA COAST...NEAR FLAGLER BEACH...BEGINNING SOMETIME AFTER 10 PM EDT TONIGHT AND THEN SPREAD NORTHWARD REACHING THE NORTHEAST FLORIDA AND SOUTHEAST GEORGIA STATE LINE SOME TIME AROUND 6 AM WEDNESDAY MORNING AND THE BRUNSWICK AREA IN SOUTHEAST GEORGIA BY 9 AM ON WEDNESDAY. THE TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS WILL BE EXITING THE SOUTHEAST GEORGIA COAST EARLY ON THURSDAY MORNING. WINDS WILL ALSO APPROACH HURRICANE FORCE...GREATER THAN 74 MPH...IN SQUALLS ALONG THE IMMEDIATE COAST DURING THE DAY ON WEDNESDAY AND INTO THE EARLY EVENING. ALTHOUGH THE STRONGEST WINDS ARE EXPECTED TO AFFECT COASTAL COUNTIES...TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS...WINDS GREATER THAN 39 MPH...COULD ALSO REACH INLAND AREAS AS FAR WEST AS I-75 AND THEREFORE A HIGH WIND WATCH IS IN EFFECT FOR ALL OF THE INLAND COUNTIES IN NORTHEAST FLORIDA AND SOUTHEAST GEORGIA LISTED ABOVE.  ...TIDES/STORM SURGE INFORMATION... DUE TO THE STRONG NORTHEASTERLY WINDS WHICH THE AREA HAS BEEN EXPERIENCING OVER THE PAST FEW DAYS...THE TIDES HAVE BEEN RUNNING AROUND 2 TO 2 1/2 FEET ABOVE THE HEIGHT OF A NORMAL HIGH TIDE. THE TIDAL VALUES ALONG THE RIVERS...BAYS AND THE INTRACOASTAL WATERWAY WILL CONTINUE TO INCREASE EVEN BEFORE THE HURRICANE APPROACHES THE REGION AND THIS COULD CAUSE MINOR TIDAL FLOODING ALONG COASTAL ROADWAYS AT THE TIME OF HIGH TIDE. AUGUSTINE AREA AND MID TO LATE MORNING IN DUVAL AND NASSAU COUNTIES. THE SURGE WILL LAST THROUGH THE DAY ON WEDNESDAY. THIS STATEMENT APPLIES TO PEOPLE IN MIAMI-DADE...BROWARD...PALM  BEACH...GLADES AND HENDRY COUNTIES OF SOUTH FLORIDA CONCERNING  HURRICANE FLOYD.  ...WATCH/WARNING HURRICANE WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FOR MIAMI-DADE...BROWARD AND PALM  BEACH COUNTIES INCLUDING LAKE OKEECHOBEE.  A HIGH WIND WARNING IS IN EFFECT FOR HENDRY AND GLADES COUNTIES FOR  THIS AFTERNOON AND TONIGHT.  ...CENTER LOCATION/MOVEMENT/INTENSITY AND TREND... AT 5 AM EDT HURRICANE FLOYD WAS LOCATED ABOUT 275 MILES EAST  SOUTHEAST OF MIAMI AND 285 MILES EAST SOUTHEAST OF WEST PALM BEACH.  FLOYD IS MOVING WEST NORTHWEST NEAR 14 MPH AND A GRADUAL TURN TO THE  NORTHWEST IS STILL FORECAST LATER TODAY. THE HIGHEST WINDS REMAIN NEAR  155 MPH...MAKING IT A STRONG CATEGORY FOUR STORM. LITTLE CHANGE IN  STRENGTH IS FORECAST OVER THE NEXT 24 HOURS.  THE PROBABILITY OF THE CENTER OF THE HURRICANE PASSING WITHIN 75  MILES OF WEST PALM BEACH IS 40 PERCENT AND FOR MIAMI IT IS 22  PERCENT. MIAMI'S PROBABILITY HAS DECREASED SINCE THE 11 PM ADVISORY  MONDAY. ALTHOUGH THE FORECAST TRACK IS STILL EXPECTED TO KEEP THE  CENTER OFFSHORE...THE FORECAST UNCERTAINTY IS ENOUGH THAT RESIDENTS  IN THE WARNING AREA SHOULD RUSH PREPARATIONS TO COMPLETION AS SOON  AS POSSIBLE.   ...WIND INFORMATION FLOYD IS A LARGE STORM WITH TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS...40 MPH OR  GREATER EXTENDING OUTWARD 190 MILES TO THE WEST OF THE CENTER...  AND HURRICANE FORCE WINDS EXTENDING OUTWARD UP TO 90 MILES WEST OF  THE CENTER. ALONG THE SOUTHEAST FLORIDA COAST EARLY THIS MORNING  WINDS WILL BE 10 TO 20 MPH WITH OCCASIONAL GUSTS TO 30 MPH IN  COASTAL LOCATIONS BUT GRADUALLY INCREASING THROUGH THE DAY. THE  FIRST SQUALLS ASSOCIATED WITH FLOYD WILL BE MOVING INTO THE COASTAL  WATERS BY LATE MORNING WITH SUSTAINED WINDS OF 30 TO 40 MPH WITH  HIGHER GUSTS.   WINDS ACROSS SOUTH FLORIDA ASSOCIATED WITH FLOYD ARE DEPENDENT ON  THE EXACT TRACK TAKEN BY THE HURRICANE. TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS  WILL BE LIKELY OVER COASTAL SECTIONS OF PALM BEACH...BROWARD AND  MIAMI DADE COUNTIES AS EARLY AS 8 TO 10 AM TODAY. WINDS IN EXCESS OF  58 MPH ARE FORECAST ACROSS COASTAL PALM BEACH AND BROWARD BY MID  AFTERNOON AND ACROSS MIAMI DADE BY EVENING WITH OCCASIONAL GUSTS  NEAR HURRICANE FORCE OF 74 MPH POSSIBLE. IN PARTICULAR...SUSTAINED  HURRICANE FORCE WINDS ARE FORECAST OVER NORTHEAST PALM BEACH COUNTY  INCLUDING THE WEST PALM BEACH AND JUPITER AREAS BY 11 PM TONIGHT AS  THE CENTER OF FLOYD IS EXPECTED TO PASS TO THE EAST. LAKE OKEECHOBEE  WILL EXPERIENCE TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS BY EARLY AFTERNOON AND  WINDS IN EXCESS OF 58 MPH BY EVENING. EASTERN HENDRY AND GLADES  COUNTIES WILL EXPERIENCE TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS BY LATE  AFTERNOON.  WIND GUSTS NEAR 40 MPH WERE ALREADY OCCURRING AT FOWEY ROCKS LIGHT  AND LAKE WORTH PIER BEFORE 5 AM TUESDAY.  ...RAINFALL/FLOODING SCATTERED SHOWERS WILL CONTINUE TO MOVE THROUGH THE AREA THIS  MORNING WITH NO WIDESPREAD SIGNIFICANT AMOUNTS OF RAINFALL. SHOWERS  AND SQUALLS WILL INCREASE THIS AFTERNOON AND BECOME VERY HEAVY  TONIGHT AND WEDNESDAY. THE HEAVY RAINS TONIGHT AND WEDNESDAY COULD  PRODUCE AMOUNTS OF 3 TO 5 INCHES...MAINLY ALONG THE COASTAL SECTIONS  OF PALM BEACH COUNTY WHICH COULD CAUSE SOME LOCAL URBAN STREET  FLOODING. HOWEVER...DUE TO FLOYDS STEADY MOVEMENT AND THE FACT THAT  THE CENTER IS FORECAST TO REMAIN OFFSHORE...TORRENTIAL RAINS IN  EXCESS OF 5 INCHES FOR SOUTHEAST FLORIDA ARE NOT LIKELY.  ...STORM SURGE FLOODING/TIDE/OTHER MARINE HAZARDS ALONG ITS CURRENT TRACK TIDES ALONG THE SOUTHEAST COAST WILL  GRADUALLY INCREASE THROUGH TUESDAY WITH A MORE RAPID RISE TO AS  MUCH AS 2 TO 3 FEET ABOVE NORMAL TUESDAY NIGHT AND EARLY WEDNESDAY.  SOME MINOR TIDAL OVERFLOW MAY OCCUR NEAR TIMES OF HIGH TIDE ON  TUESDAY AND WEDNESDAY. ALTHOUGH IT NOW SEEMS A REMOTE POSSIBILITY THAT  FLOYD WOULD RETURN TO A MORE WESTERLY COURSE INSTEAD OF TURNING MORE  TO THE NORTHWEST...IF THE CENTER WAS TO MOVE ACROSS THE SOUTHEAST  FLORIDA COASTLINE...STORM SURGE HEIGHTS WILL BE MUCH HIGHER  ESPECIALLY ALONG AND JUST NORTH OF WHERE THE CENTER CROSSES THE  COAST.  SURF CONDITIONS WILL BECOME INCREASINGLY ROUGH AND BOATERS SHOULD  REMAIN IN PORT. OCEAN INLETS WILL BECOME VERY HAZARDOUS...  ESPECIALLY WITH THE OUTGOING TIDE. SWIMMING... BATHING... AND  SURFING SHOULD CEASE ALONG OCEAN BEACHES IN MIAMI-DADE... BROWARD...  AND PALM BEACH COUNTIES DUE TO THE DANGEROUS SURF...RIP CURRENTS AND  LONGSHORE CURRENTS  TIMES OF HIGH TIDE AT PALM BEACH INLET... 1206 PM TUESDAY...1214 AM WEDNESDAY...1251 PM WEDNESDAY.  TIMES OF HIGH TIDE AT THE MIAMI HARBOR ENTRANCE... 1204 PM TUESDAY...1212 AM WEDNESDAY...1249 PM WEDNESDAY.  ...PROTECTIVE ACTIONS PEOPLE WHO ARE STILL WORKING TO COMPLETE ANY OUTSIDE PREPARATION  SHOULD BE RUSHING THESE ACTIVITIES TO COMPLETION. THIS WOULD INCLUDE THE  PROTECTION OF BOATS...REMOVING OUTSIDE DEBRIS AND CHECKING OR  INSTALLING SHUTTERS. BECAUSE OF INCREASING WIND IT IS RECOMMENDED  THAT ALL OUTSIDE ACTIVITIES BE FINISHED BY MID MORNING. RESIDENTS  SHOULD ALREADY KNOW WHETHER THEIR LOCATION IS IN AN EVACUATION ZONE  AND HAVE A SAFE DESTINATION IN MIND. ANY PERSONS THAT NEED TO TRAVEL  SHOULD LEAVE THIS MORNING BEFORE THE INCREASING WINDS AND SQUALLS  MAKE TRAVEL DANGEROUS.  A MANDATORY EVACUATION OF MOBILE HOMES AND THE BARRIER ISLANDS  INCLUDING MIAMI BEACH.. KEY BISCAYNE.. AND VIRGINIA KEY HAS BEEN  ORDERED BY MIAMI-DADE EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT. A MANDATORY EVACUATION  OF MOBILE HOMES IS IN EFFECT IN BROWARD COUNTY. MANDATORY  EVACUATION OF MOBILE HOMES...BARRIER ISLANDS...AND AREAS KNOWN FOR  SEVERE FLOODING HAS BEEN ORDERED IN PALM BEACH COUNTY. ADDITIONAL  MANDATORY EVACUATIONS MAY BE DECLARED IN SOUTHEAST FLORIDA COUNTIES  EARLY TUESDAY MORNING AS THE ACTUAL PATH OF FLOYD BECOMES APPARENT.  PERSONS IN MOBILE HOMES... EVEN INLAND AWAY FROM THE BEACHES...  SHOULD ALSO THINK OF SAFER ACCOMMODATIONS. SCHOOLS WILL BE CLOSED  TUESDAY IN BROWARD.. MIAMI-DADE.. AND PALM BEACH COUNTIES. BOTH  MIAMI INTERNATIONAL AND FORT LAUDERDALE/HOLLYWOOD INTERNATIONAL  AIRPORTS ARE SCHEDULED TO SUSPEND FLIGHT OPERATIONS AS WINDS  INCREASE ALTHOUGH MOST AIRLINES HAVE ALREADY CANCELLED THEIR  FLIGHTS. SEVERAL PRECAUTIONARY MEASURES ARE UNDERWAY BY MONROE COUNTY  EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT OFFICIALS...  MONROE COUNTY SHELTERS THAT ARE OPEN ARE KEY LARGO ELEMENTARY SCHOOL AND STANLEY SWITLIK ELEMENTARY SCHOOL IN MARATHON.  ALL MONROE COUNTY SCHOOLS ARE CLOSED TO STUDENTS TODAY.  ALL COUNTY AND STATE PARKS ARE CLOSED AS OF 2 AM.  ALL COUNTY OFFICES FROM THE SEVEN MILE BRIDGE TO THE NORTH END OF  KEY LARGO ARE CLOSED TODAY. THERE IS A POSSIBILITY SOME OTHER COUNTY  OFFICES MAY BE CLOSED WEST OF THE SEVEN MILE BRIDGE TODAY.  ALSO...ALL BRIDGES IN THE FLORIDA KEYS...INCLUDING THE SEVEN MILE  BRIDGE IS STILL OPEN AS OF 2 AM.  MONROE COUNTY RUMOR CONTROL TELEPHONE NUMBER IS 1-800-955-5504.   ALL PERSONS IN THE UPPER AND MIDDLE KEYS ARE URGED TO STAY OFF  ROADS...ESPECIALLY IN THE UPPER KEYS AND THE 18 MILE STRETCH WHERE  THERE IS A POSSIBILITY OF FLOODING. PERSONS ATTEMPTING TO DRIVE  NORTH FROM THE KEYS TO THE MAINLAND SHOULD BE AWARE THAT EVACUATION  TRAFFIC ALONG THE ENTIRE FLORIDA EAST COAST IS EXTREMELY HEAVY. IF  TRAVEL TO THE MAINLAND IS ABSOLUTELY REQUIRED TODAY...IT WOULD BE  BEST TO AVOID THE TURNPIKE...INTERSTATE 95..AND U.S. 1 FROM  MIAMI-DADE COUNTY NORTHWARD.   ...STORM SURGE FLOODING/TIDES/OTHER MARINE HAZARDS... OCEAN REEF HARBOR, NORTH END OF KEY LARGO  1217 PM TUE  1225 AM WED  101 PM WED   KEY LARGO, LARGO SOUTH SOUND   1250 PM TUE  1258 AM WED  134 PM WED  MARATHON (VACA KEY)  1224 PM TUE  1214 AM WED  108 PM WED  DURING TUESDAY NIGHT AND WEDNESDAY...WIND DIRECTION IS EXPECTED TO  BECOME MORE FROM THE WEST. AS A RESULT...EVEN THOUGH THE CENTER OF  FLOYD IS EXPECTED TO BE MOVING AWAY BY THAT TIME...THIS WIND  DIRECTION WILL PUSH HIGHER WATER LEVELS INTO FLORIDA BAY...PRODUCING  SOME MINOR COASTAL FLOODING OF LOW AREAS AND ROADS NEAR FLORIDA BAY.  THIS WOULD HAVE AN IMPACT ON THE 18-MILE STRETCH OF U.S. 1 NORTH OF  KEY LARGO AND CARD SOUND ROAD. HIGH TIDE AT THE WESTERN SIDE OF CARD  SOUND ROAD WILL OCCUR AT 316 AM WEDNESDAY AND AGAIN AT 402 PM.  WEDNESDAY.  MARINERS SHOULD REMAIN IN PORT ALONG UPPER AND MIDDLE KEYS WATERS  TODAY WITH A TROPICAL STORM WARNING IN EFFECT. SMALL CRAFT  ADVISORIES WILL REMAIN IN EFFECT FOR THE LOWER KEYS. WIND WAVES  TODAY INTO TONIGHT WILL REACH 8 TO 12 FEET OVER OPEN WATERS.  ALSO...LARGE SWELLS GENERATED ON THE WEST SIDE OF FLOYD WILL  PROPAGATE SOUTHWARD DOWN THE STRAITS OF FLORIDA AFFECTING WATERS  EAST OF THE UPPER AND MIDDLE KEYS TODAY AND TONIGHT. MARINERS IN THE  LOWER KEYS SHOULD MONITOR LATER WEATHER ISSUANCES...AND BE ALERT TO  POSSIBLY DETERIORATING WEATHER...WIND AND SEAS.  ...WIND IMPACTS... FLOYD IS VERY LARGE IN SIZE. TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS EXTEND OUT  150 MILES TO THE SOUTHWEST OF FLOYDS CENTER...AND 190 MILES TO  THE NORTHWEST.   WIND ACROSS THE WATERS OF THE FLORIDA KEYS EARLY THIS MORNING HAVE  BEEN NEAR 25 MPH SUSTAINED...WITH GUSTS AT TIMES TO 30 TO 35 MPH. FOWEY ROCKS OFF MIAMI HAS REPORTED SUSTAINED WIND OF 30 TO 35 MPH  WITH GUSTS NEAR 40 MPH...OR TROPICAL STORM STRENGTH. WIND DIRECTION  HAS BEEN MOSTLY FROM THE NORTH ACROSS THE MIDDLE AND UPPER KEYS AND  MORE NORTH TO NORTHEAST IN THE LOWER KEYS AND AT DRY TORTUGAS.   WIND AT THE AIRPORTS FROM MARATHON TO KEY WEST HAVE BEEN NORTH TO  NORTHEAST AT 15 TO 20 MPH WITH HIGHER GUSTS.   BASED ON THE CURRENT FORECAST TRACK...SUSTAINED WINDS OF TROPICAL  STORM FORCE OF 40 MPH ARE EXPECTED TO REACH PORTIONS OF THE UPPER  AND MIDDLE KEYS AND SURROUNDING WATERS AFTER SUNRISE THIS MORNING.  TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS COULD CONTINUE INTO TONIGHT IN THESE  AREAS. WIND GUSTS MAY EVEN EXCEED 50 MPH THIS AFTERNOON AND EVENING  FROM KEY LARGO TO OCEAN REEF IF FLOYD TRACKS CLOSER TO THE AREA. WINDS ACROSS THE LOWER KEYS AND THE ADJACENT WATERS WILL ONLY BE  SLIGHTLY LOWER DURING TODAY AND TONIGHT...BUT OCCASIONAL WIND GUSTS  PAST 40 MPH ARE POSSIBLE...ESPECIALLY THIS AFTERNOON AND EVENING  WHEN FLOYD IS EXPECTED TO BE AT ITS CLOSEST POINT TO THE KEYS.   WIND DIRECTION WILL BE MAINLY NORTH THIS MORNING...SHIFTING TO  NORTHWEST THIS AFTERNOON AND THEN TO WEST OR WEST-NORTHWEST TONIGHT.  ALSO...WIND COULD BE EVEN STRONGER IF ANY OUTER RAINBANDS FROM FLOYD  MAKE IT INTO THE AREA.  ...RAINFALL INFORMATION... ALTHOUGH THERE CAN BE OCCASIONAL DOWNPOURS OF RAIN IN ANY RAINBAND  THAT DOES MOVE THROUGH THE KEYS...NO WIDESPREAD HEAVY RAINS WILL  OCCUR DUE TO THE FAST MOVEMENT AND THE LOCATION OF FLOYD IN RELATION  TO THE KEYS. IF FLOYD TURNS MORE SHARPLY TO THE NORTHWEST THERE IS  EVEN A POSSIBILITY THAT MUCH OF THE RAINBANDS STAY NORTH AND EAST OF  THE AREA. ALTHOUGH THERE CAN BE OCCASIONAL DOWNPOURS OF RAIN IN ANY RAINBAND  THAT DOES MOVE THROUGH THE KEYS...NO WIDESPREAD HEAVY RAINS WILL  OCCUR DUE TO THE FAST MOVEMENT AND THE LOCATION OF FLOYD IN RELATION  TO THE KEYS. IF FLOYD TURNS MORE SHARPLY TO THE NORTHWEST THERE IS  EVEN A POSSIBILITY THAT MUCH OF THE RAINBANDS STAY NORTH AND EAST OF  THE AREA.
