THIS STATEMENT APPLIES TO PEOPLE IN MIAMI-DADE...BROWARD...PALM  BEACH...GLADES AND HENDRY COUNTIES OF SOUTH FLORIDA CONCERNING  HURRICANE FLOYD.  ...WATCH/WARNING HURRICANE WARNING IS IN EFFECT FOR MIAMI-DADE...BROWARD AND PALM  BEACH COUNTIES INCLUDING LAKE OKEECHOBEE.  A HIGH WIND WARNING WILL BE ISSUED AT 5 AM FOR HENDRY AND  GLADES COUNTIES FOR THIS AFTERNOON AND TONIGHT.  ...CENTER LOCATION/MOVEMENT/INTENSITY AND TREND... AT 2 AM EDT HURRICANE FLOYD WAS LOCATED ABOUT 320 MILES EAST  SOUTHEAST OF WEST PALM BEACH....FORT LAUDERDALE AND MIAMI. FLOYD WAS  MOVING WEST NORTHWEST NEAR 14 MPH AND A GRADUAL TURN TO THE  NORTHWEST IS STILL EXPECTED LATER TODAY. THE HIGHEST WINDS REMAIN  NEAR 155 MPH...MAKING IT A STRONG CATEGORY FOUR STORM. LITTLE CHANGE  IN STRENGTH IS FORECAST OVER THE NEXT 24 HOURS.  THE PROBABILITY OF THE CENTER OF THE HURRICANE PASSING WITHIN 75  MILES OF WEST PALM BEACH IS 38 PERCENT AND FOR MIAMI IT IS 24  PERCENT. ALTHOUGH THE FORECAST TRACK IS STILL EXPECTED TO KEEP THE  CENTER OFFSHORE...THE FORECAST UNCERTAINTY IS ENOUGH THAT RESIDENTS  IN THE WARNING AREA SHOULD RUSH PREPARATIONS TO COMPLETION AS SOON  AS POSSIBLE.   ...WIND INFORMATION FLOYD IS A LARGE STORM WITH TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS...40 MPH OR  GREATER EXTENDING OUTWARD 200 MILES TO THE WEST OF THE CENTER...  AND HURRICANE FORCE WINDS EXTENDING OUTWARD UP TO 90 MILES WEST OF  THE CENTER. ALONG THE SOUTHEAST FLORIDA COAST WINDS WILL BE 10 TO 20  MPH WITH OCCASIONAL GUSTS TO 30 MPH IN COASTAL LOCATIONS BUT  GRADUALLY INCREASING THROUGH THE REST OF TONIGHT.  TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS WILL BE LIKELY OVER COASTAL PALM BEACH  AND BROWARD AS EARLY AS 8 AM TODAY... AND BEGIN OVER MIAMI DADE  COUNTY BEFORE NOON. WINDS IN EXCESS OF 58 MPH ARE FORECAST ACROSS  COASTAL PALM BEACH AND BROWARD BY EARLY AFTERNOON AND ACROSS MIAMI  DADE BY MID AFTERNOON WITH OCCASIONAL GUSTS NEAR HURRICANE FORCE OF  74 MPH. IN PARTICULAR...SUSTAINED HURRICANE FORCE WINDS ARE FORECAST  OVER PALM BEACH COUNTY INCLUDING THE EASTERN SHORE OF LAKE  OKEECHOBEE BY THIS EVENING.  ...RAINFALL/FLOODING SCATTERED SHOWERS WILL CONTINUE TO MOVE THROUGH THE AREA OVERNIGHT  WITH NO WIDESPREAD SIGNIFICANT AMOUNTS OF RAINFALL. SHOWERS AND  SQUALLS WILL INCREASE ON TUESDAY AFTERNOON AND BECOME VERY HEAVY  TUESDAY NIGHT AND WEDNESDAY. THE HEAVY RAINS TUESDAY NIGHT AND  WEDNESDAY COULD BRING AMOUNTS OF 3 TO 5 INCHES...MAINLY ALONG THE  COASTAL SECTIONS OF PALM BEACH COUNTY WHICH COULD CAUSE SOME LOCAL  URBAN STREET FLOODING.  ...STORM SURGE FLOODING/TIDE/OTHER MARINE HAZARDS ALONG ITS CURRENT TRACK TIDES ALONG THE SOUTHEAST COAST WILL  GRADUALLY INCREASE THROUGH TUESDAY WITH A MORE RAPID RISE TO AS  MUCH AS 2 TO 3 FEET ABOVE NORMAL TUESDAY NIGHT AND EARLY WEDNESDAY.  SOME MINOR TIDAL OVERFLOW MAY OCCUR NEAR TIMES OF HIGH TIDE ON  TUESDAY AND WEDNESDAY. SHOULD FLOYD REMAIN ON A MORE WESTERLY COURSE  INSTEAD OF TURNING MORE TO THE NORTHWEST... AND THE CENTER MOVE  ACROSS THE SOUTHEAST FLORIDA COAST... STORM SURGE HEIGHTS WILL BE  MUCH HIGHER ESPECIALLY ALONG AND JUST NORTH OF WHERE THE CENTER  CROSSES THE COAST.  SURF CONDITIONS WILL BECOME INCREASINGLY ROUGH AND BOATERS SHOULD  REMAIN IN PORT. OCEAN INLETS WILL BECOME VERY HAZARDOUS...  ESPECIALLY WITH THE OUTGOING TIDE. SWIMMING... BATHING... AND  SURFING SHOULD CEASE ALONG OCEAN BEACHES IN MIAMI-DADE... BROWARD...  AND PALM BEACH COUNTIES DUE TO THE DANGEROUS SURF...RIP CURRENTS AND  LONGSHORE CURRENTS  TIMES OF HIGH TIDE AT PALM BEACH INLET... 1206 PM TUESDAY...1214 AM WEDNESDAY...1251 PM WEDNESDAY.  TIMES OF HIGH TIDE AT THE MIAMI HARBOR ENTRANCE... 1204 PM TUESDAY...1212 AM WEDNESDAY...1249 PM WEDNESDAY.  ...PROTECTIVE ACTIONS PEOPLE WHO ARE STILL WORKING TO COMPLETE ANY OUTSIDE PREPARATION  SHOULD BE RUSHING THESE ACTIVITIES TO COMPLETION. THIS WOULD INCLUDE THE  PROTECTION OF BOATS...REMOVING OUTSIDE DEBRIS AND CHECKING OR  INSTALLING SHUTTERS. BECAUSE OF INCREASING WIND IT IS RECOMMENDED  THAT ALL OUTSIDE ACTIVITIES BE FINISHED BY MID MORNING TUESDAY.  PERSONS SHOULD ALREADY KNOW WHETHER THEIR LOCATION IS IN AN  EVACUATION ZONE AND HAVE A DESTINATION IN MIND. A MANDATORY  EVACUATION OF MOBILE HOMES AND THE BARRIER ISLANDS INCLUDING MIAMI  BEACH.. KEY BISCAYNE.. AND VIRGINIA KEY HAS BEEN ORDERED BY  MIAMI-DADE EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT. A MANDATORY EVACUATION OF MOBILE  HOMES IS IN EFFECT IN BROWARD COUNTY. MANDATORY EVACUATION OF MOBILE  HOMES...BARRIER ISLANDS...AND AREAS KNOWN FOR SEVERE FLOODING HAS  BEEN ORDERED IN PALM BEACH COUNTY. ADDITIONAL MANDATORY EVACUATIONS  MAY BE DECLARED IN SOUTHEAST FLORIDA COUNTIES EARLY TUESDAY MORNING  AS THE FINAL TRACK OF FLOYD BECOMES APPARENT. PERSONS IN MOBILE HOMES...  EVEN INLAND AWAY FROM THE BEACHES... SHOULD ALSO THINK OF SAFER  ACCOMMODATIONS. SCHOOLS WILL BE CLOSED TUESDAY IN BROWARD..  MIAMI-DADE.. AND PALM BEACH COUNTIES. BOTH MIAMI INTERNATIONAL AND  FORT LAUDERDALE/HOLLYWOOD INTERNATIONAL AIRPORTS ARE SCHEDULED TO  SUSPEND FLIGHT OPERATIONS AT 9 AM TUESDAY MORNING. MOST BRIDGES ARE  ALREADY IN LOCK DOWN STATUS. PFOST                                                     WWUS31 KMLB 140406 HLSMLB AMZ550-555-570-575-FLZ041-044>047-053-054-058-059-064-140930-  HURRICANE LOCAL STATEMENT NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MELBOURNE FL 1205 AM EDT TUE SEP 14 1999  ...HURRICANE FORCE WINDS NOW FORECAST TO OCCUR OVER ALL OF THE COASTAL COUNTIES OF EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA FROM EXTREMELY DANGEROUS HURRICANE FLOYD...  ...AREAS AFFECTED... THIS STATEMENT RECOMMENDS ACTIONS TO BE TAKEN BY RESIDENTS OF VOLUSIA... BREVARD... INDIAN RIVER... SAINT LUCIE... MARTIN... LAKE... SEMINOLE... ORANGE... OSCEOLA AND OKEECHOBEE COUNTIES OF EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA IN PREPARATION FOR HURRICANE FLOYD.  ...WATCHES AND WARNINGS... A HURRICANE WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FOR THE ENTIRE EAST COAST OF FLORIDA. AN INLAND HIGH WIND WATCH IS IN EFFECT FOR LAKE...ORANGE... SEMINOLE...OKEECHOBEE...AND OSCEOLA COUNTIES OF EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA. A FLOOD WATCH HAS ALSO BEEN POSTED FOR THE COASTAL COUNTIES OF MARTIN...ST LUCIE...INDIAN RIVER...BREVARD...AND VOLUSIA.  ...STORM INFORMATION... AT 11 PM EDT THE CENTER OF HURRICANE FLOYD WAS LOCATED NEAR LATITUDE 24.5 NORTH...LONGITUDE 74.7 WEST OR ABOUT 460 MILES SOUTHEAST OF CAPE CANAVERAL. FLOYD WAS MOVING SLIGHTLY NORTH OF DUE WEST NEAR 14 MPH. A GRADUAL TURN TOWARD THE NORTHWEST IS STILL EXPECTED ON TUESDAY. HOWEVER...THE LATEST FORECAST TRACK HAS FLOYD MOVING A LITTLE FARTHER TO THE WEST OF THE PREVIOUS FORECAST TRACK...BRINGING IT A LITTLE CLOSER TO THE EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA COAST. MAXIMUM SUSTAINED WINDS REMAIN 155 MPH WITH HIGHER GUSTS.  ...PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS... A HURRICANE WARNING MEANS THAT HURRICANE CONDITIONS ARE EXPECTED WITHIN 24 HOURS. REMEMBER...HURRICANE FORCE WINDS EXTEND OUT 125 MILES FROM THE CENTER. THIS MEANS THAT THE CENTER OF FLOYD WILL NOT HAVE TO STRIKE THE COAST IN ORDER TO PRODUCE HURRICANE CONDITIONS OVER LAND. HURRICANE FORCE WINDS ARE NOW PROJECTED TO IMPACT ALL COASTAL COUNTIES FROM MARTIN TO VOLUSIA COUNTY LATE TUESDAY AND EARLY WEDNESDAY. PREPARATIONS FOR HURRICANE CONDITIONS SHOULD BE NEARING COMPLETION. ANY REMAINING OUTDOOR PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS MUST BE COMPLETED BY TUESDAY MORNING. HOWEVER...RESIDENTS MUST LISTEN CLOSELY TO THE INSTRUCTIONS OF THEIR RESPECTIVE COUNTY OFFICIALS. HEED ANY AND ALL OFFICIAL EVACUATION ORDERS. AGAIN...THIS IS A DANGEROUS SITUATION. ADDITIONAL AND SPECIFIC QUESTIONS REGARDING COUNTY EVACUATION CONDITIONS AND PROCEDURES SHOULD BE DIRECTED TO COUNTY CITIZEN INFORMATION CENTERS. PUBLIC COOPERATION IS STRONGLY URGED!  IT IS IMPORTANT FOR EVERYONE TO REMAIN INFORMED OF THE LATEST TRACK AND INTENSITY OF FLOYD. PLAN TO GET UP EARLY TUESDAY MORNING IN ORDER TO CHECK ON THE STATUS OF THIS EXTREMELY DANGEROUS HURRICANE. FLOYD IS LARGE AND STILL MOVING QUICKLY AND THERE IS SOME UNCERTAINTY IN EXACTLY HOW CLOSE TO THE COAST FLOYD WILL GET. ANY FURTHER CHANGE TO THE LEFT OF THE FORECAST TRACK WOULD LIKELY BRING THIS MAJOR CATEGORY 4 HURRICANE DIRECTLY OVER LAND!  SCHOOLS HAVE BEEN CANCELLED FOR BOTH TUESDAY AND WEDNESDAY FOR ALL COASTAL COUNTIES. INLAND RESIDENTS SHOULD LISTEN FOR THE LATEST INFORMATION REGARDING SCHOOL CANCELLATIONS FROM THEIR COUNTY OFFICIALS AND LOCAL NEWS. ALSO...SHELTERS HAVE BEEN OPENED IN EACH OF THE COASTAL COUNTIES...AND SOME INLAND COUNTIES. IF HEADING TO A SHELTER...KEEP IN MIND THAT PETS...WEAPONS...AND ALCOHOL ARE NOT ALLOWED.  ONCE TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS BEGIN TO AFFECT YOUR LOCATION... TRAVEL IS THEN DISCOURAGED.  ...CURRENT RADAR/SEVERE WEATHER THREAT INFORMATION... RAINBANDS FROM FLOYD ARE EXPECTED TO BEGIN OVER MARTIN AND ST LUCIE COUNTIES TUESDAY MORNING AND GRADUALLY SPREAD OVER THE REST OF EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA DURING THE DAY TUESDAY AND INTO WEDNESDAY MORNING.  ...WIND IMPACTS... BASED ON THE LATEST OFFICIAL FORECAST...TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS SHOULD BEGIN IN MARTIN COUNTY BY AROUND 9AM...AND SPREAD INTO OKEECHOBEE...ST LUCIE...INDIAN RIVER AND SOUTHERN BREVARD COUNTIES BY NOON AND VOLUSIA COUNTY BY LATE AFTERNOON. STRONG TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS WILL SPREAD INLAND OVER OSCEOLA...ORANGE...LAKE AND SEMINOLE COUNTIES BY EARLY TUESDAY EVENING AND CONTINUE INTO WEDNESDAY. HIGH WIND WARNINGS WILL BE ISSUED AT 5AM TUESDAY FOR INLAND COUNTIES. HURRICANE FORCE WINDS WILL APPROACH MARTIN COUNTY DURING THE EARLY EVENING THEN SPREAD NORTH AND BECOME STRONGER OVER INDIAN RIVER...BREVARD...AND VOLUSIA COUNTIES VERY EARLY WEDNESDAY MORNING.  THE CENTER OF FLOYD IS EXPECTED TO PASS ABOUT 60 MILES OFFSHORE MARTIN COUNTY...AND ABOUT 25 MILES OFFSHORE CAPE CANAVERAL. IMPORTANTLY...FLOYD IS A STRONG CATEGORY 4 HURRICANE WITH HURRICANE WINDS EXTENDING OUTWARD 125 MILES. THIS MATTER CAN NOT BE OVERSTATED!!  ...STORM SURGE AND TIDE INFORMATION... STORM SURGE OF 5 TO 10 FEET ABOVE NORMAL TIDES ARE POSSIBLE ALONG THE FLORIDA EAST COAST IF THE CENTER REACHES THE COAST. NORMAL HIGH TIDES OF 2 TO 4 FEET WILL BE AROUND NOON TUESDAY AND AGAIN AROUND MIDNIGHT TUESDAY. COASTAL FLOODING AND SIGNIFICANT BEACH EROSION CAN BE EXPECTED.  ...RAINFALL INFORMATION... A FLOOD WATCH HAS BEEN ISSUED FOR THE COASTAL COUNTIES. EVEN THOUGH FLOYD IS MOVING QUICKLY...IT IS RATHER LARGE. AS A RESULT...RAINFALL FROM FLOYD COULD MEASURE AS MUCH AS 5 TO 8 INCHES. FLOODING HAZARDS WILL BE FURTHER HEIGHTENED FOR LOCATIONS THAT HAVE ALREADY RECEIVED GENEROUS RAINS OVER THE PAST FEW DAYS. INLAND COUNTIES CAN EXPECT 4 TO 5 INCHES OF RAIN.  ...MARINE INFORMATION... WEATHER CONDITIONS WILL CONTINUE TO DETERIORATE RAPIDLY OVER THE COASTAL WATERS OVERNIGHT AND SMALL CRAFT SHOULD REMAIN IN PORT. SEAS ARE ALREADY BUILDING AHEAD OF FLOYD WITH 14 FOOT SEAS REPORTED 20 MILES OFFSHORE CAPE CANAVERAL. THE SURF WILL BECOME VERY ROUGH AND THE THREAT OF RIP CURRENTS WILL BE HIGH.  ...NEXT UPDATE... THE NEXT HURRICANE LOCAL STATEMENT WILL BE ISSUED ABOUT 530 AM OR SOONER IF CONDITIONS WARRANT. SHORT RANGE FORECASTS ISSUED HOURLY BY NWS MELBOURNE WILL CONTAIN THE LATEST RADAR INFORMATION AND EXPECTED EFFECTS FROM HURRICANE FLOYD WHEN IT APPROACHES THE COAST. THIS STATEMENT APPLIES TO PEOPLE IN THE UPPER AND MIDDLE KEYS OF MONROE COUNTY FLORIDA CONCERNING THE EFFECTS OF HURRICANE FLOYD.  ...WATCHES AND WARNINGS... A TROPICAL STORM WARNING IS IN EFFECT FOR THE UPPER AND MIDDLE FLORIDA KEYS...FROM THE SEVEN-MILE BRIDGE NORTHWARD TO THE NORTH END  OF KEY LARGO. A WIND ADVISORY MAY BE REQUIRED FOR THE LOWER KEYS TUESDAY AND TUESDAY NIGHT.  ...HURRICANE INFORMATION... AT 11 PM EDT HURRICANE FLOYD WAS CENTERED ABOUT 360 MILES EAST-  SOUTHEAST OF MIAMI. FLOYD IS MOVING SLIGHTLY NORTH OF DUE WEST NEAR  14 MPH. A GRADUAL TURN TO THE NORTHWEST IS EXPECTED ON TUESDAY.  MAXIMUM SUSTAINED WINDS ARE NEAR 155 MPH WITH HIGHER GUSTS...MAKING  IT A STRONG CATEGORY FOUR STORM. LITTLE CHANGE IN STRENGTH IS  EXPECTED TONIGHT AND TUESDAY.  ...PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS... BASED ON CURRENT FORECAST TRENDS...THERE ARE NO PLANS FOR EVACUATION ORDERS FOR MONROE COUNTY. HOWEVER...MONROE COUNTY EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT ADVISES EVERYONE IN THE KEYS TO STAY TUNED TO FUTURE REPORTS.   SEVERAL PRECAUTIONARY MEASURES ARE UNDERWAY BY MONROE COUNTY  EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT OFFICIALS...  MONROE COUNTY SHELTERS THAT ARE OPEN ARE KEY LARGO ELEMENTARY SCHOOL AND STANLEY SWITLIK ELEMENTARY SCHOOL IN MARATHON.  ALL MONROE COUNTY SCHOOLS ARE CLOSED TO STUDENTS ON TUESDAY.  ALL COUNTY AND STATE PARKS ARE CLOSED AS OF MONDAY NIGHT.  ALL COUNTY OFFICES FROM SEVEN MILE BRIDGE TO THE NORTH END OF KEY  LARGO ARE CLOSED TUESDAY. THERE IS A POSSIBILITY SOME OTHER COUNTY  OFFICES MAY BE CLOSED WEST OF THE SEVEN MILE BRIDGE TUESDAY.  MONROE COUNTY RUMOR CONTROL TELEPHONE NUMBER IS 1-800-955-5504.  UPPER AND MIDDLE KEYS RESIDENTS AND VISITORS ARE URGED TO STAY OFF ROADS...ESPECIALLY IN THE UPPER KEYS AND THE 18 MILE STRETCH WHERE THERE IS A POSSIBILITY OF FLOODING. PERSONS ATTEMPTING TO DRIVE NORTH FROM THE KEYS TO THE MAINLAND SHOULD BE AWARE THAT EVACUATION TRAFFIC ALONG THE ENTIRE FLORIDA EAST COAST IS EXTREMELY HEAVY. IF TRAVEL TO THE MAINLAND IS ABSOLUTELY REQUIRED TONIGHT OR EARLY TUESDAY... IT WOULD BE BEST TO AVOID THE TURNPIKE...INTERSTATE 95..AND U.S. 1 FROM MIAMI-DADE COUNTY NORTHWARD.    ...STORM SURGE FLOODING/TIDES/OTHER MARINE HAZARDS SOME MINOR TIDAL OVERFLOW MAY OCCUR ALONG THE UPPER AND MIDDLE KEYS...NEAR THE TIMES OF HIGH TIDE TUESDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY. BROCK/KASPER                                                         WWUS31 KMIA 140308 HLSMIA FLZ063-066-068-072-074-140615-  HURRICANE FLOYD LOCAL STATEMENT NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MIAMI FL 1115 PM EDT MON SEP 13 1999  ...HURRICANE FLOYD A THREAT TO SOUTHEAST FLORIDA...   THIS STATEMENT APPLIES TO PEOPLE IN MIAMI-DADE...BROWARD...PALM  BEACH...GLADES AND HENDRY COUNTIES OF SOUTH FLORIDA CONCERNING  HURRICANE FLOYD.  ...WATCH/WARNING HURRICANE WARNING IS IN EFFECT FOR MIAMI-DADE...BROWARD AND PALM  BEACH COUNTIES INCLUDING LAKE OKEECHOBEE. HIGH WIND WATCH IS IN EFFECT FOR HENDRY AND GLADES COUNTIES.  ...CENTER LOCATION/MOVEMENT/INTENSITY AND TREND... AT 8 PM EDT HURRICANE FLOYD WAS LOCATED ABOUT 360 MILES EAST  SOUTHEAST OF WEST PALM BEACH....FORT LAUDERDALE AND MIAMI. FLOYD WAS  MOVING WEST AT 14 MPH AND IS EXPECTED TO CONTINUE THIS MOTION THIS  EVENING WITH A GRADUAL TURN TO THE WEST-NORTHWEST LATE TONIGHT.  THE HIGHEST WINDS ARE 155 MPH...MAKING IT A STRONG CATEGORY FOUR  STORM...AND SOME FLUCTUATIONS IN STRENGTH ARE POSSIBLE OVERNIGHT.  THE PROBABILITY OF THE CENTER OF THE HURRICANE PASSING WITHIN 75  MILES OF WEST PALM BEACH WAS 38 PERCENT AND FOR MIAMI IT WAS 24  PERCENT. ALTHOUGH THE FORECAST TRACK IS EXPECTED TO KEEP THE CENTER  OFFSHORE...THE FORECAST UNCERTAINTY IS ENOUGH THAT RESIDENTS IN THE  WARNING AREA SHOULD RUSH PREPARATIONS TO COMPLETION AS SOON AS  POSSIBLE.   ...WIND INFORMATION FLOYD IS A LARGE STORM WITH TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS...40 MPH OR  GREATER EXTENDING OUTWARD 200 MILES TO THE WEST OF THE CENTER...  AND HURRICANE FORCE WINDS EXTENDING OUTWARD UP TO 90 MILES WEST OF  THE CENTER. ALONG THE SOUTHEAST FLORIDA COAST TONIGHT NORTHEAST  WINDS WILL BE 15 TO 20 MPH WITH 25 TO 30 MPH GUSTS AT THE BEACH.  TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS COULD BEGIN OVER MIAMI-DADE COUNTY AS  EARLY AS ABOUT 8 AM TUESDAY... AND BEGIN OVER BROWARD AND PALM BEACH  COUNTIES BEFORE NOON. WINDS MAY INCREASE TO HURRICANE FORCE IN  MIAMI-DADE COUNTY BY TUESDAY AFTERNOON AND IN BROWARD AND PALM BEACH  COUNTIES LATE TUESDAY AFTERNOON INTO TUESDAY NIGHT. WIND WILL BE  ESPECIALLY STRONG IN SHOWERS AND SQUALLS AS THE RAIN BANDS ALONG THE  WEST SIDE OF FLOYD MOVE THROUGH.   ...RAINFALL/FLOODING SCATTERED SHOWERS WILL MOVE THROUGH THE AREA OVERNIGHT WITH NO  WIDESPREAD SIGNIFICANT AMOUNTS OF RAINFALL. SHOWERS AND SQUALLS WILL  INCREASE ON TUESDAY AFTERNOON AND BECOME VERY HEAVY TUESDAY NIGHT  AND WEDNESDAY. THE HEAVY RAINS TUESDAY NIGHT AND WEDNESDAY COULD  BRING AMOUNTS OF 3 TO 5 INCHES...MAINLY ALONG THE COASTAL SECTIONS  OF PALM BEACH COUNTY WHICH COULD CAUSE SOME LOCAL URBAN STREET  FLOODING.  ...STORM SURGE FLOODING/TIDE/OTHER MARINE HAZARDS ALONG ITS CURRENT TRACK TIDES ALONG THE SOUTHEAST COAST WILL  GRADUALLY INCREASE THROUGH TUESDAY WITH A MORE RAPID RISE TO AS  MUCH AS 2 TO 3 FEET ABOVE NORMAL TUESDAY NIGHT AND EARLY WEDNESDAY.  SOME MINOR TIDAL OVERFLOW MAY OCCUR NEAR TIMES OF HIGH TIDE ON  TUESDAY AND WEDNESDAY. SHOULD FLOYD REMAIN ON A MORE WESTERLY COURSE  INSTEAD OF TURNING MORE WEST-NORTHWEST OR NORTHWEST... AND THE  CENTER MOVE ACROSS THE SOUTHEAST FLORIDA COAST... STORM SURGE VALUES  WILL BE MUCH HIGHER ESPECIALLY ALONG AND JUST NORTH OF WHERE THE  CENTER CROSSES THE COAST.  SURF CONDITIONS WILL BECOME INCREASINGLY ROUGH AND BOATERS ARE  URGED TO REMAIN IN PORT. OCEAN INLETS WILL BECOME VERY HAZARDOUS...  ESPECIALLY WITH THE OUTGOING TIDE. BATHERS ARE URGED TO USE EXTREME  CAUTION BECAUSE TO THE INCREASED THREAT OF DEADLY RIP AND LONGSHORE  CURRENTS AT OCEAN BEACHES. BY TUESDAY SWIMMING... BATHING... AND  SURFING SHOULD CEASE ALONG OCEAN BEACHES IN MIAMI-DADE... BROWARD...  AND PALM BEACH COUNTIES.  TIMES OF HIGH TIDE AT THE MIAMI HARBOR ENTRANCE INCLUDE... 1204 PM TUESDAY...1212AM WEDNESDAY...1249 PM WEDNESDAY.  ...PROTECTIVE ACTIONS PEOPLE WHO NEED EXTRA TIME TO COMPLETE ANY OUTSIDE PREPARATION  ACTIVITIES SHOULD BE WELL INTO THESE PREPARATIONS. THIS WOULD  INCLUDE THE PROTECTION OF BOATS...REMOVING OUTSIDE DEBRIS AND  CHECKING OR INSTALLING SHUTTERS. BECAUSE OF INCREASING WIND IT IS  SUGGESTED THAT ALL OUTSIDE ACTIVITIES SHOULD BE COMPLETED BY TUESDAY  MORNING. PERSONS SHOULD LEARN WHETHER THEIR LOCATION IS IN AN  EVACUATION ZONE AND HAVE A DESTINATION IN MIND SHOULD EVACUATION  ORDERS BE GIVEN. A MANDATORY EVACUATION OF MOBILE HOMES AND THE  BARRIER ISLANDS INCLUDING MIAMI BEACH.. KEY BIACAYNE.. AND VIRGINIA  KEY HAS BEEN ORDERED BY MIAMI-DADE EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT. A MANDATORY  EVACUATION OF MOBILE HOMES IS IN EFFECT IN BROWARD COUNTY.  ADDITIONAL MANDATORY EVACUATIONS MAY BE DECLARED IN BROWARD AND PALM  BEACH COUNTIES BY EARLY TUESDAY MORNING. PERSONS IN MOBILE HOMES...  EVEN INLAND AWAY FROM THE BEACHES... SHOULD ALSO THINK OF SAFER  ACCOMMODATIONS. SCHOOLS WILL BE CLOSED TUESDAY IN BROWARD..  MIAMI-DADE.. AND PALM BEACH COUNTIES. BOTH MIAMI INTERNATIONAL AND  FORT LAUDERDALE/HOLLYWOOD INTERNATIONAL AIRPORTS ARE SCHEDULED TO  SUSPEND FLIGHT OPERATIONS AT 9 AM TUESDAY MORNING. THIS DOES NOT INCLUDE GLYNN COUNTY IN SOUTHEAST GEORGIA AT THIS TIME... ...A HURRICANE WATCH IS IN EFFECT FROM BRUNSWICK GEORGIA NORTHWARD TO SAVANNAH GEORGIA INCLUDING GLYNN COUNTY... ...SMALL CRAFT SHOULD REMAIN IN PORT... ...A HIGH WIND WATCH IS IN EFFECT FOR TUESDAY NIGHT AND WEDNESDAY...  THIS STATEMENT PERTAINS TO RESIDENTS IN THE FOLLOWING COUNTIES OF SOUTHEAST GEORGIA APPLING...ATKINSON...BACON...BRANTLEY...CAMDEN... CHARLTON...CLINCH...COFFEE...ECHOLS...GLYNN...JEFF DAVIS...PIERCE... WARE...WAYNE AND THE FOLLOWING COUNTIES OF NORTHEAST FLORIDA... ALACHUA...BAKER...BRADFORD...CLAY...COLUMBIA..DUVAL...FLAGLER... GILCHRIST...HAMILTON...MARION...NASSAU...PUTNAM...ST. JOHNS... SUWANNEE...UNION.  HURRICANE FLOYD REPRESENTS A SERIOUS HURRICANE THREAT TO THE REGION. INTERESTS IN THE WATCH AND WARNING AREAS ARE URGED TO KEEP ABREAST OF THE LATEST INFORMATION PERTAINING TO HURRICANE FLOYD.  AT 11 PM EDT HURRICANE FLOYD WAS LOCATED NEAR LATITUDE 24.5 NORTH LONGITUDE 74.7 WEST OR APPROXIMATELY 590 MILES SOUTHEAST OF JACKSONVILLE BEACH. MAXIMUM SUSTAINED WINDS ARE NEAR 155 MPH AND THE MINIMUM CENTRAL PRESSURE IS 924 MB. FLOYD IS MOVING TOWARD THE WEST AT 14 MPH AND THIS MOVEMENT IS EXPECTED TO CONTINUE TONIGHT WITH A GRADUAL TURN TOWARDS THE NORTHWEST EXPECTED ON TUESDAY. ON ITS CURRENT FORECAST TRACK...THE CENTER OF THE STORM IS EXPECTED TO PASS APPROXIMATELY 50 TO 100 MILES OFFSHORE OF THE NORTHEAST FLORIDA AND SOUTHEAST GEORGIA COASTS FROM EARLY WEDNESDAY MORNING THROUGH THE EARLY EVENING HOURS. THE EXACT EFFECTS FELT IN THE WARNED AREA IS HIGHLY DEPENDANT UPON FLOYD'S ULTIMATE PATH AS IT MOVES ABREAST OF THE AREA.  ...WIND INFORMATION... FLOYD IS A POWERFUL AND LARGE HURRICANE. ALTHOUGH THE CENTER IS FORECAST TO REMAIN OFFSHORE...THE WIND FIELD IS LARGE ENOUGH TO HAVE A SIGNIFICANT IMPACT ON THE AREA. ON ITS CURRENT FORECAST TRACK... TROPICAL STORM WINDS WILL START TO REACH THE NORTHEAST FLORIDA COAST BEGINNING TUESDAY NIGHT AND THEN SPREAD NORTHWARD INTO SOUTHEAST GEORGIA DURING THE EARLY MORNING HOURS ON WEDNESDAY. THESE WINDS WILL CONTINUE TO AFFECT THE AREA THROUGH WEDNESDAY EVENING. WINDS WILL APPROACH HURRICANE FORCE...GREATER THAN 74 MPH...IN SQUALLS DURING THE DAY ON WEDNESDAY. MAXIMUM WINDS ARE ESTIMATED TO BE NEAR 75 MPH WITH HIGHER GUSTS  WHICH MAKES IRENE A MINIMAL CATEGORY ONE HURRICANE ON THE  SAFFIR-SIMPSON SCALE. SOME SLIGHT STRENGTHENING IS STILL POSSIBLE  BEFORE LANDFALL.   ...RAINFALL AND FLOODING STORM RAINFALL TOTALS OF 4 TO 8 INCHES HAVE FALLEN ACROSS THE  METRO AREAS OF MIAMI-DADE...BROWARD AND PALM BEACH COUNTIES WITH 2  TO 4 INCHES IN OTHER AREAS OF SOUTH FLORIDA INCLUDING THE NAPLES  AREA. ADDITIONAL RAINFALL AMOUNTS OF AT LEAST 6 TO 10 INCHES ARE  POSSIBLE BEFORE THE RAIN ENDS LATE SATURDAY. WITH SATURATED GROUND  FLOODING OF POORLY DRAINED AREAS WILL OCCUR. THE HEAVY RAINS WILL  PUT PRESSURE ON FLAT TOPPED ROOFS WHICH MAY LEAK OR COLLAPSE FROM  THE WEIGHT OF THE WATER.  MOTORISTS ARE URGED TO USE EXTREME CAUTION. STANDING WATER ON  ROADWAYS CAN CAUSE MOTORISTS TO DRIVE INTO CANALS OR OTHER DEEP  WATER. PARENTS ARE URGED TO SUPERVISE CHILDREN TO PREVENT THEM FROM  PLAYING IN FLOODED AREAS WHERE HAZARDS INCLUDE SHARP UNDERWATER  OBJECTS...STORM DRAINS AND CONTAMINATED WATER.   ...WIND INFORMATION AT NOON A WIND GUST OF 61 MPH WAS REPORTED AT HOMESTEAD AIR RESERVE  BASE AND MANY OTHER LOCATIONS IN MIAMI-DADE AND SOUTHERN BROWARD  COUNTY ARE REPORTING WIND GUSTS NEAR OR ABOVE 40 MPH. THESE WIND  GUSTS WILL SPREAD NORTH THIS AFTERNOON INTO NORTHERN BROWARD AND  PALM BEACH COUNTY AS WELL AS IN COLLIER...HENDRY AND GLADES  COUNTIES. WIND WILL APPROACH HURRICANE STRENGTH OVER MAINLAND  MONROE...AND COLLIER COUNTIES BY MID TO LATE AFTERNOON AND CONTINUE  THROUGH THIS EVENING.  ...STORM SURGE/TIDE/OTHER MARINE HAZARDS THE STORM SURGE...WHICH IS HIGHLY DEPENDENT ON THE EXACT  TRACK...WILL BE AT A MAXIMUM ALONG THE SOUTHWEST FLORIDA COAST  BEGINNING THIS EVENING OR EARLY TONIGHT AFTER IRENE MOVES NORTH  OF THE AREA. MAXIMUM STORM SURGE VALUES OF 5 TO 7 FEET ARE EXPECTED  IN THIS AREA AND WILL FLOOD THE AREA AROUND CHOKOLOSKEE...EVERGLADES  CITY INCLUDING HIGHWAY 29. STORM SURGE FLOODING CAN ALSO BE EXPECTED  NEAR MARCO ISLAND. LUSHINE                        WWUS31 KTBW 151602 HLSTBW FLZ039-042-043-048>052-055>057-060>062-065-151930-  HURRICANE IRENE LOCAL STATEMENT NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE TAMPA BAY AREA - RUSKIN FL 1200 PM EDT FRI OCT 15 1999  ...WATCH/WARNING INFORMATION...  ...HURRICANE WARNING CONTINUED FOR THE FOLLOWING LOCATIONS: ...LEE...CHARLOTTE...DESOTO...SARASOTA...MANATEE...HILLSBOROUGH    ...AND PINELLAS COUNTY.  ...HURRICANE WATCH CONTINUED FOR THE FOLLOWING LOCATIONS: ...CITRUS...HERNANDO...AND PASCO COUNTIES.  ...TORNADO WATCH UNTIL 3 PM FOR THE FOLLOWING LOCATIONS: ...HIGHLANDS COUNTY.  ...INLAND HIGH WIND WARNING IN EFFECT FOR THE FOLLOWING LOCATIONS: ...HIGHLAND...HARDEE...AND POLK COUNTIES.  ...FLOOD WATCH CONTINUED FOR THE FOLLOWING LOCATIONS: ...LEE...CHARLOTTE...DESOTO...HARDEE...HIGHLANDS...SARASOTA... ...MANATEE...HILLSBOROUGH...AND POLK COUNTIES.  ...STORM LOCATION... AT NOON EDT...THE CENTER OF HURRICANE IRENE WAS LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 125 STATUTE MILES SOUTH SOUTHEAST OF FORT MYERS OR 225 STATUTE MILES SOUTH SOUTHEAST OF TAMPA. IRENE IS MOVING NORTH NORTHEAST AT 8 MPH.  IRENE REMAINS NEAR MINIMAL HURRICANE STRENGTH WITH MAXIMUM SUSTAINED WINDS NEAR 75 MPH AROUND NEAR THE CENTER.  SLIGHT STRENGTHENING IS POSSIBLE DURING THE NEXT 12 HOURS UNTIL LANDFALL. HOWEVER TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS OF 39 TO 73 MPH EXTEND OUTWARD UP TO 140 MILES FROM THE CENTER AND ARE EXPECTED TO BEGIN EFFECTING CHARLOTTE AND LEE COUNTIES BY SOMETIME THIS AFTERNOON.  ...RADAR AND RAINFALL INFORMATION... DOPPLER RADAR COMPOSITES SHOWED THE HEAVIEST RAINBANDS REMAINED SOUTH AND EAST OF LEE COUNTY AT 1130 AM.  THESE BANDS WERE MOVING VERY SLOWLY NORTHEASTWARD. OTHER SCATTERED SHOWERS WERE CONTINUED TO DEVELOP WESTWARD FROM THE EAST COAST OF FLORIDA INTO POLK...SUMTER... PASCO...AND HERNANDO COUNTIES.  THESE SHOWERS AND ISOLATED THUNDERSTORMS ARE EXPECTED TO INCREASE IN COVERAGE AND INTENSITY FROM SOUTHEAST TO NORTHWEST THROUGH THE DAY. THIS IS ESPECIALLY TRUE IN HIGHLANDS COUNTY...WHERE A TORNADO WATCH IS IN EFFECT UNTIL 3 PM.  IRENE HAS HAD VERY HEAVY RAINFALL ASSOCIATED WITH IT SO FAR...AND THIS IS EXPECTED TO CONTINUE AS THE STORM MOVES NORTHWARD INTO FLORIDA. STORM TOTAL RAINFALL OF UP TO 10 INCHES IS POSSIBLE ALONG AND EAST OF THE CENTER TRACK OF IRENE IN HIGHLANDS AND EASTERN POLK COUNTIES. ELSEWHERE...2 TO 4 INCHES IS POSSIBLE BEFORE THE STORM MOVES BY SATURDAY NIGHT. OF COURSE...IF THE TRACK SHIFTS WESTWARD HEAVIER RAIN WILL FALL ACROSS WEST CENTRAL AND SOUTHWEST FLORIDA... AND IF IT MOVES FARTHER EAST RAINFALL AMOUNTS WILL DECREASE.  ...WIND INFORMATION... WINDS ARE CONTINUING TO INCREASE OVER LEE AND CHARLOTTE COUNTIES. AT 11 AM...WINDS WERE GUSTING BEYOND 30 MPH OVER PORTIONS OF THE AREA... WITH WINDS LIKELY GUSTING TO MINIMAL TROPICAL STORM FORCE ALONG THE COAST AND NEAR BAYS...HARBORS...INLAND WATERS...AND LOCAL HIGH SPOTS. SUSTAINED WINDS OF TROPICAL STORM FORCE ARE NOT EXPECTED UNTIL EARLY AFTERNOON IN LEE COUNTY...AND LATER AFTERNOON IN CHARLOTTE COUNTY.  SUSTAINED WINDS WILL SLOWLY INCREASE ELSEWHERE THROUGH THE AFTERNOON...BUT SHOULD REMAIN BELOW TROPICAL STORM STRENGTH UNTIL THIS EVENING. TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS WILL GRADUALLY MOVE FROM THE SOUTH TO NORTH TONIGHT...EFFECTING DESOTO...HIGHLANDS... SARASOTA...AND HARDEE COUNTIES BY MID TO LATE THIS AFTERNOON AND MANATEE...POLK...HILLSBOROUGH...AND SUMTER COUNTIES BY LATE TONIGHT AND EARLY SATURDAY MORNING.  ...STORM SURGE INFORMATION... HURRICANE TIDAL WATER AND STORM SURGE INCREASES WILL BE HIGHLY DEPENDENT UPON THE EVENTUAL STRENGTH AND TRACK OF IRENE AS THE HURRICANE MOVES NORTH NORTHEASTWARD. THE FOLLOWING STORM SURGE ESTIMATES ARE BASED ON THE LATEST TRACK AND INTENSITY FORECAST AND THE INHERENT UNCERTAINTY IN THESE TRACK FORECASTS:  ...LOCATION...    ...SURGE ESTIMATE...  ...TIME OF POTENTIAL SURGE...  LEE COAST            3 TO 5 FEET           TONIGHT THRU AM SAT  CHARLOTTE COAST AND  2 TO 4 FEET           TONIGHT THRU AM SAT CHARLOTTE HARBOR INCLUDING TIDAL DESOTO COUNTY  SARASOTA COAST       1 TO 2 FEET           TONIGHT THRU AM SAT  TO CALCULATE STORM TIDE...ADD THE STORM SURGE FORECAST TO THE ASTRONOMICAL TIDE.  STORM SURGE + ASTRONOMICAL TIDE = STORM TIDE.  ALL PERSONS ALONG THE SOUTHWEST FLORIDA GULF COAST SHOULD CLOSELY MONITOR TIDAL WATER FORECASTS. REMEMBER...THE GREATEST THREAT FOR STORM SURGE WILL OCCUR ALONG OR TO THE RIGHT OF LANDFALL. THIS STATEMENT RECOMMENDS ACTIONS TO BE TAKEN BY RESIDENTS OF MARTIN...SAINT LUCIE...OKEECHOBEE...INDIAN RIVER...BREVARD... OSCEOLA...ORANGE...LAKE...SEMINOLE...AND VOLUSIA COUNTIES OF EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA.  ...STORM INFORMATION... AT 11 AM EDT THE CENTER OF HURRICANE IRENE WAS LOCATED NEAR LATITUDE 24.7 NORTH...LONGITUDE  81.6 WEST OR ABOUT 250 MILES SOUTH OF ORLANDO. IRENE IS MOVING TOWARD THE NORTH NORTHEAST NEAR 8 MPH. MAXIMUM SUSTAINED WINDS ARE NEAR 75 MPH...WITH HIGHER GUSTS.  HURRICANE IRENE IS FORECAST TO MAKE LANDFALL ALONG THE SOUTHWEST FLORIDA COAST TONIGHT...MOVE ACROSS EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA SATURDAY AND EXIT INTO THE ATLANTIC SATURDAY NIGHT.  ...PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS... RESIDENTS OF EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA SHOULD PREPARE FOR FLOODING RAINFALL AND TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS FROM IRENE. RESIDENTS OF LOW LYING AND FLOOD PRONE AREAS SHOULD REMAIN ALERT FOR THE ISSUANCE OF FLOOD WARNINGS. LOOSE OBJECTS THAT CAN BE BLOWN ABOUT BY THE WIND SHOULD BE SECURED OR BROUGHT INSIDE.  ...STORM SURGE AND STORM TIDE INFORMATION... WITH THE CENTER OF IRENE EXPECTED TO REMAIN OVER LAND AND WEAKEN...SIGNIFICANT STORM SURGE IS NOT EXPECTED ALONG THE COAST FROM SOUTH OF FLAGLER BEACH TO JUPITER INLET. HOWEVER... SUSTAINED ONSHORE WINDS OF TROPICAL STORM FORCE SATURDAY WILL PRODUCE EXTREMELY ROUGH SURF...ADDITIONAL MINOR BEACH EROSION...AND POSSIBLY SOME MINOR COASTAL FLOODING...ESPECIALLY AROUND THE TIME OF HIGH TIDE. HIGH TIDES ALONG THE EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA COAST FROM DAYTONA BEACH TO FT PIERCE WILL BE JUST AFTER MIDNIGHT TONIGHT AND JUST AFTER 1PM SATURDAY AFTERNOON  ...CURRENT RADAR/SEVERE WEATHER THREAT... AT 1130...SCATTERED SHOWERS WITH LOCALLY HEAVY RAIN CONTINUED OVER MUCH OF EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA. THIS RAINFALL IS NOT DIRECTLY ASSOCIATED WITH THE MAIN CIRCULATION OF IRENE. RAINFALL AMOUNTS OF 1 TO 2 INCHES CAN BE EXPECTED THIS AFTERNOON WHICH WILL CAUSE SOME PONDING OF WATER ON ROADWAYS. A TORNADO WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT FOR OKEECHOBEE...MARTIN AND ST LUCIE COUNTIES UNTIL 3PM...BUT THERE HAS BEEN NO INDICATION OF SEVERE WEATHER DURING THE MORNING. ANY TORNADOES THAT DO FORM WILL TYPICALLY BE ASSOCIATED WITH INTENSE CONVECTION IN IRENE'S OUTER RAINBANDS. THE SEVERE WEATHER THREAT IS EXPECTED TO INCREASE LATE TONIGHT AND CONTINUE THROUGH SATURDAY. SPOTTER ACTIVATION WILL PROBABLY BE REQUESTED EARLY SATURDAY MORNING.  ...WIND AND RAINFALL INFORMATION... IRENE HAS BECOME BETTER ORGANIZED AND IF THE DEEP CONVECTION HOLDS TOGETHER AS IT MOVES INTO EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA SATURDAY...EXTREME RAINFALL OF PERHAPS 8 TO 12 INCHES IS POSSIBLE. FLOODING IS PROBABLY THE GREATEST THREAT FROM IRENE. THE SITUATION IS STILL UNFOLDING RAINFALL COULD BE LESS OR IT COULD BE SIGNIFICANTLY HIGHER. FLOOD WARNINGS ARE LIKELY TO BE ISSUED LATER TONIGHT OR EARLY SATURDAY. SOME AREAS OF EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA HAVE EXPERIENCED 24 INCHES OF RAIN IN THE PAST 30 DAYS. ANY ADDITIONAL RAIN WILL QUICKLY CAUSE SERIOUS FLOODING PROBLEMS.  BASED ON THE CURRENT FORECAST TRACK TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS SHOULD BEGIN TO MOVE IN TO MARTIN...ST LUCIE AND OKEECHOBEE COUNTIES THIS EVENING AND REACH SOUTHERN BREVARD...INDIAN RIVER...AND OSCEOLA COUNTIES BY EARLY SATURDAY. THE ORLANDO METRO AREA AND SANFORD COULD SEE TROPICAL STORM FORCE GUSTS BY DAYBREAK SATURDAY...AND VOLUSIA COUNTY AND DAYTONA BEACH SATURDAY AFTERNOON. PEAK WIND GUSTS DURING IRENE ARE EXPECTED TO BE IN THE 50 TO 60 MPH RANGE WHICH WILL NOT CAUSE WIDESPREAD DAMAGE...BUT WILL BLOW TREE LIMBS ON POWER LINES CAUSING SCATTERED OUTAGES...POSSIBLY BRING DOWN OLDER DISEASED TREES. THE STRONGEST WINDS WILL LIKELY OCCUR IN RAIN SQUALLS WITHIN RAINBANDS.  ...NEXT UPDATE... THE NEXT HURRICANE LOCAL STATEMENT WILL BE ISSUED AT 6 PM OR SOONER IF CONDITIONS WARRANT. SHORT RANGE FORECASTS ISSUED HOURLY BY NWS MELBOURNE WILL CONTAIN THE LATEST RADAR INFORMATION AND EXPECTED EFFECTS FROM IRENE. THIS STATEMENT APPLIES TO PEOPLE IN ALL OF THE FLORIDA KEYS OF  MONROE COUNTY CONCERNING THE EFFECTS OF HURRICANE IRENE.    ...WARNINGS... A HURRICANE WARNING IS IN EFFECT FOR ALL OF THE FLORIDA KEYS AND FOR  THE DRY TORTUGAS. A HURRICANE WARNING MEANS THAT HURRICANE  CONDITIONS ARE EXPECTED OR OCCURRING.    A FLOOD WARNING IS ALSO IN EFFECT FOR THE KEYS THROUGH 125 PM. A  FLOOD WARNING MEANS THE FLOODING IS OCCURRING OR IMMEDIATE WITHIN  THE WARNED AREA.  ...STORM INFORMATION... AT 1100 AM EDT THE CENTER OF HURRICANE IRENE WAS NEAR LATITUDE 24.7  NORTH...LONGITUDE 81.6 WEST...OR VERY NEAR KEY WEST. THE EYE WAS  POORLY-DEFINED AND MOVEMENT WAS ERRATIC WITH A NET MOTION TO THE  NORTH NORTHEAST NEAR 8 MPH.        AT 1100 AM EDT THE CENTRAL PRESSURE OF IRENE WAS 987 MB OR 29.14  INCHES. AT 800 AM EDT...THE CENTER OF HURRICANE IRENE WAS LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 160 MILES SOUTH OF FORT MYERS OR 255 MILES SOUTH SOUTHEAST OF TAMPA. IRENE IS MOVING JUST EAST OF DUE NORTH AT ABOUT 8 MPH. IRENE HAS HAD VERY HEAVY RAINFALL ASSOCIATED WITH IT SO FAR...AND THIS IS EXPECTED TO CONTINUE AS THE STORM MOVES NORTHWARD INTO WEST CENTRAL AND SOUTHWEST FLORIDA. STORM TOTAL RAINFALL OF 10 TO 15 INCHES OF RAIN IS POSSIBLE ALONG AND EAST OF THE CENTER TRACK OF IRENE.   ...WIND INFORMATION... WINDS ARE BEGINNING TO INCREASE OVER LEE COUNTY. CLAY...DUVAL...FLAGLER...MARION...NASSAU...PUTNAM... AND ST JOHNS.  A FLOOD WATCH MEANS THAT THE THREAT OF FLOODING EXISTS IN THE ABOVE  AREA. BE READY FOR QUICK ACTION IF HEAVY RAINS PRODUCE FLOODING OR  IF A FLOOD WARNING IS ISSUED.  A VERY MOIST AND DEEP EASTERLY FLOW OF AIR MOVING OFF THE ATLANTIC  ASSOCIATED WITH IRENE WILL RESULT IN HEAVY DOWNPOURS OF AN INCH OR  TWO IN AN HOUR AT TIMES UNTIL AROUND MIDNIGHT TONIGHT. THIS RAINFALL  COMBINED WITH THE RAIN WHICH HAS ALREADY FALLEN COULD CAUSE FLOODING  OF SOME AREAS.  LOW LYING AREAS AND LOCATIONS WITH POOR DRAINAGE WILL BE THE FIRST  TO BE AFFECTED. AS RAINFALL TOTALS ADD UP MORE SERIOUS FLOODING IS  POSSIBLE.  A FLOOD WATCH MEANS THAT THE THREAT OF FLOODING EXISTS WITHIN THE WATCH AREA. AT 8 AM EDT THE CENTER OF HURRICANE IRENE WAS LOCATED NEAR LATITUDE 27.8 NORTH...LONGITUDE 80.1 WEST OR ABOUT 50 MILES SOUTHEAST OF MELBOURNE FLORIDA. IRENE IS MOVING TOWARD THE NORTH NEAR 10 MPH...AND THIS GENERAL TRACK IS EXPECTED TO CONTINUE TODAY. MAXIMUM SUSTAINED WINDS ARE NEAR  75 MPH...WITH HIGHER GUSTS. WIND GUSTS TO 75 MPH HAVE OCCURRED OVER BREVARD COUNTY THIS MORNING.  ...DISCUSSION... HURRICANE IRENE REMAINED AT HURRICANE STRENGTH AS IT CROSS THE FLORIDA PENINSULA DURING THE NIGHT AND IS MOVING OVER THE IMMEDIATE ATLANTIC COASTAL WATER JUST OFFSHORE INDIAN RIVER COUNTY AND BECOMING BETTER ORGANIZED. A HURRICANE WARNING IS NOT IN EFFECT FOR THE EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA COAST BECAUSE SUSTAINED HURRICANE FORCE WINDS ARE NOT EXPECTED...HOWEVER VERY STRONG TROPICAL STORM CONDITIONS WILL OCCUR.  THE CENTER OF IRENE IS EXPECTED TO CONTINUE ON A NORTHWARD TRACK WITH THE WESTERN EDGE OF THE MAIN INNER RAINBANDS EFFECTING EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA DURING THE DAY. THE CONVECTION AROUND HURRICANE IRENE CONTINUES TO EVOLVE AS A MORE DEFINED CENTER TRIES TO FORM OVER THE COASTAL WATERS. THE STRONGEST RAINBANDS HAVE BEEN ON THE NORTH AND WEST SIDE OF IRENE AND THIS TREND MAY CONTINUE THROUGH THE DAY AS IRENE MOVES TO JUST OFFSHORE CAPE CANAVERAL BY EARLY AFTERNOON. BREVARD COUNTY IN PARTICULAR WILL EXPERIENCE CONTINUOUS TROPICAL STORM CONDITIONS THROUGH THE DAY.  RAINBANDS WILL BRING FLOODING RAINFALL AND WIND GUSTS TO 75 MPH TO BREVARD...INDIAN RIVER...MARTIN AND ST LUCIE COUNTIES THIS MORNING. HIGH WINDS AND FLOODING RAIN WILL SPREAD INTO VOLUSIA AND FLAGLER COUNTIES DURING THE DAY. CONDITIONS WILL IMPROVE FROM THE SOUTH OVER MARTIN AND ST LUCIE COUNTIES DURING THE AFTERNOON.  TRAVEL IS NOT RECOMMENDED FROM BREVARD COUNTY SOUTHWARD AS ROADS ARE FLOODED...WINDS HAS BLOW DEBRIS ON ROADWAYS...TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES ARE NOT WORKING IN SOME AREAS...VISIBILITY IS POOR AND DITCHES ARE FLOODED. THE BEST ADVICE IS TO STAY INDOORS TODAY. TRAVEL WILL BECOME HAZARDOUS OVER VOLUSIA AND FLAGLER COUNTIES BY LATE MORNING AND CONTINUE INTO THE AFTERNOON.  SUSTAINED WIND SPEEDS WILL BE 40 TO 50 MPH...AND HURRICANE FORCE WIND GUSTS CAPABLE OF PRODUCING DAMAGE WILL OCCUR IN STRONG CONVECTION WITHIN RAINBANDS. NWS MELBOURNE WILL ISSUE SEVERE WEATHER STATEMENTS TO HIGHLIGHT THE LOCATION OF THESE STRONGEST WINDS AT LEAST HOURLY DURING THE DAY. ISOLATED TORNADOS ARE ALSO POSSIBLE AS INTENSE RAINBAND CONVECTION MOVES ONSHORE. RESIDENTS SHOULD ALSO BE ALERT FOR THE ISSUANCE OF TORNADO WARNINGS.  THE FLOOD THREAT WILL REMAIN HIGH OVER VOLUSIA...BREVARD...INDIAN RIVER...ST LUCIE OKEECHOBEE AND MARTIN COUNTY DURING THE DAY WITH CONDITIONS IMPROVING FROM THE SOUTH AS THE DAY PROGRESSES.  ...INLAND COUNTIES... THE THREAT OF HIGH WINDS AND FLOODING RAINFALL OVER INLAND AREAS OF LAKE...ORANGE...SEMINOLE AND OSCEOLA COUNTIES APPEARS TO BE LESS THAN ORIGINALLY FORECAST. WINDS OF 20 TO 30 MPH WITH HIGHER GUSTS IN PASSING RAIN SQUALLS CAN BE EXPECTED ALONG WITH RAINFALL AMOUNTS OF 2 TO 3 INCHES.  ...NEXT UPDATE... THIS LOCATION WAS ABOUT 15 MILES SOUTHEAST OF FORT PIERCE. IRENE WAS MOVING NORTH NORTHEAST AT 10 MPH.  ...PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS... HURRICANE IRENE IS CURRENTLY A MINIMAL HURRICANE. THE MAXIMUM SUSTAINED WINDS WERE NEAR 75 MPH...WITH HIGHER GUSTS. THIS WAS MAINLY IN A SQUALLS WHICH WERE OUT OVER THE COASTAL WATERS. ALTHOUGH THE STRENGTH AND AREAL COVERAGE OF HURRICANE FORCE WINDS DECREASED WHILE THE CENTER OF IRENE WAS OVER LAND...THE CENTER IS NOW JUST OFFSHORE. AGAIN...A SLIGHT INCREASE IN STRENGTH IS POSSIBLE AS THE CENTER OF IRENE MOVES BACK OUT OVER THE WATER. ALSO...A FEW ISOLATED TORNADOES ARE POSSIBLE. THE THREAT FROM THESE HAZARDS WILL BE GREATEST ALONG THE COASTAL COUNTIES.  ...RAINFALL INFORMATION... AS THE CENTER OF IRENE MAKES NORTHWARDS PROGRESS...HEAVY RAIN WILL SPREAD INTO SOUTH VOLUSIA COUNTY...BUT WITH IMPROVING CONDITIONS FOR MARTIN COUNTY. NUMEROUS ROADS ARE COVERED WITH WATER IN VERO BEACH CAUSING CONSIDERABLE PROBLEMS. PEOPLE ARE URGED NOT TO VENTURE OUT THIS MORNING UNLESS ABSOLUTELY NECESSARY. ALSO...BE AWARE THAT ROADS WHICH ARE BETWEEN DRAINAGE DITCHES MAY BE DIFFICULT TO NAVIGATE AS SOME DITCHES HAVE FLOODED MAKING THESE ROADS HARD TO SEE. THE COASTAL COUNTIES FROM MARTIN...TO SAINT LUCIE...INDIAN RIVER... AND BREVARD WILL CONTINUE TO EXPERIENCE TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS... WITH HIGHER GUSTS OF 50 TO 60 MPH IN SQUALLS. SOME GUSTS MAY REACH AS HIGH 70 MPH...ESPECIALLY FOR BREVARD. THIS WILL RESULT IN DOWNED TREES AND SIGNS...DAMAGE TO AWNINGS AND POOL HOUSES...AND SOME POWER OUTAGES. RESIDENTS OF HIGH RISE BUILDINGS ALONG THE BEACH FRONT SHOULD ALSO EXPECT THESE STRONGER GUSTS. PEOPLE SHOULD NOT BE TOO QUICK TO GO OUTSIDE THIS MORNING. IT IS WISE TO LET THE HEAVY RAIN AND WIND SUBSIDE BEFORE VENTURING OUT. REMEMBER...THERE WILL BE SOME WIND DAMAGE AND DOWNED POWER LINES MAKING CONDITIONS VERY HAZARDOUS.  TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS WILL ALSO BE POSSIBLE FOR VOLUSIA AND FLAGLER COUNTIES...BUT WINDS WILL PICK UP THERE LATER THIS MORNING...AS THE RAIN BANDS MOVE IN. IF IRENE MOVES FARTHER OFFSHORE...WINDS WILL REACH ABOUT 40 MPH...BUT IF IRENE STAYS CLOSER TO THE COAST...WINDS OF 50 TO 55 MPH WILL BE POSSIBLE. THIS IS ABOUT 220 MILES  SOUTH SOUTHEAST OF MAYPORT FLORIDA. THE STORM WAS MOVING TOWARD THE  NORTH NORTHEAST NEAR 10 MPH AND A GRADUAL TURN TO A MORE NORTHERLY  MOTION IS EXPECTED TODAY.    TRACK INFORMATION...ALONG THE CURRENT FORECAST TRACK...IRENE IS  EXPECTED TO PASS APPROXIMATELY 120 MILES EAST OF MAYPORT BY  MIDNIGHT TONIGHT.  WIND INFORMATION...ON THE CURRENT FORECAST TRACK...THE HIGHEST WINDS  WILL AFFECT THE IMMEDIATE COASTAL AREAS AND ADJACENT ATLANTIC COASTAL  WATERS. SUSTAINED WINDS BETWEEN 35 AND 45 MPH WITH OCCASIONAL HIGHER  GUSTS ARE EXPECTED TO MOVE OVER THE COASTAL SECTIONS OF FLAGLER  COUNTY THIS MORNING...SPREAD NORTH TO NEAR FERNANDINA BEACH BY EARLY  THIS EVENING AND THEN MOVE NEAR BRUNSWICK BY VERY EARLY SUNDAY  MORNING. WEST OF THE ST. JOHNS RIVER FROM DOWNTOWN JACKSONVILLE  SOUTHWARD...AND WEST OF INTERSTATE 95 NORTH OF DOWNTOWN  JACKSONVILLE...SUSTAINED WINDS OF 20 TO 30 MPH WITH HIGHER GUSTS CAN  BE EXPECTED.  SUSTAINED WINDS OF 40 TO 50 KNOTS WITH HIGHER GUSTS ARE EXPECTED  OVER THE FLORIDA COASTAL WATERS THIS AFTERNOON...SUBSIDING TONIGHT. OVER THE GEORGIA COASTAL WATERS...30 TO 40 KNOT WINDS ARE  ANTICIPATED LATE TODAY...SUBSIDING LATE TONIGHT.   RAINFALL...RAINFALL WITH ASSOCIATED LOCALIZED FLOODING IS EXPECTED TO  BE ONE OF THE PRIMARY THREATS ASSOCIATED WITH IRENE. AS THE STORM  APPROACHES...ADDITIONAL RAINFALL AMOUNTS OF 3 TO 6 INCHES ARE  POSSIBLE IN THE FLOOD WATCH AREA WITH LOCALLY HIGHER AMOUNTS...  MAINLY ALONG THE COAST. RESIDENTS OF THE NORMALLY FLOOD-PRONE AREAS  AND THOSE AREAS WITH POOR DRAINAGE SHOULD BE PREPARED FOR THE  POSSIBILITY OF FLOODING.   STORM SURGE AND TIDES...A SIGNIFICANT STORM SURGE ASSOCIATED WITH  IRENE IS NOT EXPECTED. NORTHEAST WINDS ARE BLOWING ACROSS THE  COASTAL WATERS AND WILL GRADUALLY INCREASE AS THE STORM APPROACHES  THE REGION SATURDAY. TIDES OF 1 TO 3 FEET ABOVE NORMAL ON THE OPEN  OCEAN AND 1 TO 2 FEET ON THE ST. JOHNS RIVER AND THE ESTUARY SYSTEM  ARE POSSIBLE. REMEMBER...DRAINAGE IN A LARGE PORTION OF THE AREA IS  DEPENDENT ON THE TIDE LEVEL. DRAINAGE MAY BE INHIBITED AT THE TIME  OF HIGH TIDE AND...WITH HEAVY RAINFALL...THE NORMALLY FLOOD-PRONE  LOW-LYING AREAS MAY EXPERIENCE FLOODING CONDITIONS. THE NEXT  ATLANTIC COASTAL HIGH TIDE IS AROUND 2 PM TODAY.  SURF...THE SURF WILL CONTINUE TO INCREASE AND BREAKERS OF 6 TO 8  FEET ARE EXPECTED. THIS WILL MAINTAIN THE THREAT OF RIP CURRENTS OR  RUN OUTS THROUGH SUNDAY.  PREPAREDNESS RECOMMENDATIONS...RESIDENTS OF NORTH FLORIDA AND  SOUTHEASTERN GEORGIA ARE URGED TO CLOSELY MONITOR THE PROGRESS OF  IRENE. INTERESTS SHOULD MONITOR NOAA WEATHER RADIO...LOCAL MEDIA OR  CABLE TELEVISION FOR FURTHER INFORMATION...WATCHES OR WARNINGS.  COASTAL RESIDENTS SHOULD BRING OBJECTS THAT MAY BE BLOWN AROUND BY  GUSTY WINDS INDOORS. MOTORISTS TRAVERSING BRIDGES OR OVERPASSES IN  THE COASTAL COUNTIES SHOULD DRIVE WITH CAUTION DUE TO THE GUSTY  WINDS.  FOR ADDITIONAL INFORMATION...VISIT THE NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE JACKSONVILLE WEBSITE ON THE INTERNET AT HTTP://WWW.NWSJAX.NOAA.GOV.  THE NEXT HURRICANE LOCAL STATEMENT WILL BE ISSUED AROUND NOON OR  SOONER SHOULD CONDITIONS WARRANT. THIS DOES NOT INCLUDE GLYNN COUNTY IN SOUTHEAST GEORGIA AT THIS TIME...  ...A HURRICANE WATCH HAS BEEN ISSUED FROM BRUNSWICK GEORGIA NORTHWARD TO SAVANNAH GEORGIA INCLUDING GLYNN COUNTY...  ...SMALL CRAFT SHOULD REMAIN IN PORT...  ...THE HURRICANE WARNING HAS TAKEN THE PLACE OF THE HEAVY SURF ADVISORY AND ISSUES PERTAINING TO HEAVY SURF WILL NOW BE ADDRESSED IN HURRICANE LOCAL STATEMENTS...  THIS STATEMENT PERTAINS TO RESIDENTS IN THE FOLLOWING SOUTHEAST GEORGIA AND NORTHEAST FLORIDA COUNTIES...GLYNN...NASSAU...DUVAL... ST. JOHNS...FLAGLER...AND CAMDEN.  AT 5 PM EDT HURRICANE FLOYD WAS LOCATED NEAR LATITUDE 24.2 NORTH LONGITUDE 73.7 WEST OR APPROXIMATELY 610 MILES SOUTHEAST OF JACKSONVILLE BEACH. MAXIMUM SUSTAINED WINDS ARE NEAR 155 MPH AND THE MINIMUM CENTRAL PRESSURE IS 923 MB. FLOYD IS MOVING TOWARD THE WEST AT 16 MPH AND THIS MOVEMENT IS EXPECTED TO CONTINUE TONIGHT WITH A GRADUAL TURN TOWARDS THE NORTHWEST EXPECTED ON TUESDAY. ON ITS CURRENT FORECAST TRACK...THE CENTER OF THE STORM IS EXPECTED TO PASS WITHIN 100 MILES OFFSHORE OF THE NORTHEAST FLORIDA AND SOUTHEAST GEORGIA COASTS FROM EARLY WEDNESDAY MORNING THROUGH THE EARLY EVENING HOURS. THE EXACT EFFECT FELT IN THE WARNED AREA IS HIGHLY DEPENDANT UPON FLOYD'S ULTIMATE PATH AS IT MOVES ABREAST OF THE AREA.  ...WIND INFORMATION... FLOYD IS A POWERFUL AND LARGE HURRICANE. ALTHOUGH THE CENTER IS FORECAST TO REMAIN OFFSHORE...THE WIND FIELD IS LARGE ENOUGH TO HAVE A SIGNIFICANT IMPACT ON THE AREA. ON ITS CURRENT FORECAST TRACK... TROPICAL STORM WINDS WILL START TO REACH THE NORTHEAST FLORIDA COAST BEGINNING TUESDAY NIGHT AND THEN SPREAD NORTHWARD INTO SOUTHEAST GEORGIA DURING THE EARLY MORNING HOURS ON WEDNESDAY. THESE WINDS WILL CONTINUE TO AFFECT THE AREA THROUGH WEDNESDAY EVENING. WINDS WILL APPROACH HURRICANE FORCE...GREATER THAN 74 MPH...IN SQUALLS DURING THE DAY ON WEDNESDAY. AT THIS TIME THE STRONGEST WINDS ARE EXPECTED ON THE IMMEDIATE BEACHES...BUT GUSTY WINDS WILL SPREAD TO INLAND AREAS AS THE STORM PASSES ABREAST OF THE WARNED AREA.  ...TIDAL INFORMATION... DUE TO THE STRONG NORTHEASTERLY WINDS WHICH THE AREA HAS BEEN EXPERIENCING OVER THE PAST FEW DAYS...THE TIDES HAVE BEEN RUNNING AROUND 2 TO 2 1/2 FEET ABOVE NORMAL. THIS IS ABOUT THE LEVEL OF COASTAL FLOODING EXPERIENCED DURING A SPRING TIDE. THE TIDAL VALUES ALONG THE RIVERS...BAYS AND THE INTRACOASTAL WATERWAY WILL CONTINUE TO INCREASE EVEN BEFORE THE HURRICANE APPROACHES THE REGION AND THIS COULD CAUSE MINOR TIDAL FLOODING ALONG COASTAL ROADWAYS AT THE TIME OF HIGH TIDE. THE TIMES OF HIGH TIDE ALONG THE OCEAN-FRONT THROUGH WILL BE BETWEEN NOON AND 1PM AND BETWEEN MIDNIGHT AND 1 AM...WITH A ONE TO THREE HOUR DELAY ALONG THE RIVERS AND INTRACOASTAL WATERWAY.  THESE CONDITIONS WILL DETERIORATE RAPIDLY TUESDAY AND TUESDAY NIGHT AS SWELLS ASSOCIATED WITH THE HURRICANE INCREASE IN HEIGHT ON TUESDAY. IT IS POSSIBLE THAT SOME LOW LYING EVACUATION ROUTES COULD BE FLOODED AT THE TIME OF HIGH TIDE.  ...HEAVY SURF... FLOYD REPRESENTS A VERY DANGEROUS THREAT DUE TO THE WAVE ACTION WHICH IT WILL GENERATE. DEPENDING UPON THE STORMS TRACK...IT IS POSSIBLE THAT DAMAGING SURF WILL REACH INTO OR BEYOND THE DUNE LINES AND SEA WALLS BEGINNING TUESDAY NIGHT IN NORTHEAST FLORIDA AND ON WEDNESDAY MORNING IN SOUTHEAST GEORGIA. WITH THE HURRICANE'S PROJECTED PATH... MAJOR BEACH EROSION AND LIFE THREATENING SURF CONDITIONS ARE LIKELY. BOATS AND OTHER OBJECTS ON THE BEACHES...DUNE LINES AND OCEAN-FRONT AREAS SHOULD BE SECURED AS SOON AS POSSIBLE.  INLETS AND PASSES WILL BECOME DANGEROUS DUE TO LARGE BREAKERS AND SMALL CRAFT SHOULD REMAIN IN PORT.  ...EVACUATIONS... GLYNN COUNTY...AS OF 6 PM EDT...A VOLUNTARY EVACUATION ORDER HAS BEEN ISSUED FOR ZONE ONE. THIS INCLUDES THE AREAS OF THE COUNTY EAST OF US HIGHWAY 17...BLYTHE ISLAND...THE CITY OF BRUNSWICK SOUTH OF GLOUCESTER STREET AND ALL BARRIER ISLANDS.  ...SHELTER INFORMATION... FLAGLER COUNTY...AS OF 6 PM EDT...THE COUNTY HAS OPENED THE FOLLOWING SHELTERS FOR THOSE DESIRING SHELTER OVERNIGHT...BUNNELL ELEMENTARY SCHOOL. THE FOLLOWING COUNTIES HAVE CLOSED SCHOOLS FOR BOTH TUESDAY AND WEDNESDAY...NASSAU...DUVAL...ST. JOHNS...FLAGLER...CLAY...PUTNAM AND ALACHUA.  SANTE FE COMMUNITY COLLEGE EVENING CLASSES ARE CLOSED TOMORROW.  ...RECOMMENDATIONS... OBJECTS WHICH MAY BE BLOWN AROUND BY THE HIGH WINDS SHOULD BE SECURED. RESIDENTS IN HIGH PROFILE BUILDINGS SUCH AS CONDOMINIUMS SHOULD SECURE OBJECTS ON BALCONIES.  RESIDENTS OF THE HURRICANE WARNING AND WATCH AREA SHOULD ASSEMBLE A DISASTER KIT AT THIS TIME...A WELL STOCKED KIT WILL CONSIST OF THE FOLLOWING ITEMS...A FIRST AID KIT INCLUDING SPECIALIZED MEDICATIONS...CANNED FOOD FOR AT LEAST ONE WEEK WITH A NON ELECTRIC CAN OPENER...THREE GALLONS OF WATER PER PERSON PER DAY...BATTERY OPERATED RADIOS...FLASHLIGHTS AND EXTRA BATTERIES...SPECIALIZED ITEMS FOR THE ELDERLY...INFANTS AND CHILDREN. IDENTIFY AHEAD OF TIME WHERE YOU WILL GO. IF AN EVACUATION ORDER IS GIVEN FOR YOUR AREA...LISTEN CAREFULLY TO THE ADVICE OF LOCAL OFFICIALS. COUNTY SHELTERS WILL BE OPEN...BUT YOU SHOULD USE THEM ONLY AS A LAST OPTION. IF YOU USE A SHELTER...BRING PERSONAL ITEMS FOR ALL FAMILY MEMBERS. LEAVE FOOD AND WATER FOR YOUR PETS AT HOME...THEY ARE NOT ALLOWED IN SHELTERS.  ONLY STAY AT HOME IF YOU ARE NOT IN AN EVACUATION ZONE...FLOOD ZONE...OR MOBILE HOME. IF YOU DO REMAIN AT HOME...STORE WATER IN BOTTLES AND BATHTUBS. TURN YOUR REFRIGERATOR TO HIGH AND TURN OFF PROPANE TANKS. BREEZY CONDITIONS WITH WINDS FROM THE NORTHEAST TO 15 MPH ARE EXPECTED TODAY WITH GUSTY WINDS ALONG THE COAST. WINDS WILL GRADUALLY INCREASE TONIGHT WITH TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS SPREADING NORTH MIDDAY THROUGH THE EVENING ON TUESDAY.  ...MARINE INFORMATION... SEAS HAVE BEGUN TO BUILD TO NEAR 8 FEET IN THE COASTAL WATERS. SMALL CRAFT SHOULD REMAIN IN PORT. CONDITIONS WILL SLOWLY DETEORATE OVER THE NEXT 24 HOURS. EXPECT A GREATER THAN NORMAL CHANCE OF RIP CURRENTS TODAY.   THE TRACK OF HURRICANE FLOYD IS UNCERTAIN. ANYONE IN THE HURRICANE WATCH AREA COULD POSSIBLY RECEIVE HURRICANE FORCE WINDS BY LATE TUESDAY. IF YOU LIVE IN A MOBILE HOME OR ON A BARRIER ISLAND...BE PREPARED TO LEAVE IF A WARNING IS ISSUED. IDENTIFY AHEAD OF TIME WHERE YOU COULD GO IF YOU ARE TOLD TO EVACUATE. IF AN EVACUATION ORDER IS GIVEN...LISTEN CAREFULLY TO THE ADVICE OF LOCAL OFFICIALS. HAVE CLOTHES...IMPORTANT PAPERS...MEDICINES...AND SMALL VALUABLES GATHERED AND READY TO TAKE WITH YOU.  CONSIDER DEPLOYING STORM SHUTTERS OR INSTALLING PRE-CUT PLYWOOD ON YOUR WINDOWS. REMOVE ANY DISEASED OR DAMAGED TREE LIMBS WHICH COULD POSE A HAZARD. SECURE PATIO FURNITURE AND ANY OTHER LOOSE OBJECTS... OR MOVE THEM INDOORS.  FILL YOUR VEHICLES WITH GAS AND MAKE SURE YOU HAVE EXTRA CASH ON HAND SINCE POWER MAY NOT BE RESTORED FOR SOME TIME. CHECK YOUR SUPPLIES OF BATTERIES...CANNED FOODS...DRINKING WATER...AND MEDICATION.  CONTINUE TO TRACK THE PROGRESS OF THE HURRICANE AND BE READY TO TAKE FURTHER ACTIONS IF A HURRICANE WARNING BECOMES NECESSARY.  ...NEXT UPDATE... THE NEXT HURRICANE LOCAL STATEMENT WILL BE ISSUED ABOUT 1 PM OR SOONER IF CONDITIONS WARRANT. SHORT RANGE FORECASTS ISSUED HOURLY BY NWS MELBOURNE WILL CONTAIN THE LATEST RADAR INFORMATION AND EXPECTED EFFECTS FROM HURRICANE FLOYD WHEN IT APPROACHES THE COAST. THIS STATEMENT APPLIES TO PEOPLE IN MIAMI-DADE...BROWARD...PALM  BEACH...COUNTIES OF SOUTH FLORIDA CONCERNING HURRICANE FLOYD.  ...WATCH/WARNING... HURRICANE WATCH IS IN EFFECT FOR BROWARD AND PALM BEACH COUNTIES.  ...CENTER LOCATION/MOVEMENT/INTENSITY AND TREND... AT 600 AM EDT HURRICANE FLOYD WAS LOCATED ABOUT 600 MILES EAST  SOUTHEAST OF WEST PALM BEACH.  FLOYD WAS MOVING WEST AT 14 MPH AND  IS EXPECTED TO CONTINUING MOVING THIS DIRECTION AND SPEED TODAY WITH  A GRADUAL TURN TO THE WEST-NORTHWEST TONIGHT.  THE HIGHEST WINDS ARE  155 MPH AND SOME FLUCTUATIONS IN STRENGTH ARE EXPECTED OVER THE NEXT  DAY.  IT IS A STRONG CATEGORY FOUR STORM.  THE PROBABILITY OF THE  HURRICANE CENTER PASSING WITHIN 75 MILES OF WEST PALM BEACH WAS 21  PERCENT AND FOR MIAMI IT WAS 18 PERCENT.  ALTHOUGH THE FORECAST  TRACK IS EXPECTED TO KEEP THE CENTER OFFSHORE...THE FORECAST  UNCERTAINTY IS ENOUGH THAT RESIDENTS IN THE HURRICANE WATCH AREA  SHOULD BE PREPARED IN CASE LATER INFORMATION REQUIRES WARNINGS OR  WATCHES TO BE EXTENDED FURTHER SOUTH.  ...WIND INFORMATION... TODAY FLOYD WILL BASICALLY HAVE LITTLE EFFECT OVER SOUTHEAST  FLORIDA.  THE WINDS WILL BE MOSTLY NORTHEAST AT 15 TO 20 MPH AND  THEN SLOWLY SHIFT TO NORTHERLY TONIGHT.  TUESDAY NORTHERLY WINDS  WILL CONTINUE TO SLOWLY INCREASE AND BY THE AFTERNOON OUTSIDE OF THE  SHOWERS THE WINDSPEEDS SHOULD BE AROUND 25 TO 30 MPH.  WITH THE  SHOWERS WIND GUSTS WOULD PROBABLY BE AROUND 40 TO 45 MPH.  LATE  TUESDAY AFTERNOON AND THROUGH THE NIGHT THE WIND WILL CONTINUE TO  INCREASE AND SHIFT TO THE NORTHWEST.  WINDSPEEDS OUTSIDE OF THE  SHOWERS WILL RANGE FROM 30 TO 40 MPH WITH GUSTS TO 50 TO 60 MPH WITH  THE SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS.  ...RAINFALL/FLOODING... NO SIGNIFICANT AMOUNTS OF RAINFALL ARE EXPECTED UNTIL TUESDAY  AFTERNOON.  THE HEAVY RAINS COULD BRING AMOUNTS OF 3 TO 5 INCHES BY  LATE TUESDAY NIGHT.  THIS COULD CAUSE SOME LOCAL URBAN FLOODING  MAINLY OF STREETS.  PREPAREDNESS ACTIVITIES...  ...PROTECTIVE ACTIONS... THOSE PEOPLE WHO NEED EXTRA TIME TO COMPLETE ANY OUTSIDE PREPARATION  ACTIVITIES SUCH BEGIN DOING SO TODAY.  THIS WOULD INCLUDE THE  PROTECTION OF BOATS...REMOVING OUTSIDE DEBRIS...AND SO FORTH.  ON  TUESDAY ALL OUTSIDE ACTIVITIES SHOULD HAVE BEEN COMPLETED BY MIDDAY. WWUS31 KMLB 160712 HLSMLB AMZ550-555-570-575-FLZ041-044>047-053-054-058-059-064-161000-  HURRICANE IRENE LOCAL STATEMENT NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MELBOURNE FL 305 AM EDT SAT OCT 16 1999  ...THE CIRCULATION CENTER OF HURRICANE IRENE MOVING NORTH NORTHEAST ALONG COASTAL MARTIN COUNTY TOWARDS SAINT LUCIE COUNTY...  ...TROPICAL STORM WARNING IN EFFECT FROM FLORIDA CITY NORTHWARD TO FERNANDINA BEACH ON THE FLORIDA EAST COAST AND FOR LAKE OKEECHOBEE... WHICH INCLUDES THE ENTIRE COAST OF EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA...  ...FLOOD WATCH FOR ALL OF EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA THROUGH SATURDAY...  ...HIGH WIND WARNING FOR OKEECHOBEE...OSCEOLA...LAKE...ORANGE AND SEMINOLE COUNTIES FOR THE REMAINDER OF TONIGHT...   ...AREAS AFFECTED... THIS STATEMENT RECOMMENDS ACTIONS TO BE TAKEN BY RESIDENTS OF MARTIN... SAINT LUCIE... OKEECHOBEE... INDIAN RIVER... BREVARD... OSCEOLA... ORANGE... LAKE... SEMINOLE... FLAGLER... AND VOLUSIA COUNTIES OF EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA.  ...STORM INFORMATION... AT 2 AM EDT...THE CENTER OF HURRICANE IRENE WAS LOCATED NEAR LATITUDE 27.0 NORTH...LONGITUDE 80.2 WEST. THIS LOCATION WAS NEAR JUPITER INLET FLORIDA.  AT 3 AM...WEATHER RADAR LOCATED THE CIRCULATION CENTER JUST INLAND OF HOBE SOUND IN MARTIN COUNTY.  ...PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS... HURRICANE IRENE IS CURRENTLY A MINIMAL HURRICANE. THE MAXIMUM SUSTAINED WINDS WERE NEAR 75 MPH...WITH HIGHER GUSTS. THIS WAS MAINLY IN A FEW SQUALLS WHICH WERE OUT OVER THE COASTAL WATERS. ALTHOUGH THE STRENGTH AND AREAL COVERAGE OF HURRICANE FORCE WINDS HAS DECREASED...THE CENTER OF IRENE WILL SOON BE JUST OFFSHORE. IRENE WILL BE CLOSELY EXAMINED FOR ANY SIGNS OF SLIGHT STRENGTHENING AND ORGANIZATION...OR AN INCREASE IN CONVECTION.  ...WIND AND RAINFALL INFORMATION... THE COASTAL COUNTIES FROM MARTIN...TO SAINT LUCIE...INDIAN RIVER... AND BREVARD WILL EXPERIENCE TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS...WITH HIGHER GUSTS OF 50 TO 60 MPH IN SQUALLS THROUGH 5AM. THIS WILL RESULT IS SOME DOWNED TREES...DAMAGE TO AWNINGS AND POOL HOUSES...AND SOME POWER OUTAGES. RESIDENTS OF HIGH RISE BUILDINGS ALONG THE BEACH FRONT SHOULD ALSO EXPECT THESE STRONGER GUSTS.  SUSTAINED WINDS WILL GENERALLY BE LESS THAN TROPICAL STORM FORCE OVER INLAND COUNTIES...BUT MAY EXPERIENCE OCCASIONAL TO FREQUENT GUSTS TO 45 MPH IN SQUALLS. THE STRONGEST WINDS WILL OCCUR ALONG THE IMMEDIATE COAST AND BEACHES IN PROXIMITY OF THE CIRCULATION CENTER AND WITHIN THE INNER BAND SQUALLS.  THE FORECAST CONDITIONS FOR VOLUSIA AND FLAGLER COUNTIES WILL DEPEND ON THE EXACT TRACK OR IRENE...WHETHER IRENE WILL MOVE OFFSHORE OR STAY NEAR THE COASTLINE. HEAVY RAIN AND TROPICAL STORM FORCE WIND GUSTS WILL MOVE INTO THESE COUNTIES BY 5AM.  ALTHOUGH SOME WIND DAMAGE IS LIKELY...THE MAIN HAZARD WITH IRENE IS STILL THE POTENTIAL FOR FLOODING RAINS. URBAN FLOOD ADVISORIES HAVE BEEN ISSUED FOR SAINT LUCIE...INDIAN RIVER...AND BREVARD COUNTIES. MARTIN COUNTY IS UNDER A FLOOD WARNING UNTIL 510 AM. HEAVY RAINS SHOULD BEGIN TO MOVE OUT OF MARTIN COUNTY BY THAT TIME. AGAIN...THE GREATEST FLOOD THREAT WILL BE FOR THE COASTAL COUNTIES. AN ADDITIONAL 4 TO 6 INCHES OF RAIN IS POSSIBLE AS RAIN CONTINUES TO FALL AT THE RATE OF ONE TO ONE AND A HALF INCHES PER HOUR.  RESIDENTS OF LOW LYING AND FLOOD PRONE AREAS SHOULD REMAIN ALERT FOR THE ISSUANCE OF FLOOD WARNINGS AND BE PREPARED TO TAKE ACTION TO PROTECT LIFE AND PROPERTY.  ...CURRENT RADAR/SEVERE WEATHER THREAT... AT 3 AM...HEAVY RAIN AND GUSTY WINDS WITHIN SQUALLS WERE MOVING FROM THE OFFSHORE WATERS...ACROSS SOUTHERN BREVARD...INDIAN RIVER... AND SAINT LUCIE COUNTIES FROM MELBOURNE TO STUART...REACHING INLAND TO LAKE OKEECHOBEE. AS IRENE MOVES NORTH NORTHEAST AT 13 MPH...THIS HEAVY RAIN AND GUSTY WIND WILL PUSH FARTHER NORTHWARD TOWARDS CAPE CANAVERAL...AND APPROACH SOUTH VOLUSIA COUNTY.  ...STORM SURGE AND STORM TIDE INFORMATION... SIGNIFICANT STORM SURGE IS NOT EXPECTED ALONG THE COAST...HOWEVER... SUSTAINED ONSHORE WINDS OF TROPICAL STORM FORCE WILL PRODUCE EXTREMELY ROUGH SURF...RIP CURRENTS...ADDITIONAL BEACH EROSION...AND POSSIBLY SOME MINOR COASTAL FLOODING...ESPECIALLY AROUND THE TIME OF HIGH TIDE. HIGH TIDES ALONG THE EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA COAST FROM DAYTONA BEACH TO FORT PIERCE WILL BE JUST AFTER 1PM SATURDAY AFTERNOON.  ...NEXT UPDATE... THE NEXT HURRICANE LOCAL STATEMENT WILL BE ISSUED AROUND 6 AM OR SOONER IF CONDITIONS WARRANT. TROPICAL STORM WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM FLORIDA CITY TO  JUPITER INLET..INCLUDING LAKE OKEECHOBEE.  THIS INCLUDES MOST OF  MIAMI-DADE AND ALL OF BROWARD AND PALM BEACH COUNTIES.  THE  HURRICANE WARNING FOR MAINLAND MONROE AND COLLIER COUNTY HAS BEEN  DISCONTINUED.   AN INLAND HIGH WIND WARNING CONTINUES IN EFFECT FOR GLADES AND  HENDRY COUNTIES THROUGH TONIGHT.  ...CENTER LOCATION MOVEMENT INTENSITY AND TREND... AT 2 AM EDT THE CENTER OF HURRICANE IRENE WAS LOCATED NEAR 27.0N  80.2W.  THIS POSITION WAS NEAR JUPITER IN EXTREME NORTHEAST PALM  BEACH COUNTY. IRENE IS MOVING NORTH-NORTHEAST AT 13 MPH.  THIS  GENERAL MOTION IS EXPECTED TO CONTINUE THROUGH TONIGHT.  MAXIMUM SUSTAINED WINDS ARE NEAR 75 MPH WITH HIGHER GUSTS OVER THE  WATERS OFF THE FLORIDA COAST. MINIMUM CENTRAL PRESSURE IS 989 MB OR  29.21 INCHES.  ...RAINFALL AND FLOODING WIDESPREAD STORM RAINFALL TOTALS OF 8 TO 12 INCHES HAVE OCCURRED  ACROSS SOUTHEAST FLORIDA.  THE MAXIMUM RAINFALL TOTAL ESTIMATED BY  RADAR IS MORE THAN 18 INCHES AT OCEAN RIDGE IN PALM BEACH COUNTY.   THE HEAVY RAINS THAT WERE OVER PALM BEACH COUNTY EARLY HAVE NOW  MOVED NORTH EAST OF THE AREA.  HOWEVER...LIGHT TO MODERATE RAIN IS  EXPECTED OVER THE NORTHERN HALF OF PALM BEACH COUNTY THROUGH 5 AM  EDT.  WIDESPREAD FLOODING IS OCCURRING ACROSS MOST OF SOUTHEAST FLORIDA  AND ONLY SLOW IMPROVEMENT IS EXPECTED TODAY.   MOTORISTS ARE URGED TO USE EXTREME CAUTION. STANDING WATER ON  ROADWAYS CAN CAUSE MOTORISTS TO DRIVE INTO CANALS OR OTHER DEEP  WATER.  THE WINDS FROM IRENE HAVE KNOCKED DOWN POWER LINES IN MANY  LOCATIONS.  COMBINED WITH STANDING WATER...DOWNED POWER LINES CAN BE  DEADLY. IN BROWARD COUNTY...5 DEATHS OCCURRED DUE TO DOWNED POWER  LINES.  ...EVACUATION/SHELTERING... SHELTERS REMAIN OPEN IN THE TRI-COUNTY AREA.  ...PROTECTIVE ACTIONS... PERSONS ARE URGED TO REMAIN INDOORS TONIGHT. TREES AND POWER LINES  THAT HAVE BEEN BLOWN DOWN COMBINED WITH FLOODED ROADWAYS IS MAKING  DRIVING HAZARDOUS. THIS POSITION IS ABOUT  25 MILES SOUTHWEST OF WEST PALM BEACH FLORIDA.  ...PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS... HURRICANE IRENE IS INLAND OVER PALM BEACH COUNTY AND IS FORECAST TO  MOVE OFFSHORE IN THE VICINITY OF STUART. IT IS FORECAST TO PASS  ABOUT 30 MILES EAST OF CAPE CANAVERAL BY EARLY AFTERNOON SATURDAY.  THIS REPRESENTS A LARGE SHIFT IN THE FORECAST TRACK TO THE EAST. THE  GREATEST DANGER FROM HURRICANE IRENE WILL BE IN THE RAIN BANDS ALONG  THE NORTH AND EAST EDGE OF THE CIRCULATION CENTER. RESIDENTS OF  MARTIN... SAINT LUCIE ... OKEECHOBEE... INDIAN RIVER AND BREVARD  SHOULD BE ESPECIALLY ALERT AND PREPARE FOR FLOODING DUE TO  TORRENTIAL RAINFALL AND TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS.  RESIDENTS OF  LOW LYING AND FLOOD PRONE AREAS SHOULD REMAIN ALERT FOR THE ISSUANCE  OF FLOOD WARNINGS AND BE PREPARED TO TAKE ACTION TO PROTECT LIFE AND  PROPERTY.   ...CURRENT RADAR/SEVERE WEATHER THREAT... AT 11 PM... STRONG RAIN BANDS NORTH OF THE CENTER OF IRENE WERE  MOVING ONSHORE IN NORTHERN PALM BEACH COUNTY AND MARTIN AND SAINT  LUCIE COUNTIES. SOME LOCAL FLOODING HAS BEEN REPORTED IN MARTIN  COUNTY ALONG WITH MINOR ROOF DAMAGE. AS THE RAIN BANDS MOVE NORTH  TORRENTIAL TROPICAL RAINS... ALONG WITH WINDS GUSTING TO NEAR 50 MPH  WILL SWEEP NORTH ACROSS MARTIN... SAINT LUCIE AND INDIAN RIVER  COUNTIES. THE STRONGEST WINDS AND GREATEST THREAT FOR WIND DAMAGE  WILL BE ALONG THE IMMEDIATE COAST.  EAST AND THEN NORTH WINDS WILL  BUILD ALONG THE COAST NORTH OF STUART PRODUCING CONSIDERABLE BEACH  EROSION.    A FLOOD WARNING IS IN EFFECT FOR MARTIN COUNTY THROUGH EARLY  SATURDAY MORNING.  BRIEF...ISOLATED TORNADOES ARE POSSIBLE IN OUTER  RAINBANDS THROUGH THE NIGHT. THESE TYPE OF TORNADOES OFTEN SPIN UP  QUICKLY AS STRONG RAINBAND CONVECTION MOVES ONSHORE. TORNADO WARNINGS MAY BE ISSUED LATER TONIGHT.  ...WIND AND RAINFALL INFORMATION... BASED ON THE CURRENT FORECAST TRACK SUSTAINED TROPICAL STORM FORCE  WINDS SHOULD SPREAD FROM MARTIN AND SAINT LUCIE COUNTIES TO INDIAN  RIVER... OKEECHOBEE AND BREVARD COUNTIES BY EARLY MORNING AND FROM NORTH  BREVARD COUNTY TO VOLUSIA COUNTY DURING THE DAY ON SATURDAY. WINDS  GUSTING TO TROPICAL STORM FORCE COULD OCCUR ON SATURDAY IN ORANGE...  SEMINOLE AND OSCEOLA COUNTIES. PEAK WIND GUSTS DURING IRENE ALONG  THE COASTS ARE EXPECTED TO BE IN THE 50 TO 60 MPH RANGE WHICH WILL  NOT CAUSE WIDESPREAD DAMAGE...BUT WILL DOWN SOME TREES AND CAUSE  EXTENSIVE POWER OUTAGES. RESIDENTS OF HIGH RISE BUILDINGS ALONG THE  BEACH FRONT SHOULD EXPECT STRONGER GUSTS.  ...STORM SURGE AND STORM TIDE INFORMATION... SIGNIFICANT STORM SURGE IS NOT EXPECTED ALONG THE COAST...HOWEVER... SUSTAINED ONSHORE WINDS OF TROPICAL STORM FORCE WILL PRODUCE  EXTREMELY ROUGH SURF...RIP CURRENTS...ADDITIONAL BEACH EROSION...AND  POSSIBLY SOME MINOR COASTAL FLOODING...ESPECIALLY AROUND THE TIME OF  HIGH TIDE. AT 11 PM EDT THE CENTER OF HURRICANE IRENE WAS LOCATED NEAR 26.4N  80.4W.  THIS POSITION IS OVER THE EXTREME SOUTH-CENTRAL PALM BEACH  COUNTY ABOUT 25 MILES SOUTHWEST OF WEST PALM BEACH. THE MAXIMUM RAINFALL TOTAL ESTIMATED BY  RADAR IS 18 INCHES AT OCEAN RIDGE IN PALM BEACH COUNTY.  RAIN  CONTINUES TO FALL AT OCEAN RIDGE AT 11 PM.  ADDITIONAL RAINFALL  AMOUNTS OF 2 TO 4 INCHES ARE POSSIBLE OVER PALM BEACH COUNTY  TONIGHT.  THE REST OF SOUTH FLORIDA SHOULD SEE ADDITIONAL RAINFALL  AMOUNTS OF AROUND AN INCH OR LESS.  WIDESPREAD FLOODING IS OCCURRING ACROSS SOUTHEAST FLORIDA. FLOODING  WILL PERSIST FOR SEVERAL HOURS AFTER THE HEAVY RAINS END.  MOTORISTS ARE URGED TO USE EXTREME CAUTION. STANDING WATER ON  ROADWAYS CAN CAUSE MOTORISTS TO DRIVE INTO CANALS OR OTHER DEEP  WATER.  THE WINDS FROM IRENE HAVE KNOCKED DOWN POWER LINES IN MANY  LOCATIONS.  COMBINED WITH STANDING WATER...DOWNED POWER LINES CAN BE  DEADLY.    ...STORM SURGE/TIDE/OTHER MARINE HAZARDS A STORM SURGE OF 2 TO 4 FEET IS STILL POSSIBLE...MAINLY OVER PALM  BEACH COUNTY TONIGHT.  HIGH TIDES AT THE PALM BEACH INLET WILL BE AT  1:02 AM SATURDAY MORNING.  ROUGH SURF CONDITIONS CAN BE EXPECTED ALONG BOTH SOUTHEAST AND  SOUTHWEST COAST AND SMALL BOATERS ARE URGED TO REMAIN IN PORT. RIP  CURRENTS ARE POSSIBLE ALONG THE BEACHES OF SOUTHEAST FLORIDA.  ...TORNADOES THERE IS STILL A THREAT OF TORNADOES AND WATERSPOUTS. THE GREATEST  THREAT OF TORNADOES WILL BE OVER PALM BEACH COUNTY TONIGHT.  ...EVACUATION/SHELTERING... FOUR SHELTERS REMAIN OPEN IN PALM BEACH COUNTY WITH PLANS TO OPEN A  FIFTH SHELTER.  ...PROTECTIVE ACTIONS... PERSONS ARE URGED TO REMAIN INDOORS TONIGHT. TRACK INFORMATION...ALONG THE CURRENT FORECASTED TRACK IRENE IS  EXPECTED TO MOVE ACROSS SOUTHERN FLORIDA TONIGHT AND SHOULD EMERGE  INTO THE ATLANTIC AROUND VERO BEACH EARLY SATURDAY MORNING. IT IS  NOW FORECAST TO PASS APPROXIMATELY 100 MILES EAST OF MAYPORT  SATURDAY EVENING.   WIND INFORMATION...ON THE CURRENT FORECAST TRACK...THE HIGHEST WINDS  WILL BE ALONG THE IMMEDIATE COAST AND ADJACENT ATLANTIC COASTAL  WATERS. SUSTAINED WINDS BETWEEN 35 AND 45 MPH WITH OCCASIONAL HIGHER  GUSTS ARE EXPECTED TO MOVE OVER THE IMMEDIATE COASTAL SECTIONS OF  FLAGLER COUNTY SATURDAY MORNING AND SPREAD NORTH TO NEAR FERNANDINA  BEACH BY EARLY EVENING.   OFFSHORE...SUSTAINED WINDS OF 40 TO 50 MPH WITH HIGHER GUSTS ARE EXPECTED OVER THE COASTAL WATERS BEGINNING SATURDAY AFTERNOON AND  CONTINUING INTO SATURDAY NIGHT.   INLAND...WEST OF THE ST. JOHNS RIVER FROM DOWNTOWN JACKSONVILLE  SOUTHWARD...AND WEST OF INTERSTATE 95 NORTH OF DOWNTOWN  JACKSONVILLE...SUSTAINED WINDS OF 20 TO 30 MPH WITH HIGHER GUSTS CAN  BE EXPECTED.  RAINFALL...RAINFALL AND ASSOCIATED LOCALIZED FLOODING IS EXPECTED TO  BE ONE OF THE PRIMARY THREATS ASSOCIATED WITH IRENE. IT MUST BE REMEMBERED THAT THE DRAINAGE IN  LARGE PORTION OF THE AREA IS DEPENDENT ON THE TIDE LEVEL. HURRICANE IRENE...AT 5PM EDT THE CENTER OF HURRICANE IRENE WAS  LOCATED NEAR LATITUDE 25.6 NORTH...LONGITUDE 81.0 WEST OR  APPROXIMATELY 330 MILES SOUTH SOUTHWEST OF JACKSONVILLE. THE STORM  WAS MOVING TOWARD THE NORTH NORTHEAST NEAR 12 MPH. A GRADUAL TURN TO  THE NORTH IS EXPECTED OVER THE NEXT 24 HOURS.   TRACK INFORMATION...ALONG THE FORECASTED TRACK IRENE IS EXPECTED TO MOVE ACROSS SOUTHERN AND CENTRAL FLORIDA THROUGH SATURDAY  AFTERNOON AND SHOULD EMERGE INTO THE ATLANTIC BETWEEN DAYTONA BEACH  AND ST. AUGUSTINE ON SATURDAY EVENING.    WIND INFORMATION...ON THE CURRENT FORECAST TRACK...THE HIGHEST WINDS  WILL BE ALONG THE IMMEDIATE COAST AND ADJACENT ATLANTIC COASTAL  WATERS. SUSTAINED WINDS BETWEEN 40 AND 45 MPH WITH OCCASIONAL HIGHER  GUSTS ARE EXPECTED TO MOVE OVER THE IMMEDIATE COASTAL SECTIONS OF  FLAGLER BEACH SATURDAY MORNING AND SPREAD NORTH TO NEAR THE  FLORIDA-GEORGIA BORDER BY EARLY EVENING.   OFFSHORE...SUSTAINED WINDS OF 40 TO 50 MPH WITH HIGHER GUSTS ARE EXPECTED OVER THE COASTAL WATERS BEGINNING SATURDAY AFTERNOON AND CONTINUING THROUGH SUNDAY MORNING.  INLAND...WEST OF THE ST. JOHNS RIVER FROM DOWNTOWN JACKSONVILLE  SOUTHWARD...AND WEST OF INTERSTATE 95 NORTH OF DOWNTOWN  JACKSONVILLE...SUSTAINED WINDS OF 25 TO 30 MPH WITH HIGHER GUSTS CAN  BE EXPECTED.  RAINFALL...RAINFALL AND ASSOCIATED LOCALIZED FLOODING IS EXPECTED TO  BE ONE OF THE PRIMARY THREATS ASSOCIATED WITH IRENE. AS THE STORM  APPROACHES GENERAL RAINFALL AMOUNTS OF 3 TO 6 INCHES ARE ANTICIPATED  WITH LOCALLY HIGHER AMOUNTS POSSIBLE. RESIDENTS OF THE NORMALLY  FLOOD PRONE AREAS AND THOSE AREAS WITH POOR DRAINAGE SHOULD BE  PREPARED FOR THE POSSIBILITY OF FLOODING.   STORM SURGE AND TIDES...A SIGNIFICANT STORM SURGE IS NOT EXPECTED  ALONG THE COAST. EAST TO NORTHEAST WINDS ARE ALREADY BLOWING ACROSS  THE COASTAL WATERS AND WILL GRADUALLY INCREASE AS THE STORM  APPROACHES THE REGION. TIDES OF 1 TO 3 FEET ABOVE NORMAL ON THE OPEN  OCEAN AND 1 TO 2 FEET ON THE ST. JOHNS RIVER AND THE ESTUARY SYSTEM  ARE POSSIBLE. IT MUST BE REMEMBERED THAT THE DRAINAGE IN LARGE  PORTION OF THE AREA IS DEPENDENT ON THE TIDE LEVEL. IT IS POSSIBLE  THAT DRAINAGE MAY BE INHIBITED AT THE TIME OF HIGH TIDE AND WITH  HEAVY RAINFALL THE NORMALLY FLOOD PRONE LOW LYING AREAS MAY  EXPERIENCE FLOODING CONDITIONS.  SURF...WILL CONTINUE TO INCREASE AND BREAKERS OF 6 TO 8 FEET ARE EXPECTED. THIS WILL MAINTAIN THE THREAT OF RIP CURRENTS OR RUN OUTS THROUGH SUNDAY.   ...PREPAREDNESS RECOMMENDATONS... RESIDENTS OF NORTH FLORIDA AND SOUTHEASTERN GEORGIA ARE URGED TO  CLOSELY MONITOR THE PROGRESS OF IRENE.    INTERESTS IN NORTH FLORIDA AND SOUTHEAST GEORGIA SHOULD MONITOR  LOCAL MEDIA...CABLE TELEVISION OR NOAA WEATHER RADIO OF FURTHER  INFORMATION...WATCHES OR POSSIBLE WARNINGS. IRENE IS MOVING TOWARD THE NORTH NORTHEAST NEAR 12 MPH. A GRADUAL TURN TO THE NORTH IS EXPECTED OVER THE NEXT 24 HOURS. MAXIMUM SUSTAINED WINDS ARE NEAR  85 MPH...WITH HIGHER GUSTS.  ...PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS... HURRICANE IRENE IS INLAND OVER SOUTH FLORIDA AND IS FORECAST TO MOVE ACROSS EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA THROUGH SATURDAY. RESIDENTS OF EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA SHOULD PREPARE FOR FLOODING RAINFALL AND TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS FROM IRENE. RESIDENTS OF LOW LYING AND FLOOD PRONE AREAS SHOULD REMAIN ALERT FOR THE ISSUANCE OF FLOOD WARNINGS AND BE PREPARED TO TAKE ACTION TO PROTECT LIFE AND PROPERTY. ALSO...LOOSE OBJECTS THAT CAN BE BLOWN ABOUT BY THE WIND SHOULD BE SECURED OR BROUGHT INSIDE BEFORE DARK.  ...CURRENT RADAR/SEVERE WEATHER THREAT... AT 515PM...THE MAIN RAINBANDS ASSOCIATED WITH IRENE WERE OVER BROWARD COUNTY AND OFFSHORE PALM BEACH COUNTY. THESE RAINBANDS AND ASSOCIATED HEAVY RAIN WILL BEGIN MOVING INTO MARTIN COUNTY BY 6PM AND WILL QUICKLY RESULT IN LOCALIZED FLOODING. RESIDENTS SHOULD BE ALERT FOR THE ISSUANCE OF FLOOD WARNINGS. FLOODING RAINFALL WILL SPREAD INTO ST LUCIE...OKEECHOBEE... AND INDIAN RIVER COUNTIES LATER THIS THE EVENING. BRIEF...ISOLATED TORNADOES ARE POSSIBLE IN OUTER RAINBANDS THROUGH THE NIGHT. THESE TYPE OF TORNADOES OFTEN SPIN UP QUICKLY AS STRONG RAINBAND CONVECTION MOVES ONSHORE. TORNADO WARNINGS MAY BE ISSUED LATER TONIGHT.  ...WIND AND RAINFALL INFORMATION... FLOODING IS THE GREATEST THREAT FROM IRENE WITH 8 TO 12 INCHES OF RAIN ARE POSSIBLE. SOME AREAS OF EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA HAVE EXPERIENCED 24 INCHES OF RAIN IN THE PAST 30 DAYS. ANY ADDITIONAL RAIN WILL QUICKLY CAUSE SERIOUS FLOODING PROBLEMS.  BASED ON THE CURRENT FORECAST TRACK TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS SHOULD BEGIN TO SPREAD OVER MARTIN...ST LUCIE AND OKEECHOBEE COUNTIES THIS EARLY THIS EVENING AND SPREAD OVER ALL OF EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA DURING THE NIGHT AND THROUGH THE DAY SATURDAY. THE ORLANDO METRO AREA AND SANFORD COULD SEE TROPICAL STORM FORCE GUSTS BY DAYBREAK SATURDAY. PEAK WIND GUSTS DURING IRENE ARE EXPECTED TO BE IN THE 50 TO 60 MPH RANGE WHICH WILL NOT CAUSE WIDESPREAD DAMAGE... BUT WILL BLOW TREE LIMBS ON POWER LINES CAUSING SCATTERED OUTAGES... POSSIBLY BRING DOWN OLDER DISEASED TREES. THE STRONGEST WIND GUSTS WILL LIKELY OCCUR IN RAIN SQUALLS WITHIN RAINBANDS MOVING ONSHORE.  ...STORM SURGE AND STORM TIDE INFORMATION... SIGNIFICANT STORM SURGE IS NOT EXPECTED ALONG THE COAST...HOWEVER... SUSTAINED ONSHORE WINDS OF TROPICAL STORM FORCE WILL PRODUCE EXTREMELY ROUGH SURF...RIP CURRENTS...ADDITIONAL MINOR BEACH EROSION...AND POSSIBLY SOME MINOR COASTAL FLOODING...ESPECIALLY AROUND THE TIME OF HIGH TIDE. THE HEAVY RAINS WILL  PUT PRESSURE ON FLAT TOPPED ROOFS WHICH MAY LEAK OR COLLAPSE FROM  THE WEIGHT OF THE WATER.  MOTORISTS ARE URGED TO USE EXTREME CAUTION. STANDING WATER ON  ROADWAYS CAN CAUSE MOTORISTS TO DRIVE INTO CANALS OR OTHER DEEP  WATER. WWUS31 KJAX 142108 HLSJAX AMZ435-450-452-454-470-472-474- FLZ020>025-030>033-035>038-040- GAZ132>136-149>154-162>166-150000-  HURRICANE LOCAL STATEMENT NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE JACKSONVILLE FL 500 PM EDT TUE SEP 14 1999  ...A HURRICANE WARNING IS IN NOW EFFECT FROM BOCA RATON FLORIDA IN SOUTHEAST FLORIDA NORTH TO LITTLE RIVER INLET IN NORTH CAROLINA...  ...A HIGH WIND WARNING IS IN EFFECT FOR MOST INLAND SECTIONS OF NORTH FLORIDA AND A HIGH WIND WATCH IS IN EFFECT FOR INLAND SECTIONS OF SOUTHEAST GEORGIA TONIGHT AND WEDNESDAY...  ...HURRICANE FLOYD IS A LARGE AND POWERFUL HURRICANE AND REPRESENTS AN EXTREMELY SERIOUS THREAT TO THE REGION. PLEASE HEAD THE ADVICE OF EMERGENCY OFFICIALS AND LEAVE EVACUATION ZONES NOW...  THIS STATEMENT PERTAINS TO RESIDENTS IN THE FOLLOWING COUNTIES OF SOUTHEAST GEORGIA APPLING...ATKINSON...BACON...BRANTLEY...CAMDEN... CHARLTON...CLINCH...COFFEE...ECHOLS...GLYNN...JEFF DAVIS...PIERCE... WARE...WAYNE AND THE FOLLOWING COUNTIES OF NORTHEAST FLORIDA... ALACHUA...BAKER...BRADFORD...CLAY...COLUMBIA..DUVAL...FLAGLER... GILCHRIST...HAMILTON...MARION...NASSAU...PUTNAM...ST. JOHNS... SUWANNEE...UNION.  AT 5 PM EDT HURRICANE FLOYD WAS LOCATED NEAR LATITUDE 26.3 NORTH LONGITUDE 77.5 WEST OR APPROXIMATELY 345 MILES SOUTHEAST OF JACKSONVILLE BEACH. MAXIMUM SUSTAINED WINDS ARE NEAR 140 MPH. SOME FLUCTUATIONS IN INTENSITY ARE LIKELY DURING THE NEXT 24 HOURS. ON ITS CURRENT FORECAST TRACK...THE CENTER OF THE STORM IS EXPECTED TO PASS BETWEEN 50 TO 100 MILES OFFSHORE OF THE NORTHEAST FLORIDA AND SOUTHEAST GEORGIA COASTS. SPECIFICALLY...THE CENTER OF THE HURRICANE IS EXPECTED TO BE OFFSHORE FLAGLER BEACH AROUND 2 PM ON WEDNESDAY AND THEN CONTINUE TO MOVE NORTH REACHING THE AREA OFFSHORE FERNANDINA BEACH AROUND 7 PM WEDNESDAY AND THE OFFSHORE WATERS OF BRUNSWICK AND THE GOLDEN ISLES IN SOUTHEAST GEORGIA AROUND 9 PM WEDNESDAY.  ...WIND INFORMATION... COASTAL WINDS...TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS...WINDS GREATER THAN 39 MPH...ARE EXPECTED AS FOLLOWS...NEAR FLAGLER BEACH AFTER 10 PM TONIGHT...NEAR FERNANDINA BEACH 6 AM WEDNESDAY MORNING...BRUNSWICK BY 9 AM WEDNESDAY. WINDS WILL ALSO APPROACH HURRICANE FORCE...GREATER THAN 74 MPH...IN SQUALLS ALONG THE IMMEDIATE COAST FROM MID-MORNING ON WEDNESDAY NEAR FLAGLER BEACH INTO THE EARLY EVENING IN SOUTHEAST GEORGIA. THE HURRICANE FORCE WIND GUSTS COULD LAST OVER SIX HOURS.  INLAND WINDS...TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS WILL ALSO REACH INLAND AREAS AS FAR WEST AS I-75 AND THEREFORE A HIGH WIND WARNING IS IN EFFECT FOR MANY INLAND COUNTIES IN NORTHEAST FLORIDA. HIGH WIND WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT FOR SOUTHEAST GEORGIA...AN MAY BE UPGRADED TONIGHT.  ...TIDES/STORM SURGE INFORMATION... TIDES ARE CURRENTLY RUNNING 2 TO 2 1/2 FEET ABOVE NORMAL AND MINOR FLOODING WAS REPORTED DURING THE PAST HIGH TIDE. THE TIDAL VALUES ALONG THE RIVERS...BAYS AND THE INTRACOASTAL WATERWAY WILL CONTINUE TO INCREASE AND THIS COULD CAUSE ADDITIONAL FLOODING OF ROADWAYS. THE TIMES OF ASTRONOMICAL HIGH TIDE ALONG THE OCEANFRONT WILL BE BETWEEN NOON AND 1 PM AND BETWEEN MIDNIGHT AND 1 AM THROUGH WEDNESDAY...WITH A ONE TO THREE HOUR DELAY ALONG THE RIVERS AND INTRACOASTAL.  HURRICANE FLOYD WILL BRING A STORM SURGE OF 5 TO 8 FEET ALONG NASSAU...DUVAL...ST. JOHNS...AND FLAGLER COUNTIES AND 8 TO 10 FEET ALONG GLYNN AND CAMDEN COUNTIES. Indian River County     January  21-22 l989 - Brevard, Volusia, Flagler, St. Johns and Indian River Counties - High Winds - A gale center that exhibited subtropical storm characteristics formed in the coastal waters east of Canaveral then moved slowly northeast. Sustained winds of 40 to 50 mph with gusts near 75 mph downed many trees, signs and power lines, and caused window and roof damage to several homes. High waves caused moderate beach erosion. Tens of thousands of homes were without electric power for up to l2 hours. Rainfall amounts of 4" to 6" caused ponding of water in low-lying areas, which damaged several homes and motels and caused many traffic accidents.   March   6 l992 - Early Evening - Central Florida - Hail up to l.75" covered the ground up to a foot deep in southwest Seminole County. l.75" hail fell in Lake County and l.25" hail fell in Orange County. Severe Thunderstorm winds caused damage in Orange, Seminole, Brevard, and Indian River Counties. Damage ran into the millions, but there were no serious injuries.    21 l993 - l400 - Indian River Co., Vero Beach - Flash flooding damaged about 50 homes and many roads around Hwy 60 were washed out.    25 1955 - afternoon - central Florida - Large Hail caused heavy roof damage to homes and barns in Sumter County. Large hail also fell in Pasco, Hernando, Polk, and Indian River Counties. Hail of lesser size was reported in Lake and Brevard counties.   31 1996 - Afternoon - early evening - North central to southeast Florida - Severe weather hit for the second day in a row.  A  small tornado blew down a few trees on S. R. 60 west of Vero Beach.  Baseball to softball size hail was reported near  Fellsmere, while dime to golf ball size hail occurred from Levy to Dade county, causing over a quarter million dollars damage to  property and crops. Lightning struck and injured a man on Miami Beach. In Levy County, two large pine trees were snapped  at the base and downed at Cedar Key.   March  6 l992 - Early Evening - Central Florida - Hail up to l.75" covered the ground up to a foot deep in southwest Seminole County. l.75" hail fell in Lake County and l.25" hail fell in Orange County. Severe Thunderstorm winds caused damage in Orange, Seminole, Brevard, and Indian River Counties. Damage ran into the millions, but there were no serious injuries.    21 l993 - l400 - Indian River Co., Vero Beach - Flash flooding damaged about 50 homes and many roads around Hwy 60 were washed out.    25 1955 - afternoon - central Florida - Large Hail caused heavy roof damage to homes and barns in Sumter County. Large hail also fell in Pasco, Hernando, Polk, and Indian River Counties. Hail of lesser size was reported in Lake and Brevard counties.    May   2 l964 - entire day - North Florida - Madison, Hamilton, Baker, Union, Clay, Columbia, Duval, St. Johns, Putnam and Bradford Counties - Heavy rains from a slow moving low pressure system caused considerable local flooding on most streams and forced evacuation of some residential areas. Maxville and Middleburg communities were hardest hit. Two persons drowned at Maxville while fleeing rising waters. Hail fell in scattered areas and caused some crop damage. Early on the morning of the 3rd Thunderstorm winds unroofed 2 houses and damaged other homes and commercial buildings at Roseland in Indian River County.    8 l977 - Night - St. Lucie, Indian River, Brevard Cos. - A line of thunderstorms moved through the area from west to east. Several of these thunderstorms were severe, accompanied by lightning, gusty winds, locally heavy rain and some hail. Lightning struck a tire store in Vero Beach causing a fire resulting in $750,000 damage. Winds up to 50 mph were reported at Kennedy Space Center.   8 l979 - morning-afternoon - Central Florida - Tornado Outbreak/Heavy Rain/Floods - A low pressure system in the eastern Gulf of Mexico spawned waves of tornadic thunderstorms with excessive rainfall. Widespread damage occurred in the Tampa Bay area. The 19 tornadoes reported are the most in one day in Florida history. 3 people drowned in Pinellas County where flooding was most severe. Rainfall amounts of 18 inches in 24 hours were reported. Tornadoes damaged homes, mobile homes, businesses, 4 schools, power lines, and trees. Worst hit was the Polk Co. community of Auburndale where a tornado made a direct hit on the Auburndale School. Only 8 students were hurt by flying debris. An 83 year old woman was killed as she hid in an unreinforced concrete block storage shed. 98 trailers were damaged or destroyed and 40 people were injured. Other, less intense, tornadoes struck Pasco, Hernando, Volusia, Citrus, St. Lucie, Duval, Desoto and Charlotte Counties. Later, on the evening of the 8th, rain over 5" flooded homes and businesses in eastern Indian River Co.   30 1996 1930 - Indian River Co., Sebastian - A 20 passenger airplane at the Sebastian Airport was overturned and destroyed by thunderstorm winds.   June  17-21 l959 - south Florida - Heavy rains over the southern peninsula, associated with and following a tropical depression, caused considerable flooding in poorly drained and low lying agricultural areas and some residential sections. Considerable pasture land and some citrus land, particularly in the Indian River section, were inundated. Some highways also sustained flood damage. High tides along the west coast from Tampa south damaged boat docks and caused beach erosion. 5-day rain totals were mostly in the 7 to l2 inch category and some scattered points measured l5 inches or more during the period.    24 l993 - l935 - Brevard Co., Merritt Island - Waterspout/Tornado formed over Newfound Harbor and moved onshore at Merritt Island Airport. It overturned 3 single engine aircraft and destroyed 8 ultralights. It moved to an industrial area and blew over a few trees and destroyed a warehouse roof before dissipating over the Indian River.   26 1996 afternoon - Indian River/St Lucie Counties, Vero Beach/Ft Pierce  - In two separate incidences, severe thunderstorm  winds overturned a small aircraft at both Vero Beach Municipal Airport and Ft Pierce Airport, where wind gusts to 81 mph  were recorded.   August  3 l986 - l730 - Indian River Co. - Lightning killed a 33-year old woman seeking shelter underneath a tree.   November  l0 l963 - 08l5 - Charlotte Co., Punta Gorda - A tornado unroofed four houses and damaged l0 others in Harbour Heights. l300 - Indian River Co., Wabasso - A tornado moved from SW to NW and then out to sea damaging l0 homes. Several citrus trees were uprooted.    22-24 1984 - St. Johns, Flagler, Volusia, Brevard, Indian River, St. Lucie, Martin, Palm Beach Counties. - Great Thanksgiving Holiday East Coast Storm - A strong low pressure system developed east of Florida, and coupled with a high pressure to the northwest, a strong pressure gradient led to gale force winds along the east coast. As the low moved slowly north heavy rains of up to seven inches fell over south Florida. There was extensive coastal flooding and beach erosion with many structures damaged or destroyed. Fishing piers and seawalls were damaged or destroyed. Damage ran into the millions and was confined to the seashore except where heavy rain in the south caused local flooding. A man was killed when he stepped on a downed power line.
