COLIN                WTUS82 KEYW 142126  HLSEYW FLZ076-077-078-150000-  HURRICANE FLOYD LOCAL STATEMENT 525 PM EDT TUE SEP 14 1999  ...TROPICAL STORM WARNINGS HAVE BEEN LIFTED FOR THE MIDDLE AND UPPER  KEYS AS OF 5PM...  ...AREAS AFFECTED... THIS STATEMENT APPLIES TO PEOPLE IN ALL PARTS OF THE KEYS OF MONROE  COUNTY FLORIDA CONCERNING THE EFFECTS OF HURRICANE FLOYD.  ...WATCHES...WARNINGS AND ADVISORIES... ALL TROPICAL STORM WARNINGS HAVE BEEN LIFTED FOR THE UPPER AND MIDDLE  FLORIDA KEYS AND THE ADJACENT COASTAL WATERS. A SMALL CRAFT ADVISORY  REMAINS IN EFFECT FOR ALL OF THE FLORIDA KEYS FROM ANGELFISH KEY TO  DRY TORTUGAS AND THE ADJACENT FLORIDA STRAITS OUT TO 50 NAUTICAL  MILES AND FLORIDA BAY.   ...HURRICANE INFORMATION... AT 5 PM EDT HURRICANE FLOYD WAS CENTERED NEAR LATITUDE 26.5 NORTH... LONGITUDE 77.4 WEST OR ABOUT 235 MILES SOUTHEAST OF CAPE CANAVERAL  FLORIDA. FLOYD HAS TURNED AS EXPECTED AND WAS MOVING NORTHWEST NEAR  12 MPH. THIS MOTION WILL BRING FLOYD CLOSER TO THE CENTRAL AND NORTH  FLORIDA EAST COASTS DURING THE NEXT 24 HOURS. MAXIMUM SUSTAINED WINDS ARE NEAR 140 MPH WITH HIGHER GUSTS.  ...PRECAUTIONARY PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS... ALL BRIDGES IN THE FLORIDA KEYS...INCLUDING THE SEVEN MILE  BRIDGE ARE OPEN. WHEN DRIVING VEHICLES OVER THE BRIDGES...ESPECIALLY  HIGH PROFILE VEHICLES...BE WARY OF GUSTY WINDS IN EXCESS OF 40 MPH.  THE MONROE COUNTY RUMOR CONTROL TELEPHONE NUMBER IS 1-800-955-5504  AND WILL BE DEACTIVATED AT 11 PM THIS EVENING.   AIRLINE COMMUTERS SHOULD BE AWARE THAT MOST AIRLINES FLYING IN AND  OUT OF MIAMI INTERNATIONAL AND FORT LAUDERDALE INTERNATIONAL HAVE  CANCELLED FLIGHTS EARLIER TODAY. SERVICE FROM KEY WEST AND MARATHON  AIRPORTS ARE TO RETURN TO NORMAL SCHEDULES WEDNESDAY  MORNING...HOWEVER IT IS WISE TO CHECK WITH THE AIRPORTS BEFORE  PROCEEDING FURTHER.  ...STORM SURGE FLOODING/TIDES/OTHER MARINE HAZARDS... SOME MINOR TIDAL OVERFLOW WILL OCCUR ALONG THE UPPER AND MIDDLE  KEYS...NEAR THE TIMES OF HIGH TIDE LATE TONIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY.  THERE COULD BE PROBLEM OF WATER PILING UP IN FLORIDA BAY LATE TONIGHT AND WEDNESDAY AS WINDS SHIFT TO A MORE WESTERLY DIRECTION.  TIMES OF THE HIGH TIDES... OCEAN REEF HARBOR...NORTH END OF KEY LARGO  1225 AM WED  101 PM WED   KEY LARGO...LARGO SOUTH SOUND   1258 AM WED  134 PM WED  MARATHON (VACA KEY)  1214 AM WED  108 PM WED  THE WESTERN SIDE OF CARD SOUND ROAD   316 AM WED   402 PM WED  SMALL CRAFT ADVISORIES WILL REMAIN IN EFFECT FOR THE LOWER KEYS. WIND  WAVES THIS EVENING INTO TONIGHT WILL REACH AS HIGH 6 TO 9 FEET  OVER OPEN WATERS THE KEYS. ALSO...LARGE SWELLS GENERATED ON THE WEST  SIDE OF FLOYD WILL PROPAGATE SOUTHWARD DOWN THE STRAITS OF FLORIDA  AFFECTING FLORIDA STRAITS WATERS OF THE UPPER AND MIDDLE KEYS TODAY  AND TONIGHT. MARINERS IN THE LOWER KEYS SHOULD MONITOR LATER WEATHER  ISSUANCES...AND BE ALERT TO CHANGEABLE WEATHER...WIND AND SEAS AND  ARE ADVISED TO REMAIN IN PORT TILL THE WIND AND SEAS SUBSIDE..  ...WIND IMPACTS... FLOYD CONTINUES TO BE A VERY LARGE HURRICANE. TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS EXTEND OUT 125 MILES TO THE SOUTHWEST OF THE CENTER OF FLOYD.  WIND GUSTS IN EXCESS OF 35 MPH ARE POSSIBLE THROUGOUT THE FLORIDA  KEYS THIS EVENING.    WINDS ACROSS THE LOWER KEYS WATERS HAVE BEEN FROM THE NORTH AND  NORTHWEST AT 20 KT WITH GUSTS POSSIBLE TO 40 KT.   WIND AT THE AIRPORTS FROM MARATHON TO KEY WEST HAVE BEEN NORTHWEST  NEAR 15 MPH WITH OCCASIONAL HIGHER GUSTS.   WIND DIRECTION ACROSS THE KEYS AND ADJACENT MARINE AREA WILL BE  NORTHWEST THIS EVENING.   ...RAINFALL INFORMATION... ALTHOUGH THERE CAN BE OCCASIONAL DOWNPOURS OF RAIN IN ANY RAINBAND  THAT DOES MOVE THROUGH THE KEYS...NO WIDESPREAD HEAVY RAINS WILL  OCCUR DUE TO THE FAST MOVEMENT AND THE LOCATION OF FLOYD IN RELATION  TO THE KEYS.   BESIDES THE WEB SITE AT THE NATIONAL HURRICANE CENTER...ADDITIONAL  WEB SITES FOR HURRICANE ADVISORY INFORMATION CAN BE ACCESSED THROUGH  FLORIDA WEATHER SERVICE OFFICES THROUGH THE FOLLOWING ADDRESSES:  KEY WEST... PLEASE HEAD THE ADVICE OF EMERGENCY OFFICIALS AND LEAVE EVACUATION ZONES NOW...  THIS STATEMENT PERTAINS TO RESIDENTS IN THE FOLLOWING COUNTIES OF SOUTHEAST GEORGIA APPLING...ATKINSON...BACON...BRANTLEY...CAMDEN... CHARLTON...CLINCH...COFFEE...ECHOLS...GLYNN...JEFF DAVIS...PIERCE... WARE...WAYNE AND THE FOLLOWING COUNTIES OF NORTHEAST FLORIDA... ALACHUA...BAKER...BRADFORD...CLAY...COLUMBIA..DUVAL...FLAGLER... GILCHRIST...HAMILTON...MARION...NASSAU...PUTNAM...ST. JOHNS... SUWANNEE...UNION.  AT 5 PM EDT HURRICANE FLOYD WAS LOCATED NEAR LATITUDE 26.3 NORTH LONGITUDE 77.5 WEST OR APPROXIMATELY 345 MILES SOUTHEAST OF JACKSONVILLE BEACH. MAXIMUM SUSTAINED WINDS ARE NEAR 140 MPH. SOME FLUCTUATIONS IN INTENSITY ARE LIKELY DURING THE NEXT 24 HOURS. ON ITS CURRENT FORECAST TRACK...THE CENTER OF THE STORM IS EXPECTED TO PASS BETWEEN 50 TO 100 MILES OFFSHORE OF THE NORTHEAST FLORIDA AND SOUTHEAST GEORGIA COASTS. SPECIFICALLY...THE CENTER OF THE HURRICANE IS EXPECTED TO BE OFFSHORE FLAGLER BEACH AROUND 2 PM ON WEDNESDAY AND THEN CONTINUE TO MOVE NORTH REACHING THE AREA OFFSHORE FERNANDINA BEACH AROUND 7 PM WEDNESDAY AND THE OFFSHORE WATERS OF BRUNSWICK AND THE GOLDEN ISLES IN SOUTHEAST GEORGIA AROUND 9 PM WEDNESDAY.  ...WIND INFORMATION... COASTAL WINDS...TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS...WINDS GREATER THAN 39 MPH...ARE EXPECTED AS FOLLOWS...NEAR FLAGLER BEACH AFTER 10 PM TONIGHT...NEAR FERNANDINA BEACH 6 AM WEDNESDAY MORNING...BRUNSWICK BY 9 AM WEDNESDAY. WINDS WILL ALSO APPROACH HURRICANE FORCE...GREATER THAN 74 MPH...IN SQUALLS ALONG THE IMMEDIATE COAST FROM MID-MORNING ON WEDNESDAY NEAR FLAGLER BEACH INTO THE EARLY EVENING IN SOUTHEAST GEORGIA. THE HURRICANE FORCE WIND GUSTS COULD LAST OVER SIX HOURS.  INLAND WINDS...TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS WILL ALSO REACH INLAND AREAS AS FAR WEST AS I-75 AND THEREFORE A HIGH WIND WARNING IS IN EFFECT FOR MANY INLAND COUNTIES IN NORTHEAST FLORIDA. HIGH WIND WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT FOR SOUTHEAST GEORGIA...AN MAY BE UPGRADED TONIGHT.  ...TIDES/STORM SURGE INFORMATION... TIDES ARE CURRENTLY RUNNING 2 TO 2 1/2 FEET ABOVE NORMAL AND MINOR FLOODING WAS REPORTED DURING THE PAST HIGH TIDE. THE TIDAL VALUES ALONG THE RIVERS...BAYS AND THE INTRACOASTAL WATERWAY WILL CONTINUE TO INCREASE AND THIS COULD CAUSE ADDITIONAL FLOODING OF ROADWAYS. THE TIMES OF ASTRONOMICAL HIGH TIDE ALONG THE OCEANFRONT WILL BE BETWEEN NOON AND 1 PM AND BETWEEN MIDNIGHT AND 1 AM THROUGH WEDNESDAY...WITH A ONE TO THREE HOUR DELAY ALONG THE RIVERS AND INTRACOASTAL.  HURRICANE FLOYD WILL BRING A STORM SURGE OF 5 TO 8 FEET ALONG NASSAU...DUVAL...ST. JOHNS...AND FLAGLER COUNTIES AND 8 TO 10 FEET ALONG GLYNN AND CAMDEN COUNTIES. THIS STORM SURGE WILL BEGIN SPREADING NORTHWARD FROM VERY EARLY WEDNESDAY MORNING NEAR FLAGLER BEACH...AROUND SUNRISE IN THE ST. AUGUSTINE AREA...AND MID TO LATE MORNING IN DUVAL AND NASSAU COUNTIES. THE STORM SURGE WILL BEGIN TO SPREAD INTO THE SOUTHEAST GEORGIA WATERS EARLY ON WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON. THE STORM SURGE WILL LAST FOR A PERIOD OF 10 TO 12 HOURS AS THE HURRICANE APPROACHES AND DECREASE WITHIN 6 HOURS AFTER PASSAGE OF THE EYE OFFSHORE.  ...HEAVY SURF... ONE OF THE PRIMARY THREATS FROM FLOYD WILL BE THE LARGE...LIFE THREATENING WAVE ACTION WHICH IT WILL GENERATE. HURRICANES IN 1804 AND 1893...WHICH MOVED ALONG OR NEAR THE PROJECTED TRACK...CAUSED SERIOUS DAMAGE ALONG THE COAST DUE TO WAVE ACTION. DAMAGING SURF WILL LIKELY REACH INTO OR BEYOND THE DUNE LINES AND SEA WALLS BEGINNING TONIGHT IN NORTHEAST FLORIDA AND ON WEDNESDAY MORNING IN SOUTHEAST GEORGIA. MAJOR BEACH EROSION WILL OCCUR AND SEAS ARE FORECAST TO BE AS HIGH AS 18 TO 25 FEET ON WEDNESDAY.  ...RAIN... AS THE HURRICANE APPROACHES THE REGION TONIGHT AND WEDNESDAY...RAIN BANDS WILL INCREASE IN FREQUENCY WITH LOCALLY HEAVY RAIN AMOUNTS POSSIBLE. GIVEN THE PROJECTED PATH ASSOCIATED WITH HURRICANE FLOYD... RAINFALL AMOUNTS OF UP TO 4 TO 6 INCHES ALONG THE COASTAL COUNTIES AND 2 TO 4 INCHES INLAND ARE POSSIBLE.  ...GENERAL INFORMATION... DO NOT CALL 911 UNLESS IT IS AN EMERGENCY. MANY PUBLIC SCHOOLS HAVE BEEN CLOSED FOR TOMORROW IF IN DOUBT CONTACT YOU LOCAL OFFICIALS.  ...ACTIONS IN SPECIFIC COUNTIES PASSED TO THE NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE IN JACKSONVILLE AS OF 500 PM EDT...  ...GLYNN COUNTY... A MANDATORY EVACUATION FOR ALL OF GLYNN COUNTY. THE ST. SIMONS ISLAND CAUSEWAY IS CLOSED. SHELTER AREAS WILL BE OPEN IN THE CITIES OF DOUGLAS (IN COFFEE COUNTY) AND TIFTON (IN TIFT COUNTY) FOR THOSE WHO HAVE NO OTHER LOCATION TO SEEK SHELTER.  ...CAMDEN... A MANDATORY EVACUATION FOR ALL OF CAMDEN COUNTY. SHELTER AREAS WILL BE OPEN IN DOUGLAS (IN COFFEE COUNTY) FOR THOSE WHO HAVE NO OTHER LOCATION TO SEEK SHELTER.  ...NASSAU... A MANDATORY EVACUATION OF AMELIA ISLAND AND LOW LYING AREAS SUBJECT TO FLOODING WEST OF AMELIA ISLAND.  ...DUVAL... A MANDATORY EVACUATION IS IN EFFECT FOR THE RESIDENTS EAST OF THE INTRACOASTAL WATERWAY...MOBILE HOME RESIDENTS...AND LOW LYING AREAS. KNOWN SHELTERS ARE...LANDMARK MIDDLE SCHOOL...ED WHITE HIGH SCHOOL... MANDARIN MIDDLE SCHOOL...AND WILLIAM RAINES HIGH SCHOOL. PUBLIC SCHOOLS WILL BE CLOSED TODAY AND WEDNESDAY. FOR ADDITIONAL INFORMATION ON SHELTER LOCATIONS AND EVACUATION INFORMATION CALL THE DUVAL COUNTY EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT INFORMATION CENTER AT (904) 630-4636.  ...ST. JOHNS... A MANDATORY EVACUATION OF THE BARRIER ISLANDS EAST OF THE INTRACOASTAL AND ALL PERSONS LIVING IN MOBILE AND MANUFACTURED HOMES. THE FOLLOWING EVACUATION SHELTERS HAVE BEEN OPENED...MILL CREEK ELEMENTARY...OSCEOLA ELEMENTARY...AND MASON ELEMENTARY. THE SPECIAL NEEDS SHELTER WILL BE THE ST. JOHNS COUNTY AGRICULTURAL CENTER OFF OF SR 208. EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT IS ENCOURAGING CITIZENS AND VISITORS TO LEAVE EARLY AND HEAD WEST OUT OF ST. JOHNS COUNTY. EVACUATION SHELTERS SHOULD BE USED ONLY AS A LAST OPTION.  ...FLAGLER... A MANDATORY EVACUATION IS IN EFFECT FOR COASTAL FLAGLER COUNTY AND RESIDENTS OF LOW LYING AREAS. FLAGLER COUNTY RESIDENTS MAY WATCH TV- 15 AT THE TOP AND BOTTOM OF EACH HOUR FOR UPDATED INFORMATION. FOR ADDITIONAL INFORMATION CALL THE FLAGLER COUNTY INFORMATION NUMBER AT (904) 437-8202 OR VISIT THEIR WEBSITE AT HTTP://WWW.FLAGLEREMERGENCY.COM/.  ...UNION... A MANDATORY EVACUATION IS IN EFFECT FOR ALL PERSONS LIVING IN MOBILE AND MANUFACTURED HOMES. SHELTERS IN UNION COUNTY WILL BE OPENED AT 4 PM TODAY. FOR ADDITIONAL INFORMATION CALL THE UNION COUNTY EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT NUMBER AT (904) 496-4300 OR (904) 496-4303.  ...BAKER... A VOLUNTARY EVACUATION IS IN EFFECT FOR PERSONS LIVING IN MOBILE AND MANUFACTURED HOMES. A SHELTER HAS BEEN OPENED AT THE FAMILY SERVICE CENTER AT THE KELLER INTERMEDIATE SCHOOL. A SPECIAL NEEDS SHELTER HAS BEEN OPENED AT FRASER HOSPITAL. FOR ADDITIONAL INFORMATION CALL THE BAKER COUNTY EMERGENCY OPERATIONS CENTER AT (904) 259-8024.  ...PUTNAM... THE EVACUATION OF RESIDENTS LIVING IN MOBILE AND MODULAR HOMES AND THOSE LIVING IN FLOOD PRONE AREAS IS RECOMMENDED. SEVERAL SHELTERS HAVE BEEN OPENED. CALL (904) 329-0379 FOR ADDITIONAL INFORMATION.  ...OTHER INLAND COUNTIES... THE FOLLOWING INLAND COUNTIES HAVE CLOSED SCHOOLS FOR BOTH TODAY AND WEDNESDAY...ALACHUA...CLAY...MARION AND PUTNAM.  ...RECOMMENDATIONS... WITH ONLY A FEW HOURS OF DAYLIGHT LEFT ALL FINAL PREPARATIONS SHOULD BE RUSHED TO COMPLETION. CONDITIONS WILL RAPIDLY DETERIORATE OVERNIGHT. RESIDENTS ARE URGED TO FOLLOW THE ADVICE OF THEIR LOCAL EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AND PUBLIC OFFICIALS IN REGARD TO EVACUATIONS AND PRECAUTIONS.  THE NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE URGES RESIDENTS TO CONTINUE TO MONITOR FLOYD VIA NOAA WEATHER RADIO...LOCAL RADIO...AND TELEVISION STATIONS IN CASE ADDITIONAL WARNINGS OR STATEMENTS ARE ISSUED. ADDITIONAL STATEMENTS AND INFORMATION...INCLUDING STORM PREPARATION TIPS...CAN ALSO BE FOUND ON THE NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE WEBSITE AT... HTTP://WWW.NWSJAX.NOAA.GOV (LOWER CASE). OSCEOLA AND OKEECHOBEE COUNTIES OF EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA IN PREPARATION FOR HURRICANE FLOYD.  ...WATCHES AND WARNINGS... A HURRICANE WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FOR THE ENTIRE EAST COAST OF FLORIDA. AN INLAND HIGH WIND WARNING IS IN EFFECT FOR LAKE... ORANGE...SEMINOLE...OKEECHOBEE...AND OSCEOLA COUNTIES OF EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA. A FLOOD WATCH HAS ALSO BEEN POSTED FOR THE COASTAL COUNTIES OF MARTIN...ST LUCIE...INDIAN RIVER...BREVARD...AND VOLUSIA.  ...STORM INFORMATION... AT 5 AM EDT... THE CENTER OF HURRICANE FLOYD WAS LOCATED NEAR LATITUDE 25.1 NORTH... LONGITUDE  75.9 WEST OR ABOUT 370 MILES SOUTHEAST OF CAPE CANAVERAL. FLOYD IS NOW MOVING WEST NORTHWEST NEAR 14 MPH.  MAXIMUM SUSTAINED WINDS REMAIN NEAR 155 MPH WITH HIGHER GUSTS. LITTLE SIGNIFICANT CHANGE IN STRENGTH IS FORECAST DURING THE NEXT 24 HOURS.  FLOYD HAS BEGUN MAKING A GRADUAL TURN TO A SLIGHTLY MORE NORTHWESTERLY TRACK. HOWEVER THIS IS STILL A LARGE AND POWERFUL HURRICANE. EVEN IF THE EYE WALL REMAINS OFF SHORE... HURRICANE FORCE WINDS WILL SWEEP OVER ALL THE CENTRAL FLORIDA COASTAL COUNTIES IN THE WARNING AREA BEGINNING THIS EVENING IN MARTIN COUNTY AND ENDING IN FLAGLER COUNTY WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON. REMEMBER... ANY FURTHER CHANGE TO THE LEFT OF THE FORECAST TRACK WOULD LIKELY BRING THIS MAJOR CATEGORY 4 HURRICANE DIRECTLY OVER LAND!   ...PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS... PREPARATIONS FOR HURRICANE CONDITIONS SHOULD BE NEARING COMPLETION. ANY REMAINING OUTDOOR PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS MUST BE COMPLETED BY MIDDAY TODAY. RESIDENTS MUST LISTEN CLOSELY TO THE INSTRUCTIONS OF THEIR RESPECTIVE COUNTY OFFICIALS. QUESTIONS REGARDING COUNTY EVACUATION CONDITIONS AND PROCEDURES SHOULD BE DIRECTED TO COUNTY CITIZEN INFORMATION CENTERS.  SCHOOLS HAVE BEEN CANCELLED FOR BOTH TUESDAY AND WEDNESDAY FOR MOST AREAS.  ALSO...SHELTERS HAVE BEEN OPENED IN EACH OF THE COASTAL COUNTIES...AND SOME INLAND COUNTIES. IF HEADING TO A SHELTER...KEEP IN MIND THAT PETS...WEAPONS...AND ALCOHOL ARE NOT ALLOWED.  ONCE TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS BEGIN TO AFFECT YOUR LOCATION... TRAVEL IS DISCOURAGED.  ...CURRENT RADAR/SEVERE WEATHER THREAT INFORMATION... THE OUTER RAIN BANDS OF HURRICANE FLOYD ARE NOW VISIBLE ON THE DOPPLER RADAR IN MELBOURNE. RAIN SHOWERS WERE SWEEPING OVER THE GRAND BAHAMA BANKS AND WILL BE SWEEPING ACROSS EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA BEGINNING ABOUT NOON.  ...WIND IMPACTS... BASED ON THE LATEST OFFICIAL FORECAST...TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS SHOULD BEGIN IN MARTIN COUNTY BY AROUND 11AM...AND SPREAD INTO OKEECHOBEE...ST LUCIE...INDIAN RIVER AND SOUTHERN BREVARD COUNTIES BY MID AFTERNOON. TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS WILL SPREAD ACROSS VOLUSIA...SEMINOLE...ORANGE...AND LAKE COUNTIES BY THIS EVENING. HURRICANE FORCE WINDS WILL APPROACH MARTIN COUNTY ABOUT 9 PM THIS EVENING AND SWEEP ACROSS SAINT LUCIE... INDIAN RIVER AND BREVARD COUNTIES TONIGHT AND WEDNESDAY MORNING. HURRICANE FORCE WINDS WILL ENTER VOLUSIA AND FLAGLER COUNTIES BEFORE SUNRISE ON WEDNESDAY.  THE CENTER OF FLOYD IS EXPECTED TO PASS ABOUT 60 MILES OFFSHORE MARTIN COUNTY...AND ABOUT 40 MILES OFFSHORE CAPE CANAVERAL. IMPORTANTLY...FLOYD IS A STRONG CATEGORY 4 HURRICANE WITH HURRICANE WINDS EXTENDING OUTWARD 125 MILES.  ...STORM SURGE AND TIDE INFORMATION... A STORM SURGE OF 7 TO 12 FEET CAN BE EXPECTED AROUND MIDNIGHT TONIGHT. THIS WILL PRODUCE SIGNIFICANT BEACH EROSION.  ...RAINFALL INFORMATION... A FLOOD WATCH HAS BEEN ISSUED FOR ALL COUNTIES IN EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA.  EVEN THOUGH FLOYD IS MOVING QUICKLY... IT IS A LARGE HURRICANE. AS A RESULT...RAINFALL FROM FLOYD COULD BE AS MUCH AS 5 TO 10 INCHES.  INLAND COUNTIES CAN EXPECT 4 TO 5 INCHES OF RAIN.  ...MARINE INFORMATION... WEATHER CONDITIONS WILL CONTINUE TO DETERIORATE RAPIDLY OVER THE COASTAL WATERS TODAY AND SMALL CRAFT SHOULD REMAIN IN PORT. SEAS ARE ALREADY BUILDING AHEAD OF FLOYD WITH 14 FOOT SEAS REPORTED 20 MILES OFFSHORE CAPE CANAVERAL. THE SURF WILL BECOME VERY ROUGH AND THE THREAT OF RIP CURRENTS WILL BE HIGH.  ...NEXT UPDATE... THE NEXT HURRICANE LOCAL STATEMENT WILL BE ISSUED ABOUT NOON SOONER IF CONDITIONS WARRANT. DECKER          WTUS82 KEYW 141035 HLSEYW FLZ076-077-078-141330-  HURRICANE FLOYD LOCAL STATEMENT 630 AM EDT TUE SEP 14 1999  ...THE OUTER CIRCULATION OF LARGE AND POWERFUL HURRICANE FLOYD WILL  CAUSE TROPICAL STORM CONDITIONS IN PARTS OF THE UPPER AND MIDDLE  KEYS TODAY AND EARLY TONIGHT...  ...AREAS AFFECTED... THIS STATEMENT APPLIES TO PEOPLE IN ALL PARTS OF THE KEYS OF MONROE  COUNTY FLORIDA CONCERNING THE EFFECTS OF HURRICANE FLOYD.  ...WATCHES...WARNINGS AND ADVISORIES... A TROPICAL STORM WARNING IS IN EFFECT FOR THE UPPER AND MIDDLE  FLORIDA KEYS AND THE ADJACENT COASTAL WATERS...FROM THE SEVEN-MILE  BRIDGE NORTHWARD TO ANGELFISH KEY. THIS INCLUDES FLORIDA BAY. A WIND ADVISORY IS IN EFFECT FOR THE LOWER KEYS. A SMALL CRAFT  ADVISORY IS IN EFFECT FROM PIGEON KEY TO DRY TORTUGAS AND THE  ADJACENT FLORIDA STRAITS OUT TO 50 NAUTICAL MILES...AND FOR THE  WATERS FROM KEY WEST TO CAPE SABLE.   ...HURRICANE INFORMATION... AT 5 AM EDT HURRICANE FLOYD WAS CENTERED ABOUT 375 MILES EAST OF KEY  WEST OR ABOUT 275 MILES EAST OF KEY LARGO. FLOYD WAS MOVING  WEST-NORTHWEST NEAR 14 MPH. A GRADUAL TURN EVEN MORE TO THE  NORTHWEST IS EXPECTED LATER TODAY. MAXIMUM SUSTAINED WINDS ARE NEAR  155 MPH WITH HIGHER GUSTS...MAKING IT A POWERFUL CATEGORY 4  STORM...JUST ONE MPH BELOW A CATEGORY 5 HURRICANE. ONLY TWO CATEGORY  5 HURRICANES HAVE EVER HIT THE U.S. THIS CENTURY...INCLUDING THE  LABOR DAY HURRICANE OF 1935 THAT DEVASTATED PARTS OF THE FLORIDA  KEYS.   ...PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS... BASED ON CURRENT FORECAST TRENDS...THERE ARE NO EVACUATION ORDERS  FOR MONROE COUNTY. HOWEVER...MONROE COUNTY EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT  ADVISES EVERYONE IN THE KEYS TO STAY TUNED TO FUTURE REPORTS.  SEVERAL PRECAUTIONARY MEASURES ARE ALREADY IN EFFECT ACCORDING TO   MONROE COUNTY EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT OFFICIALS...  MONROE COUNTY SHELTERS THAT ARE OPEN ARE KEY LARGO ELEMENTARY SCHOOL AND STANLEY SWITLIK ELEMENTARY SCHOOL IN MARATHON.  ALL MONROE COUNTY SCHOOLS ARE CLOSED TO STUDENTS TODAY.  ALL COUNTY AND STATE PARKS ARE CLOSED.  ALL COUNTY OFFICES FROM THE SEVEN MILE BRIDGE TO THE NORTH END OF  KEY LARGO ARE CLOSED TODAY. THERE IS A POSSIBILITY SOME OTHER COUNTY  OFFICES MAY BE CLOSED WEST OF THE SEVEN MILE BRIDGE TODAY.  ALSO...ALL BRIDGES IN THE FLORIDA KEYS...INCLUDING THE SEVEN MILE  BRIDGE IS STILL OPEN AS OF 6 AM.  MONROE COUNTY RUMOR CONTROL TELEPHONE NUMBER IS 1-800-955-5504.   ALL PERSONS IN THE UPPER AND MIDDLE KEYS ARE URGED TO STAY OFF  ROADS...ESPECIALLY ON THE 18 MILE STRETCH AND CARD SOUND ROAD. THERE  HAVE BEEN REPORTS FROM EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT THAT WATER WAS VERY  CLOSE TO PARTS OF THE 18 MILE STRETCH OF U.S. 1 DURING THE LAST HIGH  TIDE MONDAY EVENING...AND SEA SPRAY WAS CAUSING LOW VISIBILITY AT TIMES. IF  YOU MUST BE ON THE ROAD TODAY...PLEASE DRIVE WITH EXTREME CARE.  PERSONS ATTEMPTING TO DRIVE NORTH FROM THE KEYS TO THE MAINLAND  SHOULD BE AWARE THAT EVACUATION TRAFFIC ALONG THE ENTIRE FLORIDA  EAST COAST IS LIKELY EXTREMELY HEAVY. IF TRAVEL TO THE MAINLAND IS  ABSOLUTELY REQUIRED TODAY...IT WOULD BE BEST TO AVOID THE  TURNPIKE...INTERSTATE 95..AND U.S. 1 FROM MIAMI-DADE COUNTY  NORTHWARD.   AIRLINE COMMUTERS SHOULD BE AWARE THAT MOST AIRLINES FLYING IN AND  OUT OF MIAMI INTERNATIONAL AND FORT LAUDERDALE INTERNATIONAL HAVE  ALREADY CANCELED FLIGHTS. BOTH OF THOSE AIRPORTS ARE EXPECTED TO  SUSPEND FLIGHT OPERATIONS DURING TODAY.  ...STORM SURGE FLOODING/TIDES/OTHER MARINE HAZARDS... SOME MINOR TIDAL OVERFLOW WILL OCCUR ALONG THE UPPER AND MIDDLE  KEYS...NEAR THE TIMES OF HIGH TIDE TODAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY.  ALREADY...SOME SPOTS OF U.S. 1 NORTH OF KEY LARGO HAD WATER VERY  CLOSE TO THE ROAD AND AS THE HURRICANE MOVES CLOSER TO LAND  ADDITIONAL FLOODING PROBLEMS ARE EXPECTED. THERE COULD BE AN  ADDITIONAL PROBLEM OF WATER PILING UP IN FLORIDA BAY LATE TONIGHT  AND WEDNESDAY AS WINDS SHIFT TO MORE WESTERLY.  TIMES OF THE HIGH TIDES ARE THESE... OCEAN REEF HARBOR...NORTH END OF KEY LARGO  1217 PM TUE  1225 AM WED  101 PM WED   KEY LARGO...LARGO SOUTH SOUND   1250 PM TUE  1258 AM WED  134 PM WED  MARATHON (VACA KEY)  1224 PM TUE  1214 AM WED  108 PM WED  THE WESTERN SIDE OF CARD SOUND ROAD   318 PM TUE   316 AM WED   402 PM WED  MARINERS SHOULD REMAIN IN PORT TODAY OF THE UPPER AND MIDDLE KEYS  WATERS...WITH A TROPICAL STORM WARNING IN EFFECT. SMALL CRAFT  ADVISORIES WILL REMAIN IN EFFECT FOR THE LOWER KEYS. WIND WAVES  TODAY INTO TONIGHT WILL REACH AS HIGH 8 TO 12 FEET OVER OPEN WATERS  THE KEYS. ALSO...LARGE SWELLS GENERATED ON THE WEST SIDE OF FLOYD  WILL PROPAGATE SOUTHWARD DOWN THE STRAITS OF FLORIDA AFFECTING  FLORIDA STRAITS WATERS OF THE UPPER AND MIDDLE KEYS TODAY AND  TONIGHT. MARINERS IN THE LOWER KEYS SHOULD MONITOR LATER WEATHER  ISSUANCES...AND BE ALERT TO POSSIBLY DETERIORATING WEATHER...WIND  AND SEAS.  ...WIND IMPACTS... FLOYD CONTINUES TO BE VERY LARGE IN SIZE. TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS  EXTEND OUT 150 MILES TO THE SOUTHWEST OF FLOYDS CENTER...AND 190  MILES TO THE NORTHWEST. ACCORDING TO EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT...SOME OF  THESE WINDS HAVE ALREADY BEEN IMPACTING THE OCEAN REEF AREA OF UPPER  KEY LARGO AND FOWEY ROCKS LIGHT OFF MIAMI HAS BEEN REPORTING WIND  GUSTS PAST 40 MPH MOST OF THE EARLY MORNING HOURS.   WIND ACROSS THE WATERS OF THE FLORIDA KEYS EARLY THIS MORNING HAVE  BEEN 25 TO 30 MPH SUSTAINED...WITH GUSTS AT TIMES NEAR 35 MPH. WIND  DIRECTION HAS BEEN MOSTLY FROM THE NORTH...EXCEPT NORTH TO NORTHEAST  AT DRY TORTUGAS.   WIND AT THE AIRPORTS FROM MARATHON TO KEY WEST HAVE BEEN NORTH AS  HIGH AS NEAR 20 MPH...WITH GUSTS AS HIGH AS 25 TO 30 MPH.   BASED ON THE CURRENT FORECAST TRACK...SUSTAINED WINDS OF TROPICAL  STORM FORCE WILL SPREAD SLOWLY DOWN THE KEYS TODAY. DURING THIS  MORNING MOST OF THE TROPICAL STORM FORCE WINDS OF 39 MPH OR GREATER  WILL OCCUR IN THE UPPER KEYS AND SURROUNDING WATERS...POSSIBLY  REACHING THE MIDDLE KEYS AND THE ADJACENT WATERS THIS AFTERNOON AS  FLOYD MAKES IT CLOSEST PASS TO THE KEYS. WIND GUSTS MAY EVEN EXCEED  50 MPH THIS AFTERNOON AND EVENING FROM KEY LARGO TO OCEAN REEF IF  FLOYD TRACKS CLOSER TO THE AREA.  WINDS ACROSS THE LOWER KEYS AND THE ADJACENT WATERS WILL ONLY BE  SLIGHTLY LOWER DURING TODAY AND TONIGHT...BUT OCCASIONAL WIND GUSTS  PAST 40 MPH ARE POSSIBLE. SUSTAINED WINDS OF 25 MPH OR GREATER WILL  OCCUR OVER THE LOWER KEYS TODAY PROMPTING A WIND ADVISORY. DRIVE  WITH EXTREME CARE TODAY...ESPECIALLY ON THE BRIDGES AS THE WIND WILL  BE PERPENDICULAR TO U.S. 1  WIND DIRECTION ACROSS THE KEYS AND ADJACENT MARINE AREA WILL BE  MAINLY NORTH THIS MORNING...SHIFTING TO NORTHWEST THIS AFTERNOON AND  THEN TO WEST OR WEST-NORTHWEST TONIGHT.  ALSO...WIND COULD BE EVEN STRONGER IF ANY OUTER RAINBANDS FROM FLOYD  MAKE IT INTO THE KEYS.  ...RAINFALL INFORMATION... ALTHOUGH THERE CAN BE OCCASIONAL DOWNPOURS OF RAIN IN ANY RAINBAND  THAT DOES MOVE THROUGH THE KEYS...NO WIDESPREAD HEAVY RAINS WILL  OCCUR DUE TO THE FAST MOVEMENT AND THE LOCATION OF FLOYD IN RELATION  TO THE KEYS. IF FLOYD TURNS MORE SHARPLY TO THE NORTHWEST THERE IS  EVEN A POSSIBILITY THAT MUCH OF THE RAINBANDS STAY NORTH AND EAST OF  THE AREA.  AS OF EARLY THIS MORNING THE CLOSEST RAINBAND TO THE KEYS WAS NOT  QUITE TO ANDROS ISLAND. KEY WEST AND MIAMI RADARS AT 6 AM WERE  ALMOST FREE OF DETECTING ANY PRECIPITATION ASSOCIATED WITH FLOYD. A RATHER DRY AND COLD AIRMASS HAS OVERTAKEN THE FLORIDA PENINSULA ON STEADY NORTH TO NORTHWEST WINDS. DAYTIME TEMPERATURES WILL BEGIN TO RAPIDLY DROP AFTER SUNSET AND THROUGH THE OVERNIGHT HOURS. LOW TEMPERATURES WILL BE WELL BELOW NORMAL AND APPROACH RECORD VALUES IN MANY LOCATIONS NEAR SUNRISE. TEMPERATURES WILL BE THE COLDEST OVER INTERIOR PARTS OF LAKE AND VOLUSIA COUNTIES WHERE LOWS WILL BE IN THE 33 TO 38 DEGREE RANGE. HOWEVER...A FEW LOCATIONS MAY SLIP JUST BELOW THE FREEZING MARK IN THE MORE RURAL AND WIND PROTECTED AREAS. FOR ORANGE...SEMINOLE AND OSCEOLA COUNTIES...TEMPERATURES WILL BE IN THE 34 TO 39 DEGREE RANGE BUT A FEW LOCATIONS COULD APPROACH FREEZING. THE REMAINING LOCATIONS WILL EXPERIENCE COLD CONDITIONS BUT LOW TEMPERATURES SHOULD NOT APPROACH FREEZING.  WINDS ARE EXPECTED TO REDUCE IN SPEED SOMEWHAT OVERNIGHT...BUT NOT BECOME CALM. WINDS ARE EXPECTED TO CONTINUE OUT OF THE NORTH AT ABOUT 5 TO 10 MPH. AS A RESULT...A WIND CHILL ADVISORY IS IN EFFECT FOR ALL COUNTIES IN EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA. WIND CHILLS WILL BE FROM THE MID 20S OVER THE NORTH FORECAST AREA TO THE LOWER 30S OVER THE SOUTH FORECAST AREA. THE EFFECTS OF WIND CHILL WILL BE THE MOST PRONOUNCED IN OPEN AREAS.  RESIDENTS IN EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA SHOULD TAKE THE NECESSARY PRECAUTIONS TO PREPARE FOR THE COLD TEMPERATURES TONIGHT. CONSIDER OUTDOOR PETS AND ANIMALS...AS WELL AS TENDER PLANTS. ALSO...CHECK IN ON THE ELDERLY AND BE CAUTIOUS WHEN USING SPACE HEATERS. IN THE MORNING...DRESS ACCORDINGLY BEFORE VENTURING OUT DOORS.  OVER THE COASTAL WATERS...A SMALL CRAFT ADVISORY IS IN EFFECT SINCE SEAS ARE FORECAST TO BE 6 TO 8 FEET TONIGHT...AND HIGHER IN THE GULF STREAM. INLAND WATERS WILL CONTINUE CHOPPY.  $$  THE GRAPHICAL VERSION OF THIS HAZARDOUS WEATHER OUTLOOK IS AVAILABLE AT: HTTP://WWW.SRH.NOAA.GOV/MLB/HWOFILES/HWOMAIN.HTML   DWS                               WWUS82 KMLB 212303 SPSMLB AMZ550-555-570-575-FLZ041-044>047-053-054-058-059-064-220500-  EAST CENTRAL FLORIDA HAZARDOUS WEATHER OUTLOOK NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MELBOURNE FL 600 PM EST TUE NOV 21 2000  ...TEMPERATURES AROUND FREEZING IN SOME LOCATIONS TONIGHT... ...WIND CHILL ADVISORIES ALL LOCATIONS TONIGHT... FREEZING TEMPERATURES ARE EXPECTED TONIGHT NORTH OF BROOKSVILLE WITH TEMPERATURES FALLING INTO THE UPPER HALF OF THE 20S TO LOWER 30S. SAFEGUARD PETS...SENSITIVE PLANTS...AND WATER SOURCES. ELSEWHERE OVERNIGHT TEMPERATURES ARE EXPECTED TO FALL INTO THE 30S OVER MOST OF THE INTERIOR PENINSULA WITH NEAR 40 ALONG THE CENTRAL TO SOUTHWEST GULF COAST. ONLY REMOTE WIND PROTECTED AREAS WILL SEE ANY PATCHY FROST IN COLDER LOCATIONS.  THE DRY AND BREEZY AIR MASS WILL ALSO LEAD TO AN INCREASED THREAT FOR THE START AND SPREAD OF WILDFIRE. HANDLE ALL FIRE SOURCES WITH THE UTMOST CARE. CHECK WITH LOCAL DIVISION OF FORESTRY OFFICIALS FOR BURN AUTHORIZATIONS.  AND FOR MARINE AREAS...WINDS ARE EXPECTED TO INCREASE TO 20 KNOTS TODAY INTO EARLY TONIGHT BEFORE SLOWLY DECREASING LATER TONIGHT INTO WEDNESDAY.
